recipientOrganization.name: Fair Frome
recipientOrganization.description: Fair Frome aims to prevent and relieve financial, educational, social and health poverty for people living in Frome and the surrounding areas. This will be achieved through the provision of direct services and through the support and development of other organisations in such a way that they are able to identify and meet these needs. Fair Frome was set up in 2014, initially as a Food Bank, following a feasibility study into the level of poverty within the town. We work alongside communities, families, individuals, volunteers, partner agencies and other stakeholders to create joined up, sustainable services, support innovation, raise awareness of the issues of poverty and increase participation across Frome. Our current services include: • Ensuring that everyone has access to food through the Food Bank • Providing furniture and electrical goods for those who need them through the Furniture Bank • Running community dining events 3 times a week which bring people together in different areas of the town and provide a hot meal to those that need it -Running Holiday Hunger 3 times a week -Access for all -Financial assistance programme to ensure access to school uniform, shoes, clubs, etc.

With the support of our dedicated team of volunteers, we prepare emergency food supplies for people in need. Non-perishable foods are donated,by individuals,local churches, schools and businesses. We offer bags of food to those who come with a referral form.

recipientOrganization.name: The Hull (North Bransholme) Phoenix Project
recipientOrganization.description: To promote, education providing facilities that develop the interest and meet the needs of the community with the intent of improving life and community cohesion in Bransholme. As a community centre our aim is to make ourselves an integral part of the community and coordinate such activities to bring the community members together, to provide a safe place for all individuals, of all ages and community groups; to meet, try new things, and develop the skills and confidence they need to succeed. In doing so we hope to enrich the lives of individuals. The benefits of our community centre include providing the opportunity for people to be involved in a wide range of learning, social and physical activities. promoting individual and community involvement and well-being, promoting social inclusion for people with difficulties which prevent them becoming involved. We provide quality programmes of work and activities which give our attendees opportunities to learn new skills and provided a range of positive experiences. We currently deliver a range of programs including a friendship group for the over 60’s, after school and holiday club activities and ‘Cool kids cook’ were we promote the benefits of healthy eating on a budget. We also provide a range of programs run by partner organizations’ or our volunteers for the local people including math’s, literacy and ICT classes, drama, football, dance and gymnastics classes. We hold seasonal events and fairs where we aim to get the whole community involved in.

grants.Impact Category: Maximise ability to strengthen community cohesion and build social capacity

recipientOrganization.name: The Hinge Centre limited
recipientOrganization.description: The Hinge Centre provides support, guidance, services and opportunities to those facing social and financial deprivation. We are committed to ensuring support is available to some of the most vulnerable members of our society of the services & sessions we facilitate from the centre include: Job club & employability development, Independent Living skills for young adults, benefit & welfare support, Arts & Crafts sessions for the vulnerable and isolated, daily after school clubs for children, 1-1 and group personal development sessions (on topics such as budgeting, anger management), advocacy work, independent living skills for adults with learning disabilities and homeless support including resettlement. We also offer food provisions for individuals and families in the local community, many of which are facing financial hardship for various reasons.

grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Clapham Community Shop Limited
recipientOrganization.description: Our purpose is to provide a community owned shop which is commercially viable and strives to meet the changing needs of our customers and community. Not only does it supply newspapers, groceries, freshly baked bread and provide a prescription collection service and home deliveries, it has become the vibrant hub of the village where residents can come for a chat, buy tickets for events at the village hall and catch up on local news. It also reduces the carbon footprint by using local suppliers wherever possible and enabling people to purchase provisions within the village. Our shop provides an opportunity to be involved with a project which benefits the whole community; it gives people an outlet for their need to care for their fellow residents; and it reduces social isolation and loneliness.

grants.title: Covid19

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Beverley Community Lift
recipientOrganization.description: Beverley Community Lift Is a Transport Charity based in Beverley East Yorkshire. operating in Beverley,Pocklington,Market Weighton, Holme on Spalding Moor,and surrounding villages. We provide a door to door accessible transport service for anyone who cannot easily use other forms of transport because They are elderly Have physical disabilities Have learning difficulties Have mental health needs They are socially or rurally isolated Our key aims and objectives are :- To support and encourage independence to allow people to access local health services To support local social groups to improve wellbeing and quality of life To support and encourage volunteering in the community To work with other groups /agencies to improve the quality of life of the community. We provide a bespoke car transport service. Our volunteer drivers use their own cars to transport service users to and from their requested destinations. These are usually health related appointments e.g GP,hospital etc. or to see loved ones in hospital or care homes but can be social also. Our minibuses are wheelchair adapted and can transport between 11 and 16 passengers. We take groups of local people on weekly food shopping trips and on social outings. Most of our service users are 65-95 years of age,with many living alone Their needs can be Physical - e.g restricted movement, sight/ hearing Intellectual-e.g deteriorating health/memory can prevent enjoyment of hobbies they once loved Emotional-e.g they have lost a sense of belonging or control and feel they are becoming a "bother" Social-e.g no nearby family or friends

recipientOrganization.name: Kyra Women's Project
recipientOrganization.description: Kyra’s Objects As per Articles of Association a. The relief of people with a charitable need, in particular women in financial need, hardship or distress; b. The promotion and preservation of good health in women; c. The promotion of social inclusion of women by preventing them from being socially excluded (being excluded from society as a result of one or more of the following factors: unemployment; financial hardship; youth or old age; ill health (physical or mental); substance abuse or dependency including alcohol or drugs; discrimination on the grounds of sex, race, disability, ethnic origin, religion, belief, creed, sexual orientation or gender re-assignment; poor educational or skills attainment; relationship and family breakdown; poor housing; crime (either as a victim or as an offender rehabilitating back into society) so that they can play a fuller part in their communities and so that their life conditions may improve; d. The furtherance of such other charitable purposes (charitable under English law) as the trustees see for from time to time. Kyra provides ongoing practical and emotional support to help women make changes to their lives. Our services and courses help them cope and respond to challenges such as un-employment, redundancy, and social isolation. Kyra supports women under one roof without having to move from service to service. In particular we work with women who have needs around recovery and needs emanating from isolation - eg; from domestic abuse, mental health, rehabilitation from prison, release from prison, isolation due to age.

grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Halstead Day Centre
recipientOrganization.description: The Day Centre is intended for people over 60 to help alleviate isolation and loneliness for people who are not able to build links with their community by reason's of poor health, disabilities, impairment and other needs, including regaining confidence after a stay in hospital or after a fall. The Centre has a strong commitment to enable older people to address the factors that protect and create general health and well being. Our main objectives are to provide a range of preventative activities that enable people to live as independent as possible in their own home and remain healthy and have non-judgemental support for that choice. Our services include. Transport to and from peoples homes, as well as transport to other health care appointments on the days they attend The Centre. A daily shopping service. A bathing service, especially beneficial to the more frail members and also their family carers. A daily seated exercise class which benefits physical and mental well being. A 2 course freshly cooked lunch and beverages throughout the day. Other activities include, board & card games, quizzes, Bingo, debates, showing of old movies, speakers, entertainers, and trips out to various places of interest. The Centre also has a visiting chiropodist helping to ensure good foot care without the stress of attending a clinic. Our strategy is to work from a comprehensive range of information between, ourselves, the members and other health organisations.

grants.title: Grant to Mind in West Essex
grants.description: to provide a response and recovery grant during the COVID19 crisis to an organisation supporting those with mental health issues in West Essex

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Mind in West Essex
recipientOrganization.description: Mind in West Essex supports people affected by mental ill health, predominantly across West Essex to make positive changes in their lives and to improve their emotional resilience. We also aim to normalise the conversation around mental health and in doing so reduce the stigma that can be a barrier to people accessing the support that could help them to improve their quality of life. We provide a range of services in order to help us deliver on these aims, these include: counselling as part of the NHS psychological therapies service; a private counselling service that provides a wide range of therapeutic interventions and Life Management skills; Mental Health First Aid (MHFA) training; emotional resilience training; peer support; befriending to reduce isolation; bereavement work and community support. In addition to the above client facing services we also run a Mental Health Referral Triage service on behalf of West Essex CCG. This service processes all GP mental health referrals across West Essex and passes them on to the relevant provider. We have an active presence on social media platforms as part of our efforts to normalise mental health and engage with the public in a way that is accessible to a wide range of people. We are also actively engaged with the Time to Change Movement, particularly through engagement with local employers. We aspire to ensure that the following values can be clearly visible throughout our organisation: Welcoming: to everyone who comes into contact with any part of our organisation. Open: to all forms of feedback and open to change. Inclusive: everyone who is part of our organisation feels included and involved. Informed: We listen to what people are telling us and keep up to date with information about best practice. Responsive: We strive to be responsive to the changing needs of the population of West Essex and to the changing requirements of those who commission services from us. Effective: everyone who receives a service from us is helped to move forward on their journey towards mental wellbeing. Giving people the skills and techniques to deal with these issues again in the future.

grants.title: Grant to Homeless Action Resource Project
grants.description: to support homeless people in Southend during the COVID19 crisis

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Homeless Action Resource Project
recipientOrganization.description: HARP is the leading homeless charity in Southend. Our aim is to help prevent homelessness with early intervention as well as helping people overcome homelessness for good. Everything we do is geared towards helping people move away from homelessness permanently, enabling them to lead happy, independent and fulfilling lives within the community. We support over 1,200 people on average every year and as the amount of people affected by homelessness grows so does the demand for our services. At HARP, we are always looking at new ways to help people get off the streets - and stay off the streets. The number of bed spaces we are able to offer has grown, as part of HARP’s response to the growing need in the town, from 174 in mid-2018 to 214 today, plus additional sleeping spaces in our Extended Emergency Service - an overnight shelter at our Bradbury Centre for those in immediate need. we have always emphasised that rough sleeping is just the tip of the iceberg in terms of overall levels of homelessness. Although this is the most visible and dangerous aspect, there are countless more people in precarious accommodation, sofa-surfing, or staying in temporary housing who need ongoing support to avoid and overcome homelessness. And new people are finding themselves in these precarious and often dangerous circumstances every day.Nearly half of the people who came to HARP for help in 2019 were using our services for the first time, and over half of those new visitors were sofa surfing, had no fixed abode, or were at risk of losing their accommodation and were in need of help and support to keep it. This only goes to show how many local people are struggling to keep a roof over their heads and are in danger of ending up on the streets. We desperately need more social housing and affordable accommodation (and this means properties to rent, not just “affordable housing” for people fortunate enough to be able to purchase), as well as better support for people struggling with their financial and housing situations, and a genuine effort to tackle the root causes of homelessness.

grants.description: to supply additional IT equipment to staff and volunteers to ensure they can respond to an increased demand to the COVID19 pandemic

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Citizens Advice Bureau - Harlow
recipientOrganization.description: Citizens Advice Harlow has been serving the the community since 1956. We are here to give people the knowledge and the confidence they need to find their way forward - whoever they are, and whatever their problem. We offer free independant, confidential and impartial advice 5 days per week. This covers benefits, debt, housing, employment to name a few. We also offer specialist Law Clinics and free legal advice as part of our blended offer of advice. We deliver an outreach well as the Permitted Development Housing site at Templefields in Harlow.

grants.title: Grant to Maldon & District Community Voluntary Services
grants.description: to support community response helping people during the COVID19 pandemic in rural districts of Maldon

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Maldon & District Community Voluntary Services
recipientOrganization.description: Maldon and District CVS is the infrastructure charity for Maldon Districts voluntary sector. We have a membership of 130 charites and community groups that work in the Maldon District and offer services such as funding advice, governance advice, information provision and representation. In addition we also host the districts Volunteer Centre and other projects that support people with Maldon District to be more involved with their community. At the current time these projects include - The Essex Shed Network: after successfully launching the Maldon Shed in 2014 Maldon and District CVS were approached by other districts to support them to set up similar projects. Men in Shed projects provide community spaces with a focus on practical activities such as woodwork. These spaces enable local men to build friendships and gain/offer peer support which has the ultimate outcome of improving social connections and decreasing feelings of loneliness. The Essex Shed Network provides support, information and networking opportunities to people involved with or wishing to be involved with Men in Shed projects - Blokes: - spinning off from the Essex Shed Network we are working in partnership with Active Maldon to facilitate local men having support to access existing local services and activities that have positive health outcomes such as walking football or weight management schemes. - Southminster Patio Project: - working with the Memorial Hall in Southminster we are setting up a community gardening space at the rear of their project to enhance the Memorial Halls offer as a community hub for Southminster and to have wellbeing outcomes for local people - Harbour: - running for ten years this project provides social support to local people who are a risk of social isolation. As a weekly coffee morning it offers access to Connect Well social prescribing and wellbeing activities such as gardening, singing and crafts as well as the opportunity to make friendships. - Wellbeing walks: Weekly walks at Maldon Prom Park to encourage people to walk socially as a first step to healthier lives. - The Maldon Active Support Team: this project add value to all the above and the wider sector through the Volunteer Centre and other contacts. Working in a person centred way the project provides bespoke one to one support to people who have barriers to community involvement such as mental health conditions, physical disabilities, low income or low confidence. The Coordinator works with them to explore options they may be interested in and facilitate their involvement, this includes help with form filling, accompanied visits, adaption of opportunities and ongoing support. The MAST project also hosts some small group activities as tasters for community involvement, these are being merged with some of the above projects as the MAST project comes to an end in December 2018 and we are working as an organisation to preserving the legacy of the project.

grants.title: Grant to Chelmsford Community Transport Ltd
grants.description: to provide a shopping service for older people and a transport service for those with health conditions receiving vital treatment at Broomfield Hospital during the COVID19 pandemic

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Chelmsford Community Transport Ltd
recipientOrganization.description: Chelmsford Community Transport offers affordable and accessible travel options to those who may be isolated, lonely or unable to access public transport because of physical or mental disabilities or through rural isolation. Our aim is to provide transport for the most vulnerable people in our community - mostly elderly and disabled. Transport is door-to-door for medical, social or shopping trips; we also organise social excursions each Saturday and monthly social trips for retirement home residents. Using 7 wheelchair accessible minibuses and 15 volunteer car drivers we are a lifeline to many who would not travel without us. We connect people with their communities and ensure they are able to access all the services available to them. In addition to our minibus services we offer a bespoke car service run by volunteer car drivers in their own cars. This service is tailored to the individual and volunteers are able to assist passengers with shopping or sit with them at medical appointments or support groups. We are also able to offer transport for people to visit their loved ones in hospital or in care homes. Our services are much sought after and we are always running at full capacity. Approximately 50 new members join the scheme every month and we carry out approximately 3000 trips per month.

recipientOrganization.name: Brainwave
recipientOrganization.description: Brainwave supports children with physical and/or cognitive disabilities, whether caused by brain injury like cerebral palsy, a genetic condition like Down syndrome, autism, or general developmental delay, through the provision and promotion of specialist therapy. Brainwave’s multidisciplinary team of Paediatric Physio, Occupational and Speech and Language Therapists works with families to deliver home-based therapy and exercise Programmes tailored to each child to help them to achieve their fullest potential. That potential could be anything from a child walking or feeding themselves, to counting or forming sentences. Headquartered in Bridgwater, some 500 children in total are on the Brainwave Programme.

recipientOrganization.name: The Dorothy House Foundation Ltd, also known as Dorothy House Hospice Care
recipientOrganization.description: Dorothy House Hospice Care delivers comprehensive care across 700 square miles, serving a population of 550,000 in Bath and North East Somerset and parts of Wiltshire and Somerset. Our specialist teams provide healthcare, psychological, social, spiritual and practical support for all affected by palliative or life-limiting conditions. All our care is provided free of charge, whenever and wherever it is needed. Our goals are focused on promoting a wider understanding that death is a part of life; enabling everyone to life to its fullest potential, providing outstanding care and support when it matters most and providing families and carers with the support they need through bereavement. Our services include: • A 10 bed Inpatient Unit • Nurse-led Day Patient Services • A team of Clinical Nurse Specialists working in the community • An extensive range of rehabilitation therapies including physiotherapy, occupational therapy, lymphoedema support, complementary therapy, creative therapy and dietetic advice. • Personal, practical, and clinical care in patients’ homes through our Hospice at Home service • Emotional and psychological support for the whole family, both pre- and post-bereavement. • Nurse-led support, clubs, groups and activities at our Outreach Centres • A 24 Hour Advice Line • Educational programmes enabling external colleagues to increase their knowledge of palliative and life-limiting care and conditions. Dorothy House was inspected by the Care Quality Commission in September/October 2016 and received an ‘Outstanding’ rating, placing DH in the top 6% of adult social care providers nationally.

recipientOrganization.name: beverley cherry tree community centre
recipientOrganization.description: Beverley Cherry Tree Community Centre serves the local community, the Swinemoor Estate. Launched initially by the local Children’s Society to provide services specifically for disadvantaged children in the area, it was established as a Community Centre in 1993 and has steadily evolved to become an integral part of the community. The Swinemoor Estate is in the top 15% of multiple deprivation in the country. At the heart of the work of the centre is its advice service, which has provided thousands of individuals from Beverley and the East Riding of Yorkshire with a safe, confidential environment where they can receive guidance and support on a wide range of issues including debt, housing, benefits, homelessness, domestic violence, and legal issues. The Centre also aims to address the poverty and social isolation in the community. Many of the local families are reliant on the Centre for food vouchers for the East Yorkshire Foodbank due to low income. The Centre offers a Youth Group, a Women’s Group, a pensioners’ group. a support group for Stroke survivors and their carers, various other community groups, and is an agent for the regional Credit Union. It has “Little Gruffalo’s” pre-school/nursery/after-school service.

recipientOrganization.name: Goole GoFar
recipientOrganization.description: We provide accessible transport solutions for the people of Goole and the surrounding areas (Howdenshire & Marshland areas) who are vulnerable, isolated and socially excluded, regardless of their age. Our service is unique as it helps to reduce the barriers to transport (rurality, accessibility and affordability) thereby reducing isolation. This enables our users to become more independent and socially active, thus, creating a healthier lifestyle for those using the Goole GoFar service. Goole GoFar initially provided services for the elderly, and apart from school contracts, we very rarely offered young people and children any form of transport. However, we now offer a range of services for our elderly members, as well, as low income families, young people and children. We now work with children centres, youth clubs and community clubs on a continuous basis, as well, as providing transport for children who access extra – curricular activities through their schools. We also offer a large range of services including: •MiBus and Dial - A - Ride services - access to town shopping services. •The MediBus service - access to hospital, doctors and any medical appointment. •GoFar Outings - Days out to areas within the Yorkshire area. •Lunch outings to eating establishments/ restaurants based locally for the elderly. •Providing the elderly with access to theatre productions •Day Trips for low income families, young people and children who access their local children centre. We work with all children centre’s based in the locality. •School contracts - Home to school contracts/ extra curricular

recipientOrganization.name: Community Works CIO
recipientOrganization.description: Thirsk Community Care has merged into The Clock and together are called Community Works. It remains an independent charity, predominately working in rural Thirsk and surrounding rural areas. We “support people in North Yorkshire to engage with and contribute to their community”. The merger has achieved the ambition to have a single point of contact for children, young people, adults and older people who need to access support or a service. We can now provide a truly holistic service, not only to the individual but to the family. We are also providing support to other local charities. Our aim is to facilitate partnerships to support people in North Yorkshire, particularly from Thirsk to connect with and contribute to their community by providing opportunities for them to improve their economic, health and social wellbeing. We have four objectives: Increase Social Inclusion– We want our communities to be more socially included. Over the next three years our work will help more of our members to belong, join in, and contribute to community life. Fewer people will feel isolated and will have taken up opportunities to make and sustain friendships. More members will have moved on to join other local community groups with our support and taken part in ‘giving back’ activities that have grown their feelings of community belonging. As part of this we will have delivered focused pieces of work supporting people with mental health problems, older people, unemployed young people, and people with long-term ill health.

recipientOrganization.name: Restore ( York ) Limited
recipientOrganization.description: Restore aims to house and support those who would otherwise be homeless in York. We now have nine properties housing a total of 35 residents at any one time. Seven of the houses are male-only and two are female-only. Our current age range is from 18 to 65. We currently employ 5.5 staff and have several regular volunteers. Our costs of providing accommodation are covered by our working arrangement with the City of York Council, but it is by offering an extra level of support that we are able to engage with residents, help them get to the root cause of their homelessness and help them to move forward in their lives, with the ultimate aim of them moving into unsupported accommodation and commit to regular employment. This extra support has to be funded by grants, fundraising events and regular donations. The number of referrals we receive from other agencies ( such as The Probation Service, City of York Council, the Salvation Army and various homeless hostels etc ) has continued to rise. Our residents have a variety of issues, often a combination of mental health issues, physical health issues and addictions and many have previously found themselves in prison. All are unemployed and homeless when they are first referred to us.

recipientOrganization.name: BCCS
recipientOrganization.description: At bccs our concern and core business is the emotional health and well-being of children and young people with the main focus of our work being the early intervention, prevention and lessening of behavioural and emotional problems in children and young people. We employ qualified and dedicated Social Workers & Counsellors to deliver a caring professional service, which is structured and intensive where necessary. Our unique approach is to intervene a soon as problems are identified and work with the children for a long as it takes to put things right. Mental health problems affect about 1 in 10 children or young people and are often a direct response to what is happening in their lives. Without effective intervention, these conditions can have a significant impact on their life chances. Our experienced mental health professionals not only support the child through one to one counselling sessions but also, by conducting thorough assessments are able to provide expert advice and support to both school staff, parents and families. The majority of children we help come to us, or are referred to us through their school and it is a fact that a child with emotional and behavioural problems can often cause disruption in a classroom and generally hinder their own learning and that of the other children in the class. Through our intervention we are able to offer support to the child or young person, their families as well as both the school and their staff.

recipientOrganization.name: Chelmsford Council for Voluntary Services
recipientOrganization.description: Chelmsford Council for Voluntary Service (CVS) works to support, promote and develop local voluntary action to improve the effectiveness of voluntary and community activity in Chelmsford. Based at the Centre Supporting Voluntary Action we host small community projects, such as the Supported Volunteer Craft Group and run a busy Volunteering Centre. Last year the CVS worked directly with 317 different charities, voluntary and community groups and with 8 local strategic partners. Types of groups range from small entirely voluntary up to large multi million pond charites such as Farleigh. We support small group development in many different ways including constitutions, policies, becoming fit for grant funding, improving branding and marketing, finding funding. We also act as a central point for information cascade sending out weekly e-bulletins, information, facilitating forums, and delivering major events to bring together strategic influencers and the local voluntary sector.

grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Basildon Community Resource Centre
recipientOrganization.description: To provide a safe, professional and comforting environment for those in crisis to receive help. To ensure a listening ear approach in a non-judgemental and kindly manner. To offer support and advice via welfare rights and benefit guidance, specialist housing advice, accommodation at affordable rents, online and paper applications and letters of all descriptions, liaison with utility companies to arrange payment plans to clear arrears, liaison with bailiffs and mortgage companies and landlords to help arrangement payment to avoid repossession or eviction. Liaison with loan companies to ensure clients are being treated fairly. We also mediate between private landlords and tenants to resolve disagreements before any situation goes beyond redemption. Full assistance with disability issues and completion of Personal Independence Payment (PIP), children's Disability Living Allowance (DLA) and Attendance Allowance (AA) forms, mandatory reconsiderations and appeals. Whilst not a foodbank we provide and have done for over 13 years , sets of parcels of food and toiletries, loo rolls, baby essentials including nappies, household goods and cleaning liquids to those in an emergency need situation - issued on production of a written referral only from an agency. Staff have the authority to provide goods if necessary. These goods are all donated by churches and other faith organisations, schools and the general public and local businesses. Via a CVS Winter Warmth Grant we provide top ups for gas and electricity meters, in emergency only. We also help with the purchase of uniform for children in an impoverished family situation; these funds are donated to us specifically. We give out tents, airbeds, sleeping bags and chairs to those sleeping rough on the streets and in vehicles; donated via V Festival Clearance and Lighthouse Furniture Project. Also duvets, bedding and towels are provided to those in need once a tenancy has been arranged and where they have no funds to buy such items having paid out deposits and rent in advance to secure a home. We give out what comes in by way of donations as many individuals and agencies both statutory, nonstatutory, voluntary sector, local businesses such as Co-op, Johnsons, Howdens Joinery, Pipetech, individuals, churches and faith organisations give to the Centre. We operate a subsidised canteen serving hot and cold drinks and cold snacks at incredibly cheap prices. Specific Universal Credit assistance is provided, especially with online application and set up and then ongoing via a claimant's journal. Often clients are not able or have the wherewithal or access to a computer for this type of benefit take up and regularly we see people in obvious distress concerning this situation. We are experienced in helping and supporting claimants in enabling access to in order fulfil the requirements of the benefit itself. This is an essential and valuable service and extremely time consuming as more and more folk are being transferred over to UC and then are panicking about application and budgeting the new type of payment. This help was requested by local claimants and by the Job Centre Plus office as they are unable to assist directly with a claim or a setup of a UC account.

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Home-Start Colchester
recipientOrganization.description: Our aim is to make a real difference to the lives of local children and their families.” To safeguard, protect and preserve the good health, both mental and physical of children and parents of children: To prevent cruelty to or maltreatment of children; to relieve sickness, poverty and need amongst children and parents of children: To promote the education of the public in better standards of child care within the area of Colchester and South Tendring. To achieve our aims we provide bespoke mentoring and befriending services via one to one or in groups to benefit both parents and their children up to the age of 11 years. Group mentoring is in response to identified needs in our local community and we reach out to families most in need. Our core work is a Home-Start model of which independent research found 3 years after support ended both parent and child outcomes continued. Volunteers play an important role and offer the assistance of another person to provide both emotional and practical mentoring support in supervised role. Alongside this core work we identify need and pop up innovative projects in response. All our projects work on the principle of building skills and not building dependency with the goals to make life long changes that will support lasting change for local children we support.

We work hard to ensure the voluntary sector has the strength and resilience to thrive in a changing and challenging environment. CVSU also represents the sector at a strategic level and through engagement , partnership and collaboration we ensure the sectors influence is strengthened and that diverse voices are heard within all sectors. When we identify a need in the community or gaps in service provision we develop community projects to address these issues. We also piloted in 2018 the Green Matters gardening project..

recipientOrganization.name: Escapeline
recipientOrganization.description: Escapeline would like to secure the required funding to meet its objectives :  Raise awareness of the prevalence of gangs and child exploitation  Educate young people and those responsible for their safety and wellbeing on the dangers of gangs  Reduce the impact that gangs are having on our society  Prevent young people from being exploited by gangs  Support young victims in escaping child exploitation and in rebuilding their lives, their self esteem and their wellbeing. Escapeline plan to achieve their outcomes by providing the following services within the first year: - Deliver training in schools, colleges, universities, health professionals, police and social workers - Carry out preventative workshops for young people in Year's 5, 6 and 7. - Set up parent support groups - Establish relationships with other partnerships who can offer youth and sporting opportunities to refer young people who are on the cusp of being exploited by county line gangs - Escapeline plans to start and train a group of volunteer mentors to work with young people who have been identified as vulnerable or on the cusp of being exploited by county lines gangs. Following on from this Escapeline would like to recruit a qualified support worker in the first year for young people who are trapped and being exploited by county line gangs and expand this to three in the second year and to five in the third year - Raising awareness within the communities by organising awareness and fundraising days.

We provide environmental education, conservation work, and (relevant to this application) therapeutic Care Farming interventions for people who are vulnerable for a wide variety of reasons. Care Farming is the use of a working farm to promote mental and physical health by using animals, woodlands and the agricultural landscape in work-related activities. recipientOrganization.name: Living Paintings
recipientOrganization.description: Living Paintings purpose is to improve the quality of life for blind and partially sighted people by working to end their social and educational isolation and exclusion that they suffer daily. We do this by creating and publishing Touch to See books that enable an understanding of the visual images that colour and inform all our lives. The books include raised, tactile images and Braille inserts which are brought to life by immersive audio recordings. All our Touch to See books contain colour references encouraging interaction between blind people and the sighted people around them, breaking down the barriers that create social exclusion. Our aim is that everything we do, from creating Touch to See Books, through our online presence extending the content of our books, to our community Book Clubs, is designed to be shared, in order to integrate blind people with the sighted community around them. Our library meets all needs with its continually growing and extensive catalogue of Touch to See book titles. We provide for our littlest readers with the Pre-School Learning Library, with adaptations of the popular illustrated story books such as ‘Spot’ and ‘Peppa Pig.’ The purpose of this application is to enable us to continue to support 153 blind and partially sighted children and young people living in Somerset by providing them with unlimited loans from our growing collection of unique Touch to See books, designed to engage, entertain and educate.

Young Somerset works to achieve social and economic outcomes with young people, through the delivery of measurable outputs and outcomes. Young Somerset seeks to develop a youth work relationship that is open, honest, respectful, trusting and led by the young person. Our vision is a Somerset where young people feel a sense of belonging, a desire to contribute to their communities and have a future that is not limited by poor access to opportunities and services.

recipientOrganization.name: Cheddar Valley Plus
recipientOrganization.description: We work with the Trussel Trust to provide emergency food to people in the Cheddar Valley area which serves small villages and rural communities. Our main role is to operate the Foodbank from our warehouse in Cheddar. We will also signpost clients to organisations that can help them if necessary. We are committed to raising awareness of our operation in the local area bearing in mind that this is widespread and communication is not the best regarding public transport etc. We collect food from local organisation such as shops, churches, community groups and cafes and local people. We weigh collections and update the Trussel trust data management system with the weights and info regarding the clients we supply food to for their national statistics. We manage the accounts of any monetary donations and pay the overheads of running the warehouse. The acoounts are independently audited every year. We rely totally on volunteers who keep the Foodbank open twice a week for 2 hours at a time and adhere to all health and safety requirements and any Trussel Trust recommendations. We are endeavouring to increase our profile through marketing , word of mouth and some press releases but still have a long way to go on this.

All carers are also offered this rate. we aim to help those with mental health problems to lead a full life even with their mental health and also to remove as many as we can from the isolation that comes along with these illnesses, we also offer places to those who find that through age they have become isolated, as these people have so many skills to share with the young adults in the community. We aim to become self sustaining through the PIP garage and paying clients on the recovery courses. we also offer classic car restoration to the general public.
