grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: Salary costs for 3 months for a Family Support Worker, supporting families with terminally-ill children during the Covid-19 crisis

recipientOrganization.name: Rainbow Trust Children's Charity
recipientOrganization.description: Rainbow Trust Children's Charity (RTCC) is a national registered charity and company limited by guarantee which provides practical and emotional support to families throughout the country who have a child with a life-threatening or terminal illness. The charity provides individually tailored support to approximately 1,000 families each year. The charity's Surrey Team, based in Leatherhead, currently consists of 6 Family Support Workers and 1 Family Support Manager. The key areas which the team are working within are Caterham and Hooley in East Surrey, as well as Guildford. Families in need can self-refer, or are referred from a hospital or another partner organisation. Support lasts from diagnosis throughout treatment, and continues to the stage of recovery or bereavement and beyond, for as long as the family needs it. Support can include giving parents a chance to relax or go out for a few hours; spending time with the sick child or their siblings (talking through their worries and/or facilitating activities); helping both the sick child and their sibling(s) to remain in school by offering transport and helping them with homework; providing transport for hospital appointments or collection of medication; and liaison between parents, social workers, and other care providers, including acting as an advocate where necessary. RTCC is managed by 8 Trustees and employs over 90 full-time staff along with around 10 part-time staff.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Mental wellbeing
grants.description: Delivery costs to support people with mental health problems during the Covid-19 crisis, using new remote methods

recipientOrganization.name: Oakleaf Enterprise
recipientOrganization.description: Oakleaf is a local charity based in Guildford, offering work-related training, work experience and wider support (through social wellbeing activities and counselling) to local adults in Surrey suffering any mental illness, including bi-polar disorder, schizophrenia, depression and anxiety. Our aims are to instil confidence, boost self-esteem, reduce social isolation and to enable clients to turn their lives around, to move positively to the future with relevant vocational qualifications leading to meaningful employment for many clients. Our mission is: “We work to foster confidence and reduce social isolation by actively training, engaging and supporting individuals with mental ill-health to empower them to participate as active members of society”. Our vision is “To improve the lives of people managing mental ill-health in Surrey, to promote awareness and reduce stigma”. Our work-related training focuses on IT, upholstery and gardening. Clients join us often at a very low point in their life, but with support, guidance and a structured day, many develop new skills, secure qualifications and can begin to move back into employment. Alongside this training, we offer counselling and a full programme of social wellbeing activities – ranging from low impact yoga and mindful colouring (just an hour per week) to more intensive endeavours such our art classes, football team or choir. Our Client Services team monitors the wellbeing of all clients, measuring the impact of our work using the Recovery Star mental health assessment tool. The team meet with each client every three months, supporting them to review their progress, to revise personal targets and to move forwards positively.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Mental wellbeing
grants.description: Salary costs to help a charity support young people who are suffering during the Covid-19 crisis, using new practises

recipientOrganization.name: East to West
recipientOrganization.description: East to West (ETW) is a registered charity and Limited Company with a Christian ethos. It was founded in 1996, and became incorporated in 2009. Its stated aims are to assist in the relief of human suffering and poverty, advance the Christian faith, and to help advance in life and relieve the needs of young people. The charity delivers the following projects: School Relational Support Work (RSW), Family Link RSW, Community RSW, and supported lodgings for homeless young people. From a base in Egham, the charity employs 4 full-time staff and 13 part-time staff relating to work across Elmbridge, Runnymede, Spelthorne, Surrey Heath, and Woking, as well as Berkshire. ETW’s work is targeted at young people aged 4 to 18. Of the 613 young people worked with during the year to 31st August 2017, ETW saw a successful conclusion in 328 instances. For a further 148, ETW reached a point where the young people could operate without regular external support, and a further 180 young people dropped in to share an issue that could either be resolved quickly, or they were moved to another school. Additionally, ETW ran 44 small support groups during the year, providing breakfast clubs, and addressing issues such as stress, anger, and low self-esteem. EYW is managed by 6 Trustees.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: To fund support of children and adults with learning disabilities during the Covid-19 crisis

recipientOrganization.name: LinkAble Woking Ltd
recipientOrganization.description: LinkAble was set up in 1989 and serves Woking and Surrey Heath. Since then the charity has been providing experiences, activities and opportunities for children and adults with learning disabilities. Our children's services run on Saturdays and during school holidays. They offer younger service user’s opportunities to play, experiment, learn, take risks and form meaningful friendships in a supportive and safe environment. Our youth service runs on Saturdays, in the school holidays and during the week at Youth Clubs. Those attending our services able to access activities and experiences that they might otherwise not be able to without LinkAble’s specially trained staff. LinkAble’s services for adults in Woking with learning disabilities can be broadly sorted in to two groups. 1. Day time services tend to be used by adults with higher needs and focus on providing new experiences and accessing supported sporting activities such as cycling, yoga, Zumba as well as those that give back to the community by volunteering with rangers from Horsell Common and helping to make poppies for remembrance Sunday for the Royal British Legion. 2. Evening services generally feature more user-led social and recreational activities such as sporting activities, theatre visits and cooking together. Our transition groups MOP and SHMOU are unique to Woking and Surrey Heath as no other provider offers anything similar to them.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Families with Young Children
grants.description: Contribution to salary costs to enable help and support to be given to families with children under 5 via remote methods during the Covid-19 crisis

recipientOrganization.name: Home-Start Spelthorne
recipientOrganization.description: Home-Start Spelthorne converted to a Charitable Incorporated Organisation (CIO) on 1st April 2015 and is affiliated to the Home-Start UK network. The aim of the CIO is to support families who are experiencing difficulties or suffering stress and have at least one child under the age of five. Support is provided via home visiting volunteers, who meet with the family once a week to assist with various aspects of parenting, ranging from practical help in caring for the child, to the development of parenting skills, confidence and self-esteem. The visits are focused on increasing the independence of the family, emphasising the pleasures of family life, and reassuring parents that difficulties in bringing up children are not unusual. The approach of volunteers is flexible to take account of different needs of each family, and the charity carefully matches volunteers with families based on their skills and experience.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: Funding toward delivering an outreach approach by an organisation that works with people that have severe disabilities, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Disability Initiative
recipientOrganization.description: Disability Initiative (DI) is a charity and company limited by guarantee, which specialises in the provision of services to adults with complex physical disabilities and/or acquired brain injury. DI supports service users with continuous assessment and monitoring, initially through the early stages of disability as the person and their family come to terms with such a radical change, and then through the provision of ongoing support. Everyone who attends DI as a client is also a member of the charity and has a stake in its activities, operations and strategic direction. DI specialises in providing care and slow stream rehabilitation to individuals that helps them achieve their goals, no matter how large or small. This is accomplished through a variety of activities, accredited educational courses and therapies unique to DI. Each programme is specifically designed to meet an individual's needs and aspirations. DI operates from a purpose-built centre that offers a fully accessible environment with easy access to Camberley town centre. The charity was established in 1975. It has 9 full-time staff, 7 part-time staff, 25 volunteers and a Management Committee of 6.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: Funding toward the purchase of equipment to keep residents' mobility and cognitive conditioning up, whilst being able to entertain their residents, for a charity that works with people who have complex epilepsy and severe physical and learning difficulties, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: The Meath Epilepsy Trust
recipientOrganization.description: The Meath Epilepsy Trust was founded by Mary, Countess of Meath, described as a forward-thinking philanthropist and a woman of great compassion. Today the Meath is a registered specialist provider, caring for adults who face complex epilepsy coupled with other related disabilities. The Meath provides support to enable clients to live life fully, in an environment as close to home as possible, with opportunities for the development of practical and creative skills. The Meath Trustee Company Limited was incorporated in 2006 and is the Trustee of the Meath Epilepsy Charity. As a registered charity, the Meath provides residential care in Godalming, and supported living accommodation, as well as running a day service on site. The Skills and Enterprise Centre at the Meath has a specialist gym and runs sessions including horticulture, ceramics, Maths, English, IT, a choir and expressive arts. A range of activities and classes take place, including drama, music and dance, poetry, book club, felt making and textiles, social awareness, and holistic therapy. The Arthouse has become part of the Meath's Day Centre, providing an opportunity for people with epilepsy and other disabilities to develop new skills, confidence and self-expression through art. Other enterprises include an up-cycling project, and a café providing work experience for residents of The Meath. In 2017, The Meath celebrated 125 years of being a charity and received an ‘Outstanding’ CQC rating.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Food and Essentials
grants.description: Funding towards the final steps of setting up a Food Aid and Shopping/Prescription Delivery Service in a rural area, with many older and vulnerable people, as a result of Covid-19

recipientOrganization.name: Brockham Emergency Response Team (BERT)
recipientOrganization.description: The Brockham Emergency Response Team (BERT) was set up in December 2013 to provide assistance to the community of Brockham when it is threatened with bad weather or flooding. The team operates within the whole community of Brockham (1,077 houses according to the 2011 census), not just the civil parish. The locality is situated near a number of watercourses which are showing an increased tendency to flood during bad weather, and the Team, made up of Adult BERT, Young BERT and BEV (Brockham Emergency Volunteers) were launched to undertake practical activities for prevention, crisis intervention and a focal point for aid in the event of such an emergency. The organisation is made up of three teams – Adult BERT (25 volunteers with specialist skills and equipment, able to undertake heavy work for extended periods), Young BERT (10 young volunteers, able to help lift and carry goods and sandbags and run errands) and BEV (25 volunteers, helping in a range of ways including comforting neighbours, liaising with insurance companies and emergency rental opportunities, staffing an evacuation centre and driving). The organisation has a management committee of 5. The Community Email run by the group has about 390 subscribers, including local police, other parishes and some businesses. A report on the project can be viewed at http://issuu.com/bert896/docs/bert_origins_july_2015_this_one

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Advice and support
grants.description: Funding toward the purchase of equipment to enable a team of legal experts, based in Esher and District, who offer their services for free, to work from home, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: Funding toward online classes for people who have survived strokes, led by a Speech and Language Therapist by a charity based in Cranleigh, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Dyscover Limited
recipientOrganization.description: Dyscover Ltd. is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee. The charity is a pioneering healthcare and social welfare entity aiming are to improve the quality of life of people with aphasia (often known as dysphasia) and addresses a significant gap in the provision of successful long term management of the condition. Dyscover achieves delivers of circa 200 specialist support sessions annually as the core activity. These half-day sessions are run on 7 days of the week and are delivered to approximately 90 aphasic beneficiaries who attend one session per week on average. In addition Dyscover delivers projects such as singing sessions and a book club. Current projects and service developments are member-led and include support for couples, family support and support for people who have primary progressive aphasia (PPA). Some members also volunteer with Dyscover and are active in groups representing the members or carers of people with the condition. Dyscover was established in 1994 and is based in Walton-on-the-Hill. An annual commitment of £18,500 on the lease runs until December 31st 2017. A satellite group is based in Kingston. Dyscover has 7 Trustees, 8 part-time staff and 28 volunteers.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: Funding towards the essential running costs of a children's charity offering respite care to the parents of children with severe and complex needs, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Cherry Trees
recipientOrganization.description: Cherry Trees is a registered charity (and limited company) set up in 1980 by a group of parents and doctors, providing short-term residential respite care for children and young people with severe learning and physical disabilities. Cherry Trees aims to provide a familiar, homely environment where disabled children can enjoy themselves, whilst their parents and siblings can have a much-needed break from their caring responsibilities, as many of the children need 24-hour care seven days per week. From their home in East Clandon, Cherry Trees supports over 120 families regularly from across Surrey. The charity employs 43 staff who are split between part-time and full-time employment, and is supported by 17 Executive Council Trustees. During the past 10 years, the charity has been booked for over 3,800 visits annually, helping a total of over 400 families. Cherry Trees also has a Bursary Fund aimed at providing care for specific children and support for their families who would otherwise not receive it.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: Core cost support for centre supporting young disabled adults during the Covid-19 crisis

recipientOrganization.name: The Orpheus Centre Trust
recipientOrganization.description: The Orpheus Centre is based in Godstone in Tandridge. It is registered charity and company limited by guarantee. Orpheus was founded in 1998 by musician and entertainer Sir Richard Stilgoe. Orpheus established itself as an independent specialist college in 2012, which exists to promote independence for young disabled adults. The students engage in work experience in a variety of settings and are supported to continue this after moving on from the Centre. Orpheus specialises in performing and visual arts, offering an individualised holistic learning programme. Students are aged between 18 and 25 years and usually stay with the centre for 3 years. They learn subjects like English, Maths and IT alongside the arts and develop the skills to live independently and seek paid or voluntary work opportunities in arts-based or other industries. Orpheus offers a range of qualifications working with awarding bodies. There are 25 full time students living in independent flats, as well as around 25 day-students. Students are all motivated by the performing arts and have performed in venues including the Royal Opera House, Royal Albert Hall, Glastonbury Festival, Notting Hill Carnival, the Paralympic Opening Ceremony, and the Royal Festival Hall.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Homelessness
grants.description: Funding toward the essential running cost of a charity, based in Surrey Heath, that helps to house and feed the homeless, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: The Hope Hub Trust
recipientOrganization.description: The Hope Hub (THH) is a newly formed Charitable Incorporated Organisation (CIO) and was constituted in December 2017 following an independent consultation by Surrey Heath Borough Council which identified a need for a locally based charitable homeless service provider to work in partnership with the local authority and other agencies. As a result, The Hope Hub (THH) has been established to assist vulnerable people aged 18+ who are homeless, at risk of homelessness or otherwise vulnerable with a person-centred approach and will support each one positively empowering them towards independent living. THH will operate from Camberley, Surrey providing a pathway of services to individuals primarily within the Borough of Surrey Heath and surrounding areas. The aims of THH is to provide: H : Holistic range of services provided by qualified and trained staff and volunteers. O : Open access for all who need our services within the Borough. P : Person Centred. E : Empowering each person to move towards independent living. A Pathway of Services is to be offered managed by the Operations and Lead Case Worker. Volunteers will play a key contribution in the delivery of Crisis Support Services. Empowerment Services will be delivered by trained staff, specialists from other Agencies and in partnership with existing service provision within the Churches Together Camberley (CTC) Network but who lack a permanent and fit for purpose location from which to operate. The CTC Network services that will operate from THH include a weekly job club, 1:1 debt management/support, food support and free furniture. Service access and pathway progression will be captured and measured. Close working partnerships and recording of data with beneficiary permission will ensue with all statutory bodies and agencies to maximise individual progression. Case Studies will be captured (with permissions) each quarter. THH is responding to a need by providing a pathway of services leading to empowerment and renewed hope. Services Pathway: Crisis Support Empowerment Services | | - Hot nutritious meal - Case Worker with 1:1 support - Laundry Service - Assistance with/retention of accommodation - Shower & emergency items - Benefit Support & Advocacy - Clothing - Mental Health Worker with 1:1 Support - Healthcare access - Direct Access and referral to specialist services - Recreational Activities - Money management, Job Club, Debt Advice/ - Emergency Food Support - Regular Workshops (with Partners) - Health Clinic (weekly) - Addiction(s) Support access - Volunteering Support/Training & Preparation for Employment (other employment & Social Enterprise services to be developed from year 2 onwards)

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Food and Essentials
grants.description: Funding toward the purchasing of new telephones and a cook and delivery service for those that are vulnerable by a charity, based in Aldershot, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: The Vine Day Centre
recipientOrganization.description: Established in 1987 and becoming a registered charity in February 2003, the Vine Day Centre, located in Aldershot, provides daily support and help to homeless and vulnerable adults. The charity offers a range of frontline services as part of its Journey Programme, addressing both immediate needs and longer term needs. The day centre is open Monday to Friday, providing service users with companionship, and practical assistance including advice on housing and welfare benefits; securing accommodation; and counselling. The Vine also provides drug and alcohol support, healthcare services, a job club and IT support. The centre is equipped to provide a hot mid-day meal, as well as shower and laundry facilities. Life skills, volunteering and training opportunities and other preparation services help clients to become ready to live independently. The charity has also set up and run an Emergency Winter Night Shelter for the last two years (November to March) and a Street Dispersion Project to reduce street drinking during the last two summers (May-September). The Vine provides services in areas where some wards fall within the top 20% of deprivation. Services have been strategically developed to meet the needs of the changing community. Services are provided 9.30 - 1.30 for drop in and support including 1:1 assessments and specialist mental health appointments. From 1.30 - 3.30 The Vine provides specialist group support including GASP (Gambling, Alcohol and Substance Support Project) with group and 1:1 sessions helping individuals identify the impact of addictions. Art Therapy is delivered twice a week, alongside IT training and stage 2 Food Health and Hygiene, literacy and numeracy, debt management and other training opportunities. ‘Silvers’ is the user-led social inclusion project for those aged 55 and over. The charity employs 2 full-time and 11 part-time members of staff, is governed by a board of 7 Trustees, with additional support provided by some 10 volunteers.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Food and Essentials
grants.description: Funding for the compiling and distribution of food parcel to vulnerable people during the Covid-19 crisis

recipientOrganization.name: Renewed Hope Trust
recipientOrganization.description: Renewed Hope Trust (RHT) was established in September 2011 and registered as a CIO in April 2015. RHT is based in Redhill and helps the homeless and disadvantaged in East Surrey. Support includes practical support (food, shelter, clothing, healthcare, and assistance with finding employment and training), as well as building relationships, listening and caring. RHT has many volunteers, mainly from the local churches with whom RHT partners. The charity runs both a Drop-In Service, and a Winter Night Shelter (WNS). The open-to-all Drop-In centre for homeless and vulnerable adults includes a room on the ground floor, accessible by homeless guests, and has a small kitchen and dining room. It serves 10-20 adults every day. The guests cook meals, and receive advice, advocacy, support, and referrals to other partner agencies towards dealing with issues of homelessness, mental ill-health, addictions, depression and low self-esteem. The WNS provides a programme for 7 nights a week every day (including Christmas and New Year) from late November to early March. It provides transportation, hot evening dinners, showers, clothes-washing service, safe and warm beds, control of medication, support, cooked breakfast and a barber service. RHT also hosts "Real Meals" every Sunday lunchtime at the recently acquired Shrewsbury Chapel in Redhill, providing hot meals, friendship and diversionary activities for any homeless and vulnerable adults.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Advice and support
grants.description: Funding toward the purchase of equipment to allow a team, based in Elmbridge, that offer specialist legal advice to work from home, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Citizens Advice Elmbridge West
recipientOrganization.description: We provide free, impartial, independent and confidential advice to the residents of West Elmbridge covering Walton on Thames, Weybridge, Hersham and the surrounding areas. We offer advice to people experiencing problems relating to benefits, debts, employment, housing, discrimination, immigration and nationality, family, personal or consumer problems. Citizens Advice Elmbridge West also hosts and manages a specialist domestic abuse service, known as North Surrey Domestic Abuse Service, supporting people who are experiencing or have experienced domestic abuse and their children. This service supports a wider geographical area supporting residents of Elmbridge, Spelthorne, Epsom and Ewell boroughs of Surrey. Service delivery of both Citizens Advice and Domestic Abuse support services relies very heavily on the support of volunteers. Their contribution is priceless and is at the cornerstone of the service we provide to our community. We have 16 paid staff at Citizens Advice Elmbridge West and approximately 50 volunteers. The value of the hours donated by our volunteers amounts to approximately £240k per year.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Older people
grants.description: IG project to bring connection and joy to isolated older people during the Covid-19 crisis

recipientOrganization.name: Intergenerational Music Making, CIC
recipientOrganization.description: We are a unique music therapy intergenerational non for profit CIC connecting and bringing together generations in their local communities through intergenerational music therapy projects. We bring together local schools, colleges and universities with their local care homes in creating exciting and meaningful music projects to improve well-being. We believe everyone should have the chance to live life to the full. Our intergenerational music programmes give "targeted and identified" children and older people the opportunity to do so. Working together they create music they can feel proud of, gain an increased sense of belonging and feelings of wellbeing. The Intergenerational music therapy projects benefit both the health and education sectors within the community as the work: shares cultural and musical understanding, increases the access to music-making, encourages informal music-making at homes, promotes sustainability by including volunteering and/or staff development and lastly raises self-confidence and self-esteem of participants. - All ages and all abilities at all stages of life. The company aims to seek out opportunities to facilitate meaningful connections and experiences through the medium of music. Everyone has the ability to respond to music, and music therapy uses this connection to facilitate positive changes in emotional wellbeing and communication through the engagement in live music interaction between client and therapist. It can help develop and facilitate communication skills, improve self-confidence and independence, enhance self-awareness and awareness of others, improve concentration and attention skills. At IMM are aims are: - Those experiencing social isolation and exclusion - Those experiencing limitation associated with illness, disability or trauma, for example those living with dementia, Parkinson’s and other enduring health condition. - Local care-homes, nurseries, schools, children centres. - Creating important partnerships between the health and education sector. For example, linking and working closely with adult carers, support workers and care home staff plus teachers and SENCO’s. Cross-disciplinary working. - Establishing relationships that help diminish the impact of declining physical and mental health on older people - Nurturing careers in health care and a lifelong commitment to volunteerism among youth. - Improving health outcomes and quality-of-life for the elderly - Building self-esteem and satisfaction for both age groups through the learning of new skills. We will work with identified (young and old) and targeted groups within Surrey to improve mental health and wellbeing whilst tackling loneliness and social exclusion. IMM intergenerational music programmes are designed to enhance the academic and behavioural outcomes for those identified school children at risk for poor academic achievement while simultaneously enhancing the health and well-being of older adult volunteers who work with them.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Food and Essentials
grants.description: Delivery costs to provide 200+ cooked meals per day to vulnerable people during the Covid-19 crisis

recipientOrganization.name: Stanwell Events
recipientOrganization.description: Stanwell Events (SE) was founded in April 2018 by Anna-Marie Goodacre to provide projects enabling residents to create social cohesion and pride in the community and to raise aspirations and self-esteem. The group was constituted in June 2018 and has recently applied to register as a CIO, the Charity Commission has advised the group that the application may not be processed until April 2020. SE is very closely connected to Stanwell Foodbank (SF), with several of the management being involved in both organisations. SE is now planning to expand its youth projects to help raise aspirations and resilience among young people and expand on food projects to help alleviate food poverty and isolation. Stanwell has been identified as one of the 2 most deprived areas in Surrey. The organisation currently runs the following projects in various locations around the community: Messy play, Art classes for under 12s, Community lunches serving an average of 70 people weekly, dinner clubs for children, a coffee and chaos playgroup, arts and crafts clubs, furniture upcycling project for the over 12s, street dance and games clubs. Events and activities are also run in the school holidays to support our families. SE are expanding the project to 6 days a week to offer more youth provision and help reduce food poverty by offering food at the activities. Nov 2019

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Mental wellbeing
grants.description: To fund the purchase of equipment to offer remote support to people suffering from mental ill-health during the Covid-19 outbreak

recipientOrganization.name: Woking MIND
recipientOrganization.description: Woking Mind (WM) is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee. It was established in 1979 and is affiliated to the National MIND charity. WM provides a safe, welcoming place for people living with enduring mental health problems, offering an evidenced programme of activities and support. The charity’s aims are to prevent mental health problems from escalating; to support the recovery process; to involve and empower members to influence their care; and to promote good mental health practice. The charity works in close partnership with both clinical services and other mental health support providers in Surrey, both receiving and making referrals. Through the year there are courses and activities offered such as arts and crafts, creative writing, cinema club, discussion groups, walking tours, exercise and movement, and the WM football team. WM offers a drop-in service from 10am to 2pm, Monday to Wednesday and this enables members to seek support on days when they may be seriously struggling and unable to engage in structured groups. Informal 1-to-1 support is offered as needed, whether in person, on the phone, or via email. Since January, the charity’s 3 part-time staff have supported people in Surrey over 300 times through these methods. The charity provides mental health awareness training to local schools (free of charge) and to companies (for a donation). WM has 200 active members. The charity has 6 Trustees, 3 part-time staff and 15 volunteers.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Mental wellbeing
grants.description: Providing supporting to vulnerable young people suffering with mental ill-health exacerbated by the Covid-19 outbreak

recipientOrganization.name: Emerge Advocacy CIO
recipientOrganization.description: Emerge Advocacy (EA) is a recently registered CIO (March 2017), which exists to promote and protect good health in particular for those aged between 14 and 21 suffering from mental illness or emotional distress. This is achieved through encouraging engagement with care and treatment; provision of support, advocacy, education and preventative work. A young person can contact EA from hospital and a specially trained Volunteer Youth Worker (VYW) will be sent to reassure and listen to the young person. The VYW will help the young person to articulate their situation, feelings, and wishes to medics; be present during appointments or assessments if desired by the young person; help the young person to understand what medical professionals are communicating; help the young person set positive goals; signpost to community groups and positive activities; and provide follow-up within a week of discharge from hospital. The involvement with a young person may last up to 6 weeks. EA is supported by people from local Churches and exists to support young people of all faiths or none. EA is manages by 7 Trustees, has 1 part-time member of staff, and is supported by 8 volunteers.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Older people
grants.description: Running costs for a Telephone Befriending Service for older people in Mole Valley who are isolating during the Covid-19 outbreak

recipientOrganization.name: Age Concern Mole Valley
recipientOrganization.description: Age Concern Mole Valley (ACMV) is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee. ACMV supports older people (50+) across the district of Mole Valley in Surrey. The vision is ‘improving the lives of older people’ and the mission is ‘making later life a fulfilling and enjoyable experience’. ACMV is a small local charity that has been in operation since 1946. In 2014, Age Concern Dorking & District merged with Age Concern Mole Valley North and became ‘Age Concern Mole Valley’ covering the whole district. One of the main services provided is a ‘Local Community Support Programme’, which offers home visiting, information & signposting, befriending, and social events. ACMV also provides Monday to Friday, (9.00-2.00pm) in the Dorking office, general information and signposting and support. Other services include will writing clinics for later life planning; social events; computer training and support in both Dorking and Leatherhead (4 days per week all year); and Tai Chi classes in Westcott every Thursday. The main office is in Dorking and ACMV does outreach on Tuesdays and Thursdays in Leatherhead each week. ACMV has a lease which continues until February 2023.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Mental wellbeing
grants.description: Funding towards Telephone Counselling Service for people suffering from mental-ill health during the Covid-19 outbreak

recipientOrganization.name: Surrey Drug and Alcohol Care
recipientOrganization.description: Established in March 1986, Surrey Drug and Alcohol Care (SDAC) is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee. The object of the organisation is to relieve sickness, particularly amongst persons suffering from addiction to drugs and alcohol. To this end, the charity provides a 24/7 manned confidential helpline giving emotional support, information and advice to drug and alcohol users, their families and friends within Surrey. The service aims to provide a listening ear, offer motivational support and encouragement and advice and information on drugs and alcohol. The organisation can immediately refer young people between the ages of 13 and 19 and adults into treatment services, and carers into counselling services. The helpline service is free of charge and calls can be received at any time of the day or night, 365 days of the year, thereby providing a continuous service for those in need of help with addiction problems. The charity is governed by a Board of 7 Trustees and runs on the commitment of a team of 33 volunteers. In addition to receiving helpline calls, the charity's trained volunteers also deliver information and education packages into Surrey schools, colleges and to other interested groups.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Food and Essentials
grants.description: Funding toward the purchase of supplies for their clients, by a charity, based in Woking, that offers school items to children living in poverty, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Emmaus Transformation Trust Limited (Incorporating Woking Vineyard Christian Fellowship)
recipientOrganization.description: The charity ‘Woking Vineyard Christian Fellowship’ has recently changed its name with the Charity Commission to ‘Emmaus Transformation Trust’. This is part of a wider evolution in the charity’s work and focus over the past few years through their Lighthouse Project, that focuses on addressing poverty and empowerment in the community, and a partnership with Emmaus Rd Church in Guildford. Their current governing document still has the name ‘Woking Vineyard Christian Fellowship’ because the charity is preparing to shortly change from a Charity and Limited Company, to a Charitable Incorporated Organisation (CIO), and with this will come a revision of our governing documents that will reflect the name change. ‘Woking Vineyard Christian Fellowship’ and ‘Woking Vineyard’ are still registered as operational names with the Charity Commission, so the current governing documents are still valid, although it understandably looks a little confusing to CFS and others when our grant submission documents mention multiple names. This includes the fact that ‘The Lighthouse, Woking’ is our primary public facing operational name, with ‘Emmaus Transformation Trust’ being the less visible name of the charitable organisation. The Lighthouse Centre is a charitable project managed by Emmaus Transformation Trust (ETT). The organisation was established in 1997 and The Lighthouse project was started in 2011. The Lighthouse has progressed from a derelict building to a vibrant hub to serve those who need fresh hope and practical support. Services include the foodbank, addiction recovery support (The Bridge Project), provision of clothing, toys and equipment (The Jigsaw Project), healthy-cooking classes, bread-making classes providing skills and a support network for vulnerable women, confidence coaching, free community lunches on Thursdays, Saturday breakfasts for the homeless, job interview preparation, youth mentoring, social enterprise opportunities, drama and music workshops, and much more. The Jigsaw Project has operated since 2006. It became too big to manage and hence The Lighthouse Centre was established, which now provides a multitude of services. The Lighthouse Centre has a Management Committee of 3 people including the pastor of the Woking Vineyard Church and his wife, 5 additional part-time workers, and 40 volunteers. However, the ETT as a charity has three unrelated Trustees.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: Funding toward a remote physiotherapy service for individuals who suffer with long-term neurological and physical conditions, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: White Lodge Centre
recipientOrganization.description: White Lodge Centre (WLC) is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee, based in Chertsey in Runnymede. The charity was started in the early 1950’s by a group of parents with children with cerebral palsy who recognised the need for a purpose-built treatment centre. Following a successful fundraising campaign, WLC was established on its current site in 1962. Current services include (for disabled children and teenagers) a parent and toddler group, nursery education, play/youth schemes, respite care; and domiciliary care. For disabled adults, services include courses in life and leisure skills, fitness courses, a specialist gym, a back care service for carers, and support groups for parents. Physiotherapy, occupational therapy, hydrotherapy as well as speech and language therapy are also available. This range of services is provided by the charity's 16 full-time and 60 part-time staff, with the support of over 120 volunteers. WLC is managed by 9 Trustees.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Food and Essentials
grants.description: Essential Running costs for a foodbank serving Stanwell

recipientOrganization.name: Stanwell Food Bank
recipientOrganization.description: Stanwell Foodbank (SF) has been operational since February 2019 and exists to address food poverty in Stanwell by distributing parcels of food, baby essentials, toiletries and cleaning products to people in need in Stanwell through referrals from agencies. In partnership with Stanwell Events (SE) community association, it also provides free or affordable food sources at community events such as SE weekly community lunch, children's dinner club, school holiday meal projects, after school clubs, and through Christmas Hampers. The food is sourced from surpluses from supermarkets and other local food businesses, residents’ food donations, fundraising events and purchases made using grants. SF aims that no surplus food is wasted and that no one in Stanwell will go hungry. The group has recently registered as a CIO. SF is closely connected to another organisation (Stanwell Events [SE]), and several people are on the management committee of both organisations. Nov 2019

grants.title: Grant to Voluntary Action Reigate and Banstead
grants.description: Funding toward the essential running costs of an organisation, based in Reigate and Banstead, that recruits and places volunteers, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Voluntary Action Reigate and Banstead
recipientOrganization.description: The aims of Voluntary Action Reigate & Banstead are to build the capacity of the voluntary, community and faith sector (VCFS) in the Borough and to support volunteers and volunteering. We deliver these aims in the following ways: - We provide information and advice to VCFS organisations, assist with fundraising, facilitate networking across the sector and campaign on issues relevant to the voluntary sector. - We promote involvement in volunteering (via events and other marketing) and then match volunteers with local opportunities. We provide personalised support to volunteers with additional needs and ongoing support and training for all volunteers and host organisations. Finally we celebrate the contribution made by volunteers through publicity and awards.

Members enjoy activities plus a nutritious meal and the opportunity to socialize.

grants.title: COVID19 Virtual counselling service for people with mental health needs
grants.description: COVID19 Virtual counselling for those on low incomes

recipientOrganization.name: Somewhere House Somerset
recipientOrganization.description: We are a small charity set up to offer low cost counselling, educational workshops and community projects for the residents of our local community in Sedgemoor, with our headquarters based in Burnham-on-Sea. Somewhere House Somerset was born from the recognition that therapeutic services are not easily accessible to disadvantaged people. Cuts in government funding of mental health services has resulted in long waiting lists (with some waiting up to a year for an appointment). High costs to access private therapy means people on lower incomes are unable to seek support outside the NHS; this leaves individuals suffering alone and in distress. We aim to provide affordable therapy that is accessible to all ethnicities. What makes our services stand out, is that we ask our clients to pay what they can afford towards the cost of their counselling sessions. Our therapist are fully qualified and are members or accredited with BACP (British Association of Counselling Professionals). We follow BACP guidelines and ethics. Our counsellors meet local residents, children and young people, families, parents and lone parents, LGBTQ, victims of crime, violence and abuse, older people, individuals living in poverty, long-term unemployed, people with alcohol and substances misuse and addiction. The individuals we work with feel alone, misunderstood and not heard. They struggle with self-identity, masking their true feelings and experience difficulties in expressing themselves. Issues we help with are mental health difficulties, abuse, trauma, eating disorders, bereavement, anxiety, depression, loneliness, suicidal ideation, stress, bullying, PTSD, family dysfunction, relationship problems, parenting difficulties, substances and alcohol misuse. Our counsellors work to a person-centred approach, helping individuals perceive themselves more consciously whilst working towards meeting their full potential. The clients can talk through deeply personal feelings, find a different perspective and tools to manage difficult emotions; setting new goals and having the confidence to achieve them. Our charity also offers educational workshops. We saw a huge success and growth in 2018/19 for our interactive workshops that we run in schools and colleges; raising awareness on the risk of substances misuse and alcohol. We are fortunate to have volunteers who give their time freely, sharing deeply personal accounts of their lives in addiction, highlighting consequences and the damage caused to themselves, their families, friends and loved ones. Our aim is to pass the right information, so children and young people can make informed choices that are based in facts. Somewhere House Somerset also provides community projects. We believe that each person we support should have opportunities to develop relationships, learn new things and enjoy the activities they wish to do, we create supportive environments for the community and this is why we run community projects. We promote choice and inclusion and shape a service that is individual as they are. Becoming part of the local community enables individuals to live an active and inclusive life. Right now, we have a 5-a-side footie league that get together and have fun every Monday night. We run coffee mornings on a monthly basis and pub quiz every 6 months. The most important aspect of our work is that we bring long-term emotional, mental wellbeing and safety for the individuals we counsel. The work we conduct allows people to become more aware of the choices they make, resulting in creating greater awareness of the impact their behaviour has on each other, their friends, family and love ones. We have testimonials from clients that have used our service that can be evidenced upon request.

grants.title: COVID19 Activity packs for children in Wilstock

recipientOrganization.name: Wilstockhub
recipientOrganization.description: • The needs of the community for a community centre were first established by community residents consulting all residents in 2014. Our consultation found that there was demand for a community centre. In order to address this finding and secure investment, Wilstockhub was founded as a Company Limited by Guarantee (CLG) with no share capital on 29 April 15. • Following its founding, Wilstockhub Trustees commissioned ‘Locality’, the national membership network for community organisations, to independently consult residents, assess needs and determine attendant cost and risk. Locality confirmed the demand for a community centre was the community’s priority – a place all ages can meet and socialise, enjoy recreation and culture, and young residents can benefit from early years education. • To further its aims Wilstockhub became a registered charity on 22 June 2018. Its charitable objects benefit residents through its association with them, local authorities, voluntary and other organisations by advancing education and providing social welfare, recreation and leisure facilities for all residents. • Six trustees exercise collective governance, oversight and management of the CLG and registered charity which is Wilstockhub. Building Wilstockhub is a two phase project. Phase 1 will found the communal community space. Phase 2 will complete this building project. • The Wilstockhub Charity/CLG works with organisations to offer Wilstock and Stockmoor residents of all ages a varied programme of easily accessible and attractive community events and wellbeing activities year-round. 2. Please summarise your application in 5 bullets including (1) the HPC impact(s) you are mitigating/opportunity you are accessing (2) The community need arising from the impact (3) your primary project activity (4) The benefit your community will feel (5) Your project’s legacy. • The HPC impacts the Wilstockhub project is aiming to mitigate are as follows: 1. increased resident numbers. 2. Access to services. 3. Travel and transport. • The community needs arising from the HPC impacts on Wilstock and Stockmoor are: 1. To join all residents together as one community. 2. To overcome the lack of infrastructure serving our community through enabling access to and enjoyment of shared community services. 3. To Increase our community’s confidence in our community’s future. • Our primary project activity is to design, build, finance and operate Wilstockhub. • The benefits our expanding community will feel from Wilstockhub are as follows: 1. Education, leisure and recreation facilities. 2. Community-led services. 3. Physical space to come together in our community. 3. Less travel to access services. • Our project legacy is growing Wilstockhub into the physical nexus that a) connects current and future residents. b) Provides a vital link between residents and community services.

recipientOrganization.name: Age Concern - Southend
recipientOrganization.description: ACSOS offers a friendship/befriending service for older adults; a low cost transport service (driver mileage reimbursement only) which offers lifts to and from medical appointments, shopping, day centres/clubs and visits to loved ones in hospital/homes, a ‘handyman’ service to provide assistance with small repairs along with information, wheelchair hire, hearing aid battery replacement, advice and signposting to other services and agencies. The friendship/befriending service seeks to provide comfort, friendship and practical help to residents in the borough of Southend-on-Sea and in Castle Point and Rochford who feel isolated or who need support in maintaining the lifestyle they wish to lead. In addition to providing company, weekly visits or telephone calls also enable the volunteer to monitor the well-being of the person being visited/called (the "visitee"). This is an invaluable service in that any signs of deterioration in the health of the visitee can be reported to the appropriate authority at the earliest possible stage. ACSOS currently befriends c.300 older people. The transport service provided by ACSOS has grown substantially over the past 5 years from c.600 lifts in 2013 to over 4,000 lifts in the past year. ACSOS receives no funding for this service, the only charge being a mileage charge of 47p per mile paid directly to our volunteer drivers. ACSOS has recently merged with Club 50+ CIO (reg. no. 1152184). The club provides health promoting activities such as tai chi, yoga and “keep fit” classes as well as table tennis, short mat bowls, snooker and darts. It also provides line, modern ballroom, sequence and belly dancing tuition and offers lessons to help older people to improve their computer literacy and understand how to use the internet. Members can also play whist and bridge and there are facilities for them to develop skills in arts and crafts. As, due to age, many of its members are not as fit and active as they used to be the club tries to tailor its classes to meet their specific needs. For those that are less active and just want company, the club also has a “tea bar” where members can buy hot or cold drinks and light snacks. As most of its members are pensioners and many are on low incomes, the club has endeavoured to keep its charges as low as possible while trying to ensure that it can pay its bills. For example, charges for tutor-led activities (£2.50 per session) and “tea bar” charges (50p for a cup of tea) are lower than those charged by most other activity clubs or cafes. These activities are much needed as, compared to the national average, Southend has: * a higher than average number of people over 65; * a higher percentage of older people living in deprivation; and * significantly more older people who live alone. Older adults in Southend on Sea are also 2.5% more likely to suffer with multiple long term health conditions than the rest of the UK. ACSOS has recently obtained planning permission from Southend Borough Council to convert the Grade II listed, Havens department store in Westcliff-on-Sea into a "one-stop" centre housing all of the facilities and services need by the older people of Southend and surrounding areas.The community hub is located in an area of Southend that houses a significant percentage of the older residents of the Borough many of whom are on low incomes. The hub will house not only ACSOS but also other local charities such as advocacy, bereavement support and services for those suffering from dementia. It will also house rooms for public health and social services and provide older people with chiropody, hairdressing and beauty treatment services. The hub will also include a café which will offer hot and cold meals and drinks at a reasonable cost throughout the day and will be open to anyone. Club 50+, which has over 200 members, will be relocated to the first floor of hub from its current premises in Queens Road, Southend that is being converted into flats at the beginning of 2019. The hub will offer a range of regular ‘pop up’ services delivered by the Police, Fire Service, Peabody, Alzheimers Society and any other local organizations and charities who can offer services or information appropriate for the service users. There will be a number of opportunities for the sharing of experience and skills through inter-generational activities, for example, a “Men's Shed” will be in situ at the Hub which will offer people (both men and women) the chance to develop woodworking and metal working skills.

grants.title: Grant to Colchester Foodbank
grants.description: to provide additional staff time, volunteer expenses and purchase food to enable a timely response to COVID19 pandemic

grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Colchester Foodbank
recipientOrganization.description: What we want to see happen in the longer term (Our vision) To end hunger and poverty in the UK. What we intend to do to help make this happen (Our Aims) The prevention or relief of poverty in Colchester and the surrounding area, in particular, but not exclusively, by providing emergency food supplies to individuals in need and/or charities or other organisations working to prevent or relieve poverty. What we do (Our Mission) The Foodbank exists to prevent or relieve poverty in Colchester and the surrounding area, in particular, but not exclusively, by providing emergency food supplies to individuals with assessed short-term need and/or to charities or other organisations working towards the same aims. How we help (Delivering for the common good /public benefit) Colchester Foodbank provides short-term emergency support to individuals and families in a crisis within Colchester and the surrounding area, including Brightlingsea. We also work with other local food banks and regularly review our areas of coverage in response to need. To qualify for help, families and individuals must be referred by a professional from a partner organisation, such as Social Services, One Support, Community Mental Health Team, local housing groups, Citizens Advice Bureau and Age UK. We also work with Churches, Schools, GP Surgeries, philanthropic individuals and businesses. The need for referral to Colchester Foodbank is usually caused by a complex combination of events that may include factors like benefits delays, unemployment, illness and domestic violence. Where possible we refer or signpost people to relevant agencies, so they can get the additional help they need. This enables them to more fully understand the reality of their issues and how to get through them, seeking appropriate support and targeted transitional intervention. Also for us, to be able to monitor our longer term social impact. The way we behave while doing what we do (Our values) Colchester Foodbank is committed to community built on diversity, tolerance, cooperation, and mutual respect; we want to contribute to society and demonstrate social responsibility. Our values are important to us, and we aim to live them out in all areas of our work. We are passionate about what we do and the difference it makes in the lives of others We are compassionate; we give selflessly and put others before ourselves We hold ourselves accountable: we acknowledge and assume responsibility for actions, decisions, and consequences – as individuals and as an organisation. We are innovative, with the ambition to pursue new and creative ideas that have the potential to change lives for the better. We empower and encourage staff, volunteers and clients to take the initiative and achieve their best, in a safe environment where mistakes are viewed as learning opportunities. We provide three days’ nutritionally balanced emergency food and support to local people who are referred to us in crisis. Our emergency three day food parcels contain: Tinned soup; beans; vegetables; fish; & Meat; pasta, rice & spaghetti; cook-in sauces; Cereals; long-life milk; sugar; tea and coffee; fruit juices/squash; biscuits; jams; tinned fruit and puddings. Additional optional items (Specifically single item packs that are small and easy to carry) • Toiletry items such as: toothpaste; shower gel; shampoo; deodorant • Baby items as required: food; wipes and nappies • Small Washing up liquid and small washing powder packs • Some cooking utensils as sometimes clients do not have access to these, plus tin openers. • Pet food as required Plus ”Bags for life”, we use 3 for every adult emergency food parcel, 6 for a family emergency food parcel. We provide a small number of homeless parcels which include food items that don’t require a kitchen including just add hot water packets (pot noodles/ porridge), ring pulled tins (fruit, ham, corned beef) our main partner agency in distributing these is Beacon House. Our parcels are generically made up but we then work with each client, to make them bespoke to their personal needs. Be it food that doesn’t require cooking, gluten free, Kosher, Halal, vegetarian, vegan, apescatarian or if they just don’t like something in particular we will remove it from the parcel and try to exchange it. We provide information about our services to school assemblies, voluntary organisations and at events. We offer guided tours and talks to scouts, schools and other interested parties. Between August 2016 and July 2017 the Foodbank provided 743 family parcels and 1879 standard parcels. This fed 6090 people, of which 3478 were adults and 2612 were children. We provide well over 200 emergency food parcels every month, feeding about 500 people every month. We also provide ingredients to support the charity food 4 kids, so they can bake cakes for children's birthdays. Two years ago, we provided individuals and families in crisis with three day emergency food parcels, specifically to support 4,919 people. Last year the demand for our service increased by 342, so we fed 5,261 people. This year, demand has increased by a further 507 people, so we fed 5,768 people.

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Rainbow Services
recipientOrganization.description: Rainbow Services (Harlow) is a local charity which acts as the infrastructure support services provider for the VCSE across Harlow with extensive networks across communities, businesses and voluntary sector organisations and delivers several community projects with vulnerable and disadvantaged communities in the town, including older residents, those living in the Permitted Housing developments, young people at risk of crime and gangs, offenders, and vulnerable communities: - Rainbow Services provides infrastructure support to local voluntary and community groups, holding regular meetings, workshops and publishing a weekly e-bulletin sharing information on subjects relevant to the sector. As part of this role we also encourage the forming of partnerships and collaborative working across Harlow and the wider voluntary sector. We currently co-ordinate 3 partnerships of statutory, private, and VCSE organisations working together to identify solutions to some of the most pressing problems facing communities within Harlow (Permitted Housing Developments; youth and anti-social behaviour; worklessness). We also work closely with Harlow Volunteer Centre and catalyse volunteering across Harlow. This includes through providing direct support to the Tempo Time Credits scheme, promoting it across communities and enabling our affiliates to sign up, providing training sessions and one off volunteering opportunities to earn Time Credits. - Rainbow Services provides direct services to the local community via our Community Builder project, which is currently supporting local older residents to identify and utilise personal and community assets to reduce social isolation and loneliness. We now support this programme across West Essex. We have also introduced a digital element to this and we are providing Digital Buddies to older residents to help them use technological solutions to maintain their independence and social networks. - Our Business Engagement project is working to facilitate a more structured approach to Corporate Social Responsibility and to create a better pipeline for business involvement and volunteering opportunities with the wider Voluntary Sector and local community. - Our Recycling Workshop currently offers 2 projects: the first is a contracted arrangement (with Sodexo) to provide a workplace environment for offenders who have received a community service order through the courts in an environment that is, whilst punitive, also rehabilitative and constructive. This project is the only community and voluntary sector run programme which Sodexo offers in Essex and is creating real opportunities for offenders to give back to their community by building and refurbishing items for local groups and organisations, whilst developing transferable skills which could lead to more positive activities on completion of their order. Service users from this project are involved in a new community venture with St Clare Hospice, upcycling donated furniture for resale in their stores across the region. The second project currently running from the workshop is for young people aged 14 - 18 who are disengaging from school and society and are at risk of crime, violence, gangs, drugs and anti-social behaviour. We offer supported positive activity sessions each week for up to 40 young people each year and accept referrals of from local schools, youth services, the local Community Safety Team and the Youth Offending team. The sessions provide positive, skills based activities supported by adults who have been screened and trained to help the young people learn new skills and positive behaviours through focused, mentored activity for 6 - 8 weeks. We act as a Hub for Youthbuild Essex in delivering 2 Gateway qualifications which young people can work towards. The young people make items for both themselves/their family (enabling them to develop self-esteem and showcase their achievements) and for local community projects for example bird and bat boxes for the local nature reserve (which they then put up and which they can take friend and family to see, developing self-worth and sense of community belonging). Rainbow has a well established reputation for delivering local projects individually and in partnership with others. Rainbow Services is the partner of choice for Harlow District Council and West Essex CCG in matters of community development and consultation, and we are currently supporting Essex Count Council to trial new methods of consultation with a pilot in Harlow. We have been asked by Harlow Council to co-ordinate a consultation into diverse communities.

grants.title: Grant to Billericay Street Pastors
grants.description: to meet fuel costs of moving vital food and medical supplies in conjunction with Billericay foodbank to vulnerable people during the COVID19 pandemic

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Billericay Street Pastors
recipientOrganization.description: Street Pastors (SP) was introduce to provide a reassuring presence in the local communities. The whole ethos of SP is to listen, care, help and to engage with not only those who are out enjoying themselves within the night-time economy but also those who have found themselves in difficulties. We are trained volunteers from local churches who care about our community. We patrol in teams in town centres usually from 9pm to 2am on a Friday and/or Saturday night offering a helping hand to those who are in need on the streets. We seek to discourage anti-social behaviour by way of being a presence on the streets. This in turn decreases unnecessary call-outs to the emergency services allowing their time to be utilised elsewhere. We provide practical help, which includes handing out flip-flops to those in need, give out free bottled water and lollipops (which surprisingly has a way a diffusing potential altercations). We assist the homeless and rough sleepers with clothes, refreshments, sleeping bags or space blankets. We are called upon by some Councils and the Police to set up in areas which require our input. Alongside SP, new initiatives like Schools Pastors, Rail Pastors and Response Pastors which deal with major incidents assisting the Police and the emergency services/agencies are taking place throughout Essex and other areas. A number of our activities include, signposting individuals and those seeking help and advice to local support services and agencies. We take part in fundraising events to continue the work we are doing and to support those in need. We attend and are invited to various events/meetings run by the Council, the Voluntary sector, Police, Charities, local companies and organisations, we then provide awareness of the services we offer. Billericay Street Pastors (SP) was launched November 2013. We run and take part in outreach events at Summerfest, Soap Box Derby, Remembrance Day and the Christmas Markets. The Coordinator has regular meetings with the Police, Councils and other agencies tackling lower crime and making communities safer. We patrol twice a week on Fridays and Saturdays. We have built up strong links with the night time economy venue owners as a way of information sharing/gathering. Basildon Street Pastors - Launched August 2016. With the support of local Councillors, we were able to open a office space and we are also looking to provide a community hub in the Town Centre to facilitate various groups and offer a drop-in centre. It will signpost individuals/families to supportive services, alleviate suffering, help combat loneliness, homelessness and those disenfranchised from the community. We have had the opportunity of running an outreach tent as part of the 'Love your Borough Day' in Basildon Town centre and also Basildon MAYFEST. These are crucial events to heighten awareness of Street Pastors to different communities informing them we are here to help them. Southend Street Pastors - We attend public meetings which includes Love Southend events, Community in Harmony and the Faith Forum at the Civic Centre. The Coordinator also attends the Purple Flag meetings. Southend is one of the recipients of the Purple Flag, given by the Association of Town Centre Management. The scheme, similar to the Blue Flag for beaches, praised the town's high street and seafront for being "welcoming, safe and clean" and recipient of the Queens Award in 2015. Response Pastors - Our Response Pastors are active on the national database to respond to national crisis impacting our communities. Twelve are from Essex who work with the Police. Schools Pastors - This is to supply pastoral care within local Secondary schools. Links are well under way with 3 Projects. Two of these launched in 2018 at Billericay School and William De Ferrers school at South Woodham Ferrers. Cecil Jones School, Eastwood and Becket Keys in Brentwood are also in early stages of acceptance. This is a joint scheme between Schools Pastors, Council, Police, Church and other schools. Schools Pastors also assist with being a presence on routes home after school to discourage bullying and anti-social behaviour. Rail Pastors - This is the newly formed Project with research and ground work already carried out by the Coordinator which in turn has formed relationships with all interested parties along the C2C line and now the Abellio East Anglia in Essex. The Coordinator attends the Police and Communities Together (PACT) and route Crime monthly meetings. Preliminary meetings have taken place with C2C, Abellio East Anglia, Network Rail and British Transport Police (BTP) to secure a working framework and joined up services to support the work of this local Project. In-house Training - We have trained 24 Response Pastors, some of who have since be deployed nationwide to support communities with major incidents. We carry out county-wide recruitment and shared training sessions for newcomers, refresher training thus creating value for money. Regular meetings - These take place with the 12 Initiatives based in Essex at Police HQ to share best practices and being debriefed on current activities. To keep abreast of current trends, community/service knowledge and information sharing, a number of meetings are attended which is paramount to the continuation of providing an informative service to our communities and the public: Strategic Independent Advisory Group (SIAG) – The Coordinator is an active member of the SIAG and now the local Basildon IAG rep. These groups meet at Police HQ to monitor and advise the police on their community activity. The Coordinator has been active at the SIAG for nearly a year and will continue to be part of this group whilst funding allows. Emergency Resilience Forum (ERF) - This is also attended by Essex Street Pastors. The Joint Emergency Services Inter-operationally Programme (JESIP) forum for the ERF is also attended as we are now a recognised body in Essex as Response Pastors. Pubwatch - These groups in Billericay, Basildon and Southend forms part of the Night Time Economy patrols providing a cohesive platform which continues to share best practices.

recipientOrganization.name: Spark Somerset
recipientOrganization.description: Spark Somerset is the local infrastructure charity, supporting the voluntary and community sector. Our aim is to inspire strong and sustainable communities through voluntary and community action. We provide information, advice, training and support to charities and community groups and represent the sector on strategic bodies. In the last year, we worked 1-2-1 with over 150 community groups, providing guidance and practical support on a range of issues. including start-ups, business planning, funding and volunteer management We run a volunteer service, inspiring people to make a difference in their communities and we are currently exploring more innovative approaches to expanding volunteering options. These include a focus on youth volunteering with the Duke of Edinburgh award and Yeovil College, a supported volunteering scheme and some joint working with SCF's Skills Bank project to build the engagement of employed professionals with voluntary sector organisations. We have previously delivered a youth volunteering project in partnership with Frome Town Council. We also work in partnership with local health services on our Wellbeing South Somerset project.

recipientOrganization.name: Older Citizens Advocacy York
recipientOrganization.description: To achieve its aim, OCAY provides advocacy support for York residents over the age of 50. This support helps older people develop the confidence to speak up for themselves and voice concerns about issues affecting them. We provide generic advocacy ranging from finances and benefits, through to consumer complaints and disability issues. Many of the people we support have underlying issues such as dementia, ill health, disability and frailty as well as the immediate issues for which they seek our help. OCAY supports people to make decisions and implement solutions for themselves, rather than providing advice. We also signpost service users to other organizations in York, if their needs can be better met by another service. Our advocates support clients to access and use these other services if required. Clients need emotional and practical support. OCAY provides emotional support to manage the stress induced by issues such as making claims, which can aggravate existing health difficulties at the root of their claims. OCAY provides the practical support such as help with form filling and supporting at meetings such as assessments and tribunals. We want to achieve a position where all clients have the advocacy support they need and access to appropriate advice and support. We want to maintain timely responses for clients. In 2018/19, OCAY’s staff of 3 (2.6 fte) and volunteer team of 26 supported 301 clients. So far in this financial year we have supported 325 people.

We provide an Equipment and Information Centre, a Volunteer Service, an Eye Clinic service, activities and outreach to anyone struggling with sight loss in the York area.

grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Musical Memories CIC
recipientOrganization.description: Musical Memories provides social singing sessions for older people in rural communities. We have delivered over 550 sessions to 3,000 different individuals, with over 10,00 attendances We sing with approximately 100 older people each week and deliver sessions in Malton, Kirkbymoorside, Pickering, Helmsley and Danby. We sing, chat and laugh with all of our participants who have come to rely on the service we provide. All of them are over 70 years of age and some are 90+. Many of them have chronic health conditions and most live alone. We have provided transport to our sessions to enable them to come along in the winter months and this was very much appreciated by them. The work we have done to combat loneliness and isolation cannot be measured - although judging by the feedback, comments and letter we have received over the past 4 years we know that a Musical Memories session means so much to all our participants and I am very concerned as to how they will fair without them. In summary - they will be heartbroken and lonely.

grants.Impact Category: Maximise ability to strengthen community cohesion and build social capacity

recipientOrganization.name: SELFA
recipientOrganization.description: SELFA support children and families in Craven who are experiencing vulnerabilities to build resilience, thrive and achieve. Since we were founded 11 years ago, we have established a track record of creating positive changes for children and young people who face challenges and empowering them to make their voices heard. This is evidenced by our growing list of referrals with many of our activities over-subscribed. Over the last year 435 children and young people accessed a SELFA activity, including wellbeing projects; holiday workshops and trips; and residentials. The school holidays can be particularly difficult for those who are socially isolated or have difficult home lives and SELFA helps to mitigate this with regular opportunities to meet other people, forge friendships and have fun. We offer lots of opportunities to develop confidence and self-esteem and gain independence through learning skills, trying new things and by taking on responsibilities as part of a task.

recipientOrganization.name: Second Thoughts East Yorkshire
recipientOrganization.description: We are a registered charity supporting people to maintain good mental health as well as manage mental health problems of all kinds. We operate throughout the East Riding of Yorkshire and occasionally surrounding areas including Hull and York. All services are provided at no cost to participants, although employers may be charged for more comprehensive support. We deliver group workshops, in small peer groups of 4 - 6 people over four sessions, each lasting around three hours one day per week. The sessions are confidence building, assertiveness, anxiety management and recognising your skills. The workshops are delivered at various venues across the county. If group workshops seem too much for people, we sometimes offer a limited number of one to one support sessions for people, but this is as a lead in to joining the workshops, not counselling. Mental health is very important and we offer training and information for employers or other organisations on maintaining good mental health, and an overview of mental health problems and personality disorders. Holding on to paid employment is important for people and for employers. With huge costs to recruit, induct and train new staff, it makes far more economic sense to retain valuable employees rather than let them go because of the need for additional support. We offer bespoke training and information for employers. An introductory workshop is arranged followed by more intense workshops and cooperation if requested. This service may carry a nominal charge for companies, but it is very cost effective.
