recipientOrganization.name: Platform (Hull)
recipientOrganization.description: Platform is a day care provision for young adults in the Hull and East Riding area, age age 19-25years, who have a profound and multiple learning disability, for when full time education ends, some of the most vulnerable young people in our local community. None of the care, support and opportunities to we offer to our clients are available through statutory agencies. Our aims are to transform the lives of young people by helping them to reach their potential and support them towards achieving their aspirations ; to build a community which is welcoming and supportive, and support the young people to live a confident and independent life in the community. Our parents forum supports families with the significant challenges that they face every day. Our young people frequently spend periods of time in hospital; we support the families by providing their key worker to stay at the hospital throughout the day which allows some normality for parents carers and siblings. Our specialist staff and facilities aim to provide a wide range of activities which builds upon the skills that has been developed in education; we place a high focus on providing opportunities to develop confidence and social relationships through a wide range of community visits. We have daily access to an on-site hydrotherapy pool; partnerships and links we have built in the community, schools and colleges have enabled our participation in shared events, such as a weekly horticultural club, food technology, shopping and money management.

recipientOrganization.name: Interactive Whitby & District
recipientOrganization.description: InterActive provides play and leisure facilities and respite care to children and young people in the Whitby and District area. We have 3 part time staff and a team of 20 sessional workers. We run holiday playschemes and pre-school term time play projects integrating children of all abilities. Our primary focus is on local disabled children and young people aged 5 to 25. We run regular weekend and holiday outings and activities for all the age groups plus volunteer opportunities and a youth club for the older young people. For their families and carers we provide information and support, flexicare respite and family days.

recipientOrganization.name: Sight Support Ryedale
recipientOrganization.description: Sight Support Ryedale is a member-led charity supporting people living in Ryedale who are blind or have serious sight loss. Our services are specifically tailored to the needs of those who have little or no remaining vision We provide activities, information and assistance to support the changes and challenges which are a result of sight loss. A lack of confidence is one of the biggest challenges a person who has been diagnosed with sight loss faces. In response we deliver ‘ Living with Sight Loss’ courses. These are designed around a programme of workshops delivered by professionals to those who are newly diagnosed as blind or with serious sight loss and those who are experiencing a deterioration of an existing eye condition. These courses give knowledge, practical advice and boost confidence which, ultimately, enables people to deal with their sight loss in a more positive way. We offer a network of support, activities and friendship groups which are fully accessible to those who are blind. Through our regular social and activity groups, we enable our members to overcome the isolation and sense of exclusion often experienced as a result of the loss of sight. Our members can take part in fortnightly In-Touch groups which gives them the opportunity to meet up with old friends and to forge new friendships.

recipientOrganization.name: Move the Masses
recipientOrganization.description: Our mission is to create healthy communities by enabling people to improve their wellbeing through exercise. We do this by: - Breaking down barriers to exercise, especially for those most vulnerable - Providing flexible, rewarding volunteering opportunities linked to physical activity - Empowering people to reclaim their local public spaces as places to exercise - Promote the physical and mental health benefits that regular activity brings We run a walking buddy project called Move Mates, where volunteers walk (or sometimes run) with people who don't have the confidence or ability to get out on their own. Many service uers are older people, but anybody aged 18+ is eligible. Service users currently include people with social or general anxiety, fear of falling, visual impairments and dementia. We also recruit fitness professionals as volunteers to run free, outdoor workouts at the locations of outdoor gyms and trim trails. We promote the locations of these areas on our website and film video workouts with people in the local community, we provide these videos as a free resource for people to use.

recipientOrganization.name: Home-Start York
recipientOrganization.description: We offer early intervention by identifying and providing effective early support to families and their children who are at risk of poor outcomes. Home-Start York recruit and train volunteers. Our team of 42 active volunteers have all attended our 40-hour preparation training course. The training programme covers various topics including parenting skills, safeguarding, signposting, mental health, budgeting and other household management skills. Our volunteers receive ongoing supervision and training. All of our staff and team of volunteers are trained in safeguarding procedures. Once trained, volunteers are carefully assigned a family who they visit each week in their own homes for 2-3 hours. We aim to safeguard, protect and preserve good health, both mental and physical of parents and their children. To prevent cruelty to or maltreatment of children. To relieve sickness, poverty and need among parents and their children. To promote the education of the public in better standards of childcare. After over 30 years of Home-Start York's services in the city, we play an integral part as statutory services continue to withdraw services. With the recent pandemic, we feel it is now essential that we secure further funding so that we can continue to meet the needs of the families in York who need to access early intervention help remotely.

We have identified that many residents in a rural location can feel isolated and vulnerable and we have to strive to provide assistance and support by offering a range of support services. Our work helps our residents and volunteers break isolation and make lasting friendships, access services and the practical help they need or take up one to one support to address barriers that stop them fully engaging in community life. We provide a community hub as a focal point for local services where people can obtain information, advice, support and help. Developing, coordinating and managing local volunteers to operate and develop improved local services by stimulating involvement in local action. Operating and maintain community transport using volunteer drivers, for residents who are not able to access public or private transport. Operating a community library and library delivery service to support the residents in Nidderdale and Washburn and involving the community in its further development to meet local needs.

recipientOrganization.name: Tang Hall Community Centre
recipientOrganization.description: Tang Hall Community Centre sits amid one of the UK's 10% most deprived areas and serve 9,250 residents. Typically, as a community venue, we aim to address social isolation, poverty and health inequality through the help, advice, support and information we provide. We hire our spaces to a number of social enterprises and organisations and let rooms to third parties who hold a wide range of classes, clinics, courses and events. From our Friday breakfast clubs to our food co-operative, as well as fundamental education around growing and cooking healthy food, we encourage residents’ to improve their diet at low cost, which has lasting health benefits, whilst also encouraging social interaction and imparting skills that residents can build on to gain employment, for example. During the coronavirus pendemic, however, we will not be running any classes or workshops, but acting solely as a government Community Hub, delivering advice, support, food and medicine to our those in need within our local community whilst adhering to cleanliness/health rules and social distancing practices.

recipientOrganization.name: Community Integration and Advocacy Centre (CIAC)
recipientOrganization.description: CIAC charitable objectives are:- To advance education and relieve financial hardship amongst Emerging Communities in the Humber Region through the provision of legal and other advice and by any other means as the trustees may determine (Emerging communities are defined as refugees, asylum seekers, EEA migrants and other migrants) CIAC Mission: Supporting emerging communities to contribute fully to life in the UK as committed and active citizens. CIAC provides very low cost, ethical immigration advice to people with recourse to public funds and the right to work underpinning pro bono (free) immigration advice to people without recourse to public funds and the right to work as a long term, sustainable route out of destitution. Our multi-ethnic team of nine volunteers from eight different countries receive training and experience which enhances their future career prospects. Immigration applications such as travel documents, citizenship, lost/replacement BRPs and EU Settled Status are completed by the volunteers under supervision. More complex applications, such as further asylum submissions, lodging appeals, domestic violence applications and family reunions are completed by the CEO/Principal Immigration Advisor. Generalist advice is also provided in our weekly drop in (currently on hold). During the Coronavirus crisis income from fee paying services are expected to reduce yet the demand for pro bono services will increase. In addition, CIAC is bringing together a Local Advisory Group structuring a Well-Being Service offering counselling and therapeutic activities to asylum seekers, refugees and migrants.

recipientOrganization.description: We support and promote communities, charities and volunteers across the Harrogate district, ensuring they can access relevant information, networks and resources. We also run front line services through our Harrogate Easier Living Project (HELP) which enables older and/or vulnerable people to stay and well supported at home. Many of our clients are ‘hard to reach’ as they are not in receipt of statutory services and so are under the radar. Our staff and 98 volunteers provide services to promote independent living and to help tackle social isolation. These services include: voluntary car driving services, a befriending network, a gardening, decorating and odd job service, an information and signposting service and ad hoc social events.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Homelessness
grants.description: Funding toward the purchase of equipment and food for a Woking based charity that helps house and feed the homeless, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: York Road Project
recipientOrganization.description: Established in January 2001, York Road Project (YRP) is a registered charity providing emergency and longer-term accommodation and support to individuals over the age of 18 who are experiencing homelessness. Based in Woking, services include an 11-bed emergency night shelter, 18 beds in four separate ‘move on’ properties supporting a variety of needs, and a Day Centre which provides advocacy, education and training opportunities, and social activities for clients four days per week. YRP aims to provide more than just a roof, but to offer an holistic support package (including accommodation) to address the reasons behind clients’ homelessness. Clients face a range of issues, including addiction, relationship breakdown, unemployment, mental or physical health issues, poor literacy and numeracy, English as a second language, care background, offending, debt and social isolation. The charity considers that education and life skills are paramount in supporting clients to make changes to their lives as a roof alone does not solve all of the problems relating to homelessness. In addition to the training and other services provided, the charity is able to signpost clients to specialist services where appropriate, and also provides help with clothing, travel costs, ordering identification, reconnecting clients with their local area, and assisting clients into employment or volunteering opportunities. YRP currently employs 10 full-time and 8 part-time members of staff and is governed by a Board of 8 Trustees and supported by 8 volunteers. In the nine months to 31 March 2014, the charity saw 1,125 people attending the Day Centre sessions, which led to increased opening hours. 45 individuals were rehoused and 47 helped with benefits, and 66 certificates awarded for a range of skills including IT, Food Hygiene, CSCS and First Aid. The night shelter had an occupancy rate of 95.6% with emergency accommodation offered to 166 individuals. 68.1% of clients are new to homelessness and over half of the clients were forced to sleep rough before accessing the shelter. 30.1% of shelter clients were able to be resettled into secure and appropriate accommodation. Update (June 2016): The charity is also now operating a bigger Day Centre provision, in premises in Goldsworth Road (opposite the Job centre) - open from 7:30am for rough sleepers, providing advice, workshops, skills training and activities promoting wellbeing and self-esteem. (Woking Borough Council funded the refurbishment of this Centre). Growth in the last 4 years - has been by utilising external consultants, to build the skills of the team, to take forwards (i.e. sustainable and cost-effective route). A local chef recently ran a masterclass for clients, one of whom is now engaged in a work experience opportunity.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Mental wellbeing

recipientOrganization.name: Cruse Bereavement Care South West Surrey Area
recipientOrganization.description: Cruse Bereavement Care South West Surrey Area is a local unit of the registered charity, Cruse Bereavement Care which operates throughout England and Wales and Northern Ireland. The charity's main activities are the provision of support and help to people who have suffered bereavement. The South West Surrey unit provides advice and information, support and counselling to adults and children in the boroughs of Surrey Heath, Guildford and Waverley. Services are provided by trained volunteers, free of charge. The majority of clients are offered face-to-face support in their own home, although if this is not possible, the organisation has the use of a number of community venues within the area. Bereavement support groups are also held, where clients can share their experiences with others; and a regular monthly friendship group is run for those who wish to meet in an informal setting. Activities also include providing training and advice to other professionals and organisations as required, and being available to support school or workplace communities affected by a death. The South West Surrey Area has 5 part-time staff and 50 volunteers, and is overseen by a committee of 6 local people. In 2012/13, face-to-face support was provided to 219 bereavement clients, with 57 people participated in bereavement support groups. Each client had an average of 6 sessions with their volunteer or group.

recipientOrganization.name: Headway Surrey
recipientOrganization.description: Based in Stoughton and established in 1985, Headway Surrey Head Injuries Association Limited (known simply as Headway Surrey) is a registered charity which provides rehabilitation, advice and support to those who have suffered head injuries and/or related brain injury or similar trauma, and their families, friends and carers. The main activities include a cognitive rehabilitation programme and personal support services at the Headway Resource Centre, a drop-in facility every Friday and Community Outreach Services supporting those affected by head injury in their own homes and the community. Headway facilitate regular Carers’ Support Meetings and Drop In Sessions to help families and carers re-adjust to significant changes in their loved ones lives. A Volunteer Befriending Scheme, matches volunteers with people who have a brain injury, who enjoy similar social/recreational activities to help combat isolation and stimulate new brain pathways. The Headway website provides information to over 30,000 visitors a year and the staff team offer additional support by phone, email and face-to-face meetings. Headway Surrey also lobbies for improved services and awareness of brain injury to reduce the incident of head injury, and one of the charity's Trustees leads the Surrey Acquired Brain Injury Network (SABIN). The charity is affiliated to Headway UK, the national brain injury association, and works across Surrey. Nov 2019

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Mental wellbeing
grants.description: Funding to upgrade and implement a number of remote working practices to enable support to be given to vulnerable people across Surrey, facing an array of issues during the Covid-19 outbreak

recipientOrganization.name: Surrey Care Trust
recipientOrganization.description: Surrey Care Trust works to tackle disadvantage, social exclusion and hardship in local communities by equipping vulnerable people with the skills to improve their economic situation, reduce their social isolation, and to convince them that they have a valuable contribution to make to society. With a particular focus on areas of relative deprivation, we work with some of the most disadvantaged and socially marginalised people in the county: those from low-income families, vulnerable young people and low-skilled adults, by helping them to: become more skilled and create better chances for life, learning and work feel more respected and valued feel more motivated and able to contribute to the good of society We achieve this by offering a combination of education, training, volunteering and mentoring programmes such as: Offering vulnerable young people a different approach to education on our STEPS to 16 programme Providing a free and independent youth counselling service for those aged 16 to 25 Giving adults a second chance at education with our Adult Learning Programmes Operating our Swingbridge Community Boats; an accredited training centre for people to learn new skills and take part in environmental volunteering Supporting families and giving their children the best start in life at our Children’s Centre, Stanwell Bringing the community in Stanwell together and helping them to take action on local issues by supporting the Local Conversation project Volunteer Mentoring programme - working with young people and adults to raise their skills and realise their aspirations

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Mental wellbeing
grants.description: Costs towards a Telephone Befriending Service addressing loneliness and isolation during the Coronavirus outbreak
grants.Primary beneficiary: People in care or suffering serious illness

recipientOrganization.name: The Brigitte Trust
recipientOrganization.description: The Brigitte Trust (TBT) is a limited company and registered charity, first established in 1984. Originally working across both Surrey and Sussex, the Trust’s operations are now only based in Surrey. The charity trains volunteers to offer free non-medical emotional and practical support to people facing life-threatening illness. Support is also offered to families and carers. Volunteers offer support in various forms including shopping, dog walking, respite care, listening, and transport to hospital appointments. A volunteer may also be a point of liaison between client and social services. The Trust works in close partnership with local service providers and communities, receiving referrals from local hospices, District Nurses, Community Matrons, GPs, hospitals, social services, voluntary organisations, and churches. Some clients also self-refer. Each year, TBT helps around 170 individuals and their families. Over 80% of clients have cancer, and around 5% have had a stroke or other neurological problem. 86% are over the age of 65 and 57% live alone.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Mental wellbeing
grants.description: IT equipment and running costs for a charity supporting LGBT+ people suffering during isolation during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: Outline
recipientOrganization.description: Established in 1999, Outline is a registered charity which offers a confidential LGBT telephone helpline to support the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transsexual community in Surrey. The helpline is open between 7.30 and 10pm on Tuesday and Sunday evenings and offers advice and guidance on all areas surrounding sexual orientation including sexual health, inter-personal relationships, equal opportunities and discrimination. Support is also offered via email for those who are unable to contact Outline during the helpline opening hours and the service is manned by a total 14 volunteers working from their own homes. Although the service is based in Surrey, Outline accepts calls from the whole country, however the majority are from the Surrey area. People contact Outline for a number of reasons ranging from worries about coming out to friends and family, to advice on how to meet like-minded people in the LGBT community. Outline aims to provide a non-judgemental and supportive service to all callers, whether they are from the LGBT community themselves or are calling from the perspective of a concerned friend or relative. The helpline is manned solely by volunteers and calls are charged at a local rate. The helpline was originally initiated by the Surrey Care Trust, however Outline took control of the service as a separate voluntary entity shortly after. Despite this, Surrey PCT have provided regular grant funding in recent years to assist with the running costs of the charity. An NHS Sexual Health Development Worker also attends committee meetings on a regular basis and helps to secure on-going funding from the PCT. Since July 2010, Outline has also run a monthly social group for LGBT individuals in Woking to meet, socialise and provide each other with support. To date, the group has met on two occasions, with over 35 people attending across both meetings. There are currently 6 members on the Management Committee, which is comprised of LGBT representatives. The international celebrity, George Michael, is the patron of the charity and has often donated substantial sums of money to support it's development.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: Equipment, IT licences and activity packs to address isolation for people with learning disabilities, autism or mental health issues and sensory resources to address emotional ill-health.

recipientOrganization.name: Active Prospects
recipientOrganization.description: Active Prospects provides supported living, residential and community services, activities, employment and training support for people with learning disabilities, autism, physical or mental health needs. Our mission is to enable people with learning disabilities to live aspiring lives. We are a highly experienced supported living provider, with a local / regional base focused on community, well-being and excellence, which enables people to be independent, active, safe and included. We support over 300 people with learning disabilities, physical disabilities, sensory impairment, mental health needs, autism and behaviours of concern in their homes, individual flats or shared houses. Our Head Office is in Reigate and our services are mostly based in East Surrey, although we have recently expanded into West Sussex and Croydon. However, if we are successful with our application, the grant will solely be spent for the benefit of Surrey residents. Active Prospects has an unwavering commitment to co-production, giving people a voice at the heart of our organisation. Our award-winning co-production body, the Pro-Active Community, is a 300 strong user-led organisation and plays an important role in peer-led service improvement; social activities and inclusion; community involvement; and being active citizens. The Pro-Active Community elect a committee, who meet fortnightly. The committee are responsible for direction and priorities (including business and service development), performance, partnership creation and other key strategic matters. They are currently in the process of registering as their own an independent charity. Every quarter the Pro-Active Community hold a forum called the Surrey People's Group where anyone is free to come along and participate in workshops and discussions surrounding topics that the committee have identified as being important to or significantly impacting people with Learning Disabilities, Autism or Acquired Brain Injury in Surrey. The invite is also extended to local Commissioners and service providers to help ensure that everyone has an opportunity to get their voice heard. It's a great opportunity for everyone to work together, learn and socialise. Alongside the Pro-Active Community we have trained people we support to be Quality Checkers. They provide Pro-Checking: visiting other services, speaking to people and reviewing evidence against service standards and approaches. Their feedback is used to share best practice as well as set improvement actions. Our people are now peer quality checking other organisations and Surrey County Council services, this provides an income stream for the individuals involved. Supporting people to find paid employment is a top priority for both Active Prospects and the Pro-Active Community and helps to reduce reliance on the benefits system. People we support are also routinely involved in staff recruitment and appraisals. The Pro-Active Community are regularly invited to sit on interview panels for Surrey County Council posts and people focus groups have previously reviewed handbooks, looked at dignity issues and looked at disability/inclusivity design. All of this enriches the lives of the people we support and is demonstrated in the fact that 100% of people we support have made positive progress in their outcome goals over the last year.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Food and Essentials
grants.description: Funding toward a helpline and meals-on-wheels delivery services available in Farnham, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Farnham Maltings Association Limited
recipientOrganization.description: Farnham Maltings (FM) is a cultural organisation based in Farnham that works across the region, nationally and internationally. The organisation is both a registered charity and a company limited by guarantee, managing the Maltings as a cultural space and running the Museum of Farnham. FM has 3 primary funding partners: the Arts Council of England (ACE), Waverley Borough Council (WBC) and Farnham Town Council (FTC). FM’s activity is underpinned by a set of core values, including internationalism, equality, and partnership working. Key strands of work are: Community Engagement; Theatre Development; and Craft Development.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: Funding toward the designing and developing of free online courses for individuals and groups of people within the Mole Valley and Elmbridge area, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Freewheelers Theatre and Media Ltd
recipientOrganization.description: Freewheelers is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee. The principal activity of Freewheelers Theatre Company is giving disabled people the chance to produce and participate in drama, dance and film. Freewheelers gives young people and adults with any disability the support to produce and participate in performance arts. During weekly drama, dance, media and music workshops, Freewheelers works with artists to explore and create performances. Freewheeler's members are mainly from across Surrey and Freewheelers aims to be accessible to people on low incomes. Two days a week are based in North Leatherhead. and workshops also take place in Ashtead and Cobham. The team (including Freewheelers disabled members) also provides outreach education in mainstream schools and colleges about disability. Freewheelers gives at least 6 local performances a year and tours a major production across the South East about every 18 months. The charity works with an agent through which some of the members find work. A team of freelance and part-time artists, with the support of a Carer/Communicator, provide the workshops and training. Originally established in 1989 within Queen Elizabeth’s Foundation (QEF) for Disabled People, the Theatre Company became an independent organisation in 2006.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Homelessness
grants.description: Funding toward the essential running costs of a charity, based in Guildford, that supports the homeless, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Guildford Action For Community Care
recipientOrganization.description: Guildford Action is a registered charity which has been working in Guildford and Waverley for over 30 years and aims to help those who are disadvantaged, on low incomes or in need across the community. The charity’s mission is to ‘enhance the lives of all those we come into contact with’. The organisation provides two core services: - A day service based in central Guildford, which supports those who are homeless, have been homeless, or those on a low income, offering showers, laundry, access to primary healthcare, clothing and food, alongside non-judgemental advice and help with housing, benefits and other issues, within the safe environment of the centre. - Guildford Action for Families outreach service, which supports isolated families going through crisis or experiencing difficulties within families’ own homes and community venues. Clients of both services often have chaotic lives and face issues including debt and financial hardship, homelessness, poor living conditions, relationship breakdown, mental health challenges, isolation, domestic abuse, unemployment and substance misuse.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Older people
grants.description: Core costs for a charity tackling the impact of isolation of older people during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: Surrey Heath Age Concern
recipientOrganization.description: Surrey Heath Age Concern (formerly Frimley and Camberley Age Concern) is a small, local charity which recently became a Charitable Incorporated Organisation (CIO). Previously the CIO was a member of the Age Concern national charity but is now independent. The charity's mission statement is: “To promote the well-being of all older people in the Borough of Surrey Heath and to help make later life a fulfilling and enjoyable experience". In order to meet this goal Surrey Heath Age Concern (SHAC) operates a range of services: • A visiting and befriending service providing weekly visits which offer friendship and support. • A tea room providing a meeting place for lonely people over 50, plus refreshments at reasonable cost. • Local information, signposting and support service offering guidance and support on a range of topics. • A carer’s respite sitting service is currently being introduced. • Tea and Chatter groups where volunteers drive elderly people to a volunteer host's home on a Sunday • A Vintage Tea room ("Tea and Memories") at the cafe each week. • Other activities such as outings. SHAC receives referrals from doctors’ surgeries, mental health workers, and other professionals. The charity currently employs 3 part-time staff: a Chief Executive, Administration Assistant, and Tea Room Assistant. It is governed by 9 Trustees and supported by more than 70 volunteers.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Food and Essentials
grants.description: Hardware and software costs to move to remote working for a charity supporting people with mental ill-health during the Coronavirus outbreak

recipientOrganization.name: North Surrey Community Counselling Partnership ( NSCCP)
recipientOrganization.description: The North Surrey Community Counselling Partnership (working name The Counselling Partnership) is a registered charity which was established in 2002 to provide short-term (up to one year), low cost, non-emergency, weekly counselling on issues such as stress, depression, anger, personal crisis, low self-esteem, bereavement and relationship problems. A key objective is to promote the work within local communities where there are known pockets of deprivation or adults over the age of 17 years on low incomes. Most of the referrals are from the Boroughs of Woking, Runnymede and Elmbridge. The Counselling Partnership (TCP) is also now receiving referrals from neighbouring boroughs within Surrey. Since establishing, TCP has received over 3,500 referrals, either directly from clients or via health and social care professionals. Referrals are increasingly received from carers via Carer Support organisations and from Victim Support. Beneficiaries are asked to make a minimum contribution of £20 per session (much less than private counselling services), however the charity offers subsidies to those who find this financial commitment prohibitive. Counselling sessions are held in a variety of community venues including Walton Community Hub, Cobham Day Centre and Maybury Centre in Woking, and are facilitated by trained counsellors who work for the charity as volunteers. TCP is engaged with around 20 volunteers who are each committed to providing at least 3 hours counselling per week, for a minimum of one year. The volunteer counsellors receive supervision and mentoring, and Counsellors are also given the opportunity to use their work with the charity to accrue client hours which are required to complete professional qualifications such as the British Association for Counselling & Psychotherapy qualifications. TCP employs 2 part time staff and is governed by 9 Trustees

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Homelessness
grants.description: IT equipment and core costs for a charity helping homeless and vulnerable people in Elmbridge during the Coronavirus outbreak

recipientOrganization.name: Elmbridge Rentstart
recipientOrganization.description: Elmbridge Rentstart (ER) is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee established in 2001 supporting residents of Elmbridge who are homeless or at risk of homelessness, by providing and assisting in the provision of housing, advice, support and practical assistance. ER supports single homeless people who are not entitled to statutory support and are termed ‘non-priority’. Their only housing option is the private rental sector, but they face multiple barriers to achieving this e.g. a lack of savings for deposits or rent in advance, physical and mental health issues, addiction problems, and unemployment. They also have difficulty in finding a landlord willing to accept them. Each client is assessed by trained staff, who then work to find an immediate solution (often in terms of access to emergency accommodation for a few weeks, while working to find the right longer-term housing). ER helps people into employment and encourages them to join the ER savings scheme, enabling them to save a protected pot of money that they can use for a deposit for a property of their own once they are ready to move on from ER’s support. Over the last year ER have given advice to 384 vulnerable people and have gone on to house 154 clients. Of the 154 housed: 31% had been rough sleepers, 45% have mental health issues, 7% have a criminal record, 29% have drug and/or alcohol issues. In the last year 28% of clients started work and 32% started to save each month towards their own future. Nov 2019

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Older people
grants.description: A contribution to running costs for a charity supporting isolated older people in Reigate and Banstead during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: Age Concern Merstham, Redhill & Reigate
recipientOrganization.description: Established in 1957, Age Concern MRR has recently (July 2017) changed its legal status to a CIO (Charitable Incorporated Organisation) and has been given charitable status by the Charity Commission who recognise that it is intended to replace the old association which will be disbanded in October 2018. The new charity name has been changed to Age Concern Voluntary Association for the Elderly Merstham, Redhill and Reigate as a result of the restructuring. The charity aims to promote the wellbeing of older people and to help make later life a fulfilling and enjoyable experience. It seeks to help older people to remain living independently in their own homes for as long as they wish and are able to, and provide appropriate support in order to overcome isolation and loneliness. The charity runs a day centre three days per week in Weldon Way, Merstham which provides a hot meal, social interaction and various activities, as well as IT classes, hair dressing, hearing aid maintenance, access to a list of reliable tradespeople and information and advice (including legal advice in partnership with a local solicitor). A Befriending Service is also offered, along with transport, social outings and shopping trips. The Men’s Shed is the newest service to be offered. The annual membership fee is £15 per year, which covers access to the centre and a number of services, although some, such as the meal, are provided at an extra cost. The charity currently employs 7 part time members of staff and is supported by over 45 volunteers and 7 Trustees. It has a membership of approximately 200 elderly clients

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Older people
grants.description: Funding to cover the cost of IT equipment to allow staff to work from home, to continue to support carers across Surrey during the Covid-19 outbreak

recipientOrganization.name: Action for Carers (Surrey)
recipientOrganization.description: Action for Carers (ACS) is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee. ACS’s main remit is to give carers a voice, champion their rights, raise awareness of their needs, and to achieve equitable services and support for carers in Surrey. Surrey Young Carers is the largest project of ACS, offering 1-1 support, advice and information to around 2,000 young carers aged 4-18 every year. ACS aims to provide additional activities such as after-school and holiday activities, groups and workshops which help young people in their caring roles, and fun activities to give them a break from caring. ACS also signposts carers to specialist support. ACS was established in 1996 and became registered and incorporated in 2006.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Domestic abuse
grants.description: Contribution towards salary costs for a charity helping victims of domestic abuse during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: yourSanctuary
recipientOrganization.description: yourSanctuary is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee established in 1977 to offer support to anyone experiencing domestic abuse and to enable children to be seen, heard and validated. yourSanctuary provides a free service of highly tailored support that includes refuge accommodation, a free helpline service and outreach support in the community. The Community Outreach Service provides emotional and practical support to those experiencing domestic abuse in the boroughs of Woking, Runnymede and Surrey Heath. Staff work from a needs-led and strengths-based perspective to ensure that each client is treated as an individual. The Community Outreach Service receives over 1,000 referrals per year from a variety of agencies including police, health professionals, Children’s Services, Children’s Centres, the helpline and other statutory services. Since 2014, the children’s outreach service has provided 1-1 therapeutic support to children who have been affected by domestic abuse, and they are normally referred from the adult outreach service.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: Funding for PPE and cleaning costs at charity centre caring for vulnerable children during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: The Children's Trust
recipientOrganization.description: The Children's Trust is the UK's leading charity for children with brain injury. Every 15 minutes a child in the UK has an accident or illness causing a life changing brain injury. That’s one child every 15 minutes. An acquired brain injury (ABI) can be caused by a trauma (car accident, fall or blow to the head) or a medical event (brain tumour, meningitis or stroke). The Children’s Trust helps children and young people from all over the country that have sustained a severe brain injury to make the best recovery possible. Support for children with brain injury and neurodisability is provided in three key areas: • In 1985 The Children’s Trust started the UK's first paediatric brain injury rehabilitation service and today runs the country’s largest service of its kind. At the National Specialist Centre in Tadworth, The Children’s Trust provides intensive neurorehabilitation, step-down medical and nursing care and short breaks. • Across the country The Children’s Trust supports children in their own communities through a Brain Injury Community Service. Quality online information is also provided via the Brain Injury Hub. • At The Children’s Trust School in Tadworth, education, therapy and care are provided for children and young people with a range of special educational and care needs. Last year the school had a total of 38 pupils, both residential and day pupils. Therapies which are provided by The Children’s Trust clinical staff include music therapy, play therapy and art therapy. Sports activities are also available and these can help with the rehabilitation process. The National Specialist Centre in Tadworth has up to 58 children on site at any one time, many residing in one of 7 residential houses. The Children’s Trust also offers a weekly parent and child group, Taddies, for children 0 - 5 years, as well as age-appropriate education and activities for children attending the on-site nursery in Tadworth.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Mental wellbeing
grants.description: Funding for additional IT equipment to expand support services to people suffering from mental ill-health and isolation across Surrey amid the Coronavirus crisis

recipientOrganization.name: Mary Frances Trust
recipientOrganization.description: Mary Frances Trust (MFT) is a charity and company limited by guarantee, based in Leatherhead. It was established in 1994 by carers, professionals and people using local services and it supports people experiencing mental health problems to regain confidence and self-esteem, and to feel less socially isolated. MFT offers various activities and enables people to access opportunities around work, education and leisure in the wider community. Services include: advice & information, 1-1 support, Social & Peer Support, Self-help groups, Skill Development, Wellbeing, Courses, and a Safe Haven. In 2013 MFT became the lead for Community Connections Mental Health Services for Epsom, Ewell, and Mole Valley. In Partnership with the Surrey & Borders NHS Trust, and Surrey Downs CCG, MFT now also runs a Safe Haven in Epsom, which supports people who are in mental health crisis. The service runs 365 days a year, and more recently, MFT has started working in Banstead and East Elmbridge.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Mental wellbeing
grants.description: Funding toward the delivery in amended services and essential running costs for a youth work charity, based in Guildford, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Matrix Trust
recipientOrganization.description: Matrix Trust is a Christian charity providing support for vulnerable young people of any or no faith across the Guildford Borough. Established in April 2000, the current focus is on youth work and the Trust has been involved in direct work in Surrey schools since 2005; this has included working alongside teaching staff in areas such as PSE (personal and social education), religious education lessons and in school assemblies. The Trust also supports young people directly in their own communities providing positive activities and safe spaces in a variety of communities across the Guildford Borough.

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Aspire
recipientOrganization.description: Aspire Oxford supports people facing multiple challenges to find employment and housing. We work with people who have a background of homelessness, offending histories, addiction or mental health difficulties. We provide support that is focused on the needs of each individual, helping them to move forward with their lives. Our support includes work experience on our enterprise businesses, access to training and adult education, homelessness prevention support, housing projects for rough sleepers and ex-offenders, sports and social activities and access to paid jobs with inclusive employers. Last year we supported over 2,000 people in Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire. Aspire is a founder member of Oxford Homeless Movement and runs a range of programmes designed to prevent and tackle homelessness. We run a homelessness prevention programme which gives people the skills, confidence, knowledge and connections to prevent their own homelessness. We run Housing First projects in collaboration with local housing associations. In all of Aspire's programmes, we ensure that people with lived experience are involved at every stage, including co-designing the projects that we run and in 2019 helped to establish Oxfordshire's first Lived Experience Forum.

grants.title: COVID19 response
grants.description: Provide online youth services for young people in a very disadvantaged area, supported by local volunteers, during this pandemic.
grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Didcot TRAIN Youth Project
recipientOrganization.description: The TRAIN charity operates within the town of Didcot, Oxfordshire. It works in the gap in provision of youth services for YP who do not easily engage with mainstream provision but nevertheless are vulnerable and at high risk and are exposed to educational failure, crime, child sexual exploitation, alcohol and substance abuse, and other risky behaviours. TRAIN’s mission is to seek out, engage and empower these children and YP and reduce the negative impact upon both their short and longer-term life chances.

grants.title: COVID
grants.description: Provide crisis services for rough sleepers and those living in temporary accommodation during this pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Edge Housing - Oxford Community Church
recipientOrganization.description: Edge Housing works with those who have been homeless or vulnerably housed and seeks to support, signpost and mentor these residents into careers which will give them the stability to enter the private rented sector. We have two five bedroom houses and have an investor looking to purchase us a third. We support and challenge our residents to become all they want to be and lead successful lives. We have a team of volunteers who befriend and mentor the residents separately to encourage and listen and simply be a friend. We keep costs low so that when the resident gain employment we can subsidise the rent for three months to allow them to save. We work with Oxford University for careers, all the local support organisations and city councils in providing an individual approach in a home environment where we allow our residents to explore their own lives and we come alongside them. We are a Christian organisation and follow the biblical principle that we are all make for a purpose but we do not evangelise and our residents can be of any or no faith.

grants.title: COVID19 - meals and safeguarding
grants.description: Since the beginning of the outbreak we have seen the demands for our services grow, we are now serving an average of 130 and on occasion we have served 150 meals per day.

recipientOrganization.name: The Porch
recipientOrganization.description: We are a Christian based organisation whose mission is to help in a totally non-discriminatory way, homeless, recently re-housed homeless or vulnerably housed people. We encourage our service users (our members) to tackle the multiple disadvantages that prevent them from moving forwards towards a more positive lifestyle. We concentrate upon housing, companionship, learning skills, work related skills and opportunities for development. We offer a unique day centre based on two elements: one is the basic facilities (a café, a shower/laundry room, free internet access and a library). The other is the support side: we offer one-to-one support addressing the issues of housing, health, education, employment, and wellbeing. We seek to promote a sense of self-worth and purpose, and offer support and challenge to our members in the areas of: • Health -- access to medical/dental services and to the range of health care services we all need • Housing -- help to live where they need to • Education -- to develop their skills and abilities • Employment -- to lead a purposeful life

recipientOrganization.name: On Your Bike (Recycle) Ltd
recipientOrganization.description: On Your Bike (Recycle) Ltd is a local charity that delivers training and work placements for vulnerable and disadvantaged individuals, giving them the skills and confidence to access pathways to employment in Taunton and Bridgwater. It achieves this by recycling unwanted bikes and selling them back into the local community: a process delivered by our trainees (supported by our professional mechanics) in work placements which combine training in bike mechanics, retail, office administration and premises management experience. Figures from the year to March 2018 saw 48 people benefit from one of our work placements. This equates to nearly 4,700 hours invested in support and training for those volunteers and beneficiaries. 16 of those (33%) entered paid employment or left to pursue further training/volunteering. 5 (10%) left with no ongoing plan, 1 (2%) left without informing us of their intentions. 26 (54%) continued their placement with us. During the year to FYE Feb 2018 we sold 651 bikes and serviced approximately 952 bikes for people in our community.

grants.title: COVID19 24 hour advice line for people facing a life limiting illness and their carers
grants.description: 24 hour advice line for people facing a life limiting illness and their carers

recipientOrganization.name: St Margaret's Hospice
recipientOrganization.description: - Providing hospice care for Somerset St Margaret’s Hospice Care provides high-quality responsive care for families in Somerset when someone is given a diagnosis of a life-limiting illness. We have a vision of a community in which all dying people and those close to them have access to appropriate care and support, when they need it, wherever they need it and whoever they are. Our aim is to bring quality of life to patients and their families, carers and friends so that they can make each day count. Across Somerset we offer a range of services: • Our Community Teams provide care and support in the familiar environment of a patient’s own homes. The community teams provide care for over 260 patients at any one time. • Our 24 hour referral and advice line receives an average of 786 calls per month from patients and carers who need advice from a palliative care nurse and health professionals wishing to make a referral. • Our Sunflower Centre Day Services welcomes attendees who are well enough to live at home but who want to take advantage of our specialist care available through the day. The Sunflower Centre also provides respite for carers. • Our In-patient Unit in Taunton offers patients with complex care needs comfortable surroundings where they receive extra support, symptom control and pain management from specialist teams. • Our Outpatients Services provide a wide range of therapies including Lymphodema Treatment, Physiotherapy, Complementary Therapies, Occupational Therapy, and Psychotherapy. • Our Bereavement Services supports families and carers who have lost a loved one to a life-limiting illness. Our Family Support Worker is specially trained to help children and young people cope with the loss of a parent. • Our support groups offer an opportunity for people to meet with people going through a similar experience. Our carer support services come alongside those caring for their loved ones who have a life-limiting illness. • Our Spiritual Care Team work closely alongside clinical teams to ensure we are caring for patients’ spiritual needs alongside their physical and emotional needs. - Adapting to meet future care needs With over 5,500 people dying in Somerset each year and an estimated 4,000+ people who would benefit from hospice care, we know that there is a growing gap between those we can help and those we are currently unable to reach or support adequately. Over the last couple of years, St Margaret’s has therefore been rethinking how we can improve our reach across the county, address a current national shortfall in medical staffing and respond to patient choice by extending our care within the community, enabling patients to receive end-of-life care closer to home – while all the time ensuring that we remain financially sustainable. The Board of Trustees have recently confirmed that St Margaret’s will increase our work in the community. Providing end of life care closer to home, while ensuring specialist care is available for those who need it across Somerset, are key components of St Margaret’s strategy. This focus enables our teams to support patients and families in the community in a more proactive way, being able to plan care in advance with patients in their own homes about what their future needs might be. We will increasingly work alongside NHS and adult social care community teams to anticipate and prepare for the changing needs that our patients may have. In-patient services will remain a key component of St Margaret’s and we will bring beds together on one site in Taunton, to reduce the ongoing challenge of maintaining sustainable medical staffing with appropriate skills. Our own patients tell us they would prefer to be at home and we want to make sure this can be achieved. However, we understand that this can put an incredible amount of pressure on carers and families. By extending our community provision we can help support other healthcare providers, families and carers to meet the wishes of the patient while feeling safe and supported. St Margaret’s Hospice Care’s strategy is to further increase this in the coming years. Alongside this we are also developing work to encourage early referrals to the hospice. Often people come to the hospice later on in their illness. However, if we can provide opportunities for people with a life-limiting illness to access hospice care earlier we will be able direct them towards activities and support which will assist in improving the quality of their life. This will enable them to remain in control in their home environment, adapting as their health needs change. - Are you sitting comfortably? We would like the Active Living Programme to consider supporting us so that we can offer something new to our patients. The aim of our project is to provide staff and volunteers with the skills to integrate seated exercise into the services currently provided by the Hospice. We believe that this will improve patient's physical and mental wellbeing. By training our staff and volunteers we will have an ongoing and sustainable resource to benefit patients beyond the period of the grant. The seated exercise programmes will be integrated into our existing day hospice provision to enhance the care and subsequent benefits of the service to patients. St Margaret’s Hospice is one charity for the people of Somerset, caring and supporting patients and their families and carers. This new focus will ensure that the charity is in the best possible shape to continue providing high quality, responsive care for more people facing a life-limiting illness across Somerset in the months, and years, to come.

grants.title: COVID19 Support for expectant and new parents in Somerset
grants.description: Support for expectant and new parents, in Somerset

recipientOrganization.name: Nourish
recipientOrganization.description: The aims of Nourish - Bumps, Babies and Breastfeeding are to protect, promote and support breastfeeding within the community of Bridgwater and the surrounding villages. Nourish provides a weekly support group, held in Cannington, offering pregnant women and breastfeeding mothers the opportunity to seek support, information and empathy in a non-clinical environment for a small donation. Up until January 2018 the group had been funded by NCT (National Childbirth Trust) and was called NCT Cannington Bumps, Babes and Breastfeeding group. Unfortunately due to funding constraints facing the charity, the NCT could not continue to financially support the group. Thus the breast feeding counsellor leading the service and a handful of passionate and dedicated breastfeeding peer supporters decided to establish the group Nourish to enable the continuation of pregnancy, baby and breastfeeding support service. Support and information about breastfeeding is provided within Nourish by a qualified Breastfeeding Counsellor and trained Breastfeeding Peer Supporters. Women are often referred to the group by midwives and health visitors requiring specific support for breastfeeding, whilst others find the group from publicity such as Facebook, flyers or word of mouth. The group aims to provide a warm, friendly, open environment where women feel safe and secure to express their emotions and seek support to enable them to have a positive breastfeeding experience. As Nourish is free from the constraints of a clinical setting and the pressures on health professionals, we are able to give mothers unlimited time, to listen and offer mother-led support. This enables families to make informed decisions and have a positive experience with breastfeeding. Although Nourish offers support and information about breastfeeding a mother does not need to have an issue directly relating to breastfeeding to attend. All too often a mother needs the emotional support of other mothers to ward off feelings of isolation, anxiety or to simply discuss their trials and tribulations of parenthood whilst establishing friendships. In this way the group positively supports not only breastfeeding but the varied and sometimes challenging experiences of parenting. The group welcomes older siblings attending with their mother so that mothers with subsequent children are included within our reach. Toys and activities are provided to entertain older sibling so that their mother can spend time talking to other mums or seeking support from the peer supporters or breastfeeding counsellor. Refreshments such as tea, coffee and cake help a mother feel relaxed and welcome as well as providing much needed calories to meet the demands of nourishing her baby. We positively welcome the attendance of partners/husband alongside their breastfeeding partner/wife as women who have support to breastfeed from family members feel empowered to continue their breastfeeding journey when faced with challenges. Overall the group's aim is to nourish women, both physically and emotionally, to enable them to have a positive breastfeeding experience.

recipientOrganization.name: North Taunton Partnership
recipientOrganization.description: THE CHARITY'S OBJECTS ARE TO PROMOTE CHARITABLE PURPOSES FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE COMMUNITY IN NORTH TAUNTON AND IN PARTICULAR THE ADVANCEMENT OF EDUCATION, THE PROMOTION OF HEALTH AND THE RELIEF OF POVERTY, SICKNESS AND DISTRESS. We support all residents of North Taunton that are in need, this is done through the community centre offering a morning drop in where we host free confidential advice sessions from organisations such as the Police, SW&T housing and benefits, Citizens Advice and Inspired to Achieved employment support. We provide a morning drop in for residents to enjoy a cup of tea or coffee with friends which is a valuable facility to some of our most lonely and isolated residents, many say they don't know what they would do without it. Afternoons, evenings and weekends we offer various social, fitness and educational classes and activities. although our main service users are the elderly we also provide a programme of activities aimed at younger residents and their families in North Taunton, this takes the form of activity days on a local park in the school holidays, the activity days are now in their 12th year and are very much led by the young people and what they want rather than what we feel they need.

grants.title: COVID19 Community kitchen to supply hot meals to vulnerable people in Stoke St Gregory
grants.description: Setting up a community kitchen to prepare hot meals

recipientOrganization.name: The Willow Set Preschool and Sun Up Sun Down Club
recipientOrganization.description: The Willow Set Preschool and Sun Up, Sun Down Club is located in Stoke St Gregory approximately 12 miles fromTaunton, Bridgwater, Langport and Street. It is a rural village that includes families from a wide range of backgrounds including the farming industry, Clarks, Hinkley Point and of course willow growing businesses. The setting opened approximately 35 years ago in the church rooms and is now, after hard work and fundraising, situated on the primary school site. We are a committee run preschool with charity status also offering wrap around care. I have managed and run the preschool and wrap around care setting for over 22 years. The wrap around club has only been open just over 5 years and is growing as the need from working parents increases. My aim is to continue to provide outstanding facilities to nurture the children aged 2-11 yrs and provide a rich safe environment with outstanding inside and outside facilities. We also now run a holiday club which has highlighted an obvious need in the community as many of the days over the last six weeks have been at capacity, we again offer outstanding experiences for children to grow and have fun. The project will enable us to offer more for all the children who attend all our 3 settings. I also organise an annual free play evening every for every child, especially as we have families with some diverse needs. Each child will comes with an adult , this has numerous positives as I want parents/carers involved in all we are doing. Firstly to supervise, thus ensuring safety, but really to engage themselves and have fun with all the children. The ethos of the event is to involve parents and promote social cohesion across preschool, wrap around care and outlying organizations and supporting the understanding that Play refers to a collection of voluntary, intrinsically motivated activities that are usually associated with PLEASURE and enjoyment.Or FUN. This is an outside event providing healthy foods to explore and eat will support those families in need of this help. We have a number of disadvantaged children in the village and outlying areas, therefore this being a free evening makes it available to all regardless of their backgrounds. As a setting we work with other organisations in and around the village as we feel every child is important and deserves the best experiences throughout their childhood.

recipientOrganization.description: Timberscombe Good Neighbours is a group of local people who have come together to offer a service in their community for those in need of help and support. The people who need support may be elderly, disabled, single or young parents, carers, those temporarily in need through illness or anyone who may be isolated within our community. Our scheme is available to help anyone living in the parish of Timberscombe. The scheme is there to help people in need, those who, for whatever reason, are unable to help themselves and have no family or friends available. The scheme is not intended to replace professional care or assistance via Social Services. The help offered by Timberscombe Good Neighbours may include: • Providing transport for appointments, hospital visits or to Day Care facilities • Errands, shopping or collecting prescriptions • Preparing emergency meals • Household tasks or gardening • Visiting or befriending • Letter-writing or form-filling • Helping people after discharge from hospital • Giving carers a break • Reading to partially sighted or blind people • Providing information

grants.title: COVID19 Virtual counselling service for people with mental health needs
grants.description: Virtual counselling service for adults

recipientOrganization.name: Seed of Hope CIC
recipientOrganization.description: Seed of Hope CIC is a Social Enterprise offering Recovery based Social and Therapeutic Horticulture for people with mental health problems. We are based in The Walled Gardens of Cannington and supported in kind by Bridgwater and Taunton College who provide horticultural expertise and facilities. We currently run one day a week on Tuesdays. Our main sessions provide a six hour day of mixed horticultural activity, a yoga lesson and a Recovery group. The therapeutic horticultural activity is tailored to the varied levels of physical ability in the group. We pace the activity throughout the day and take regular breaks. We use the elements intrinsic to horticulture - Being outdoors in nature, increased light levels, working as part of a team towards a common goal, nurturing living plants and environments, gentle exercise and Hope - to deliver improved mental and physical well-being for our participants. Our yoga sessions are offered as a tool for participants to use in day to day life to aid relaxation and improve physical ability. It also serves as a physical warm up prior to our horticultural activity. The Recovery group is based on the format devised by Dr Abraham Lowe in the 1920s and used for many years by Recovery international. Participants share their experiences, support each other and explore the concepts of Recovery. Participants also have the opportunity to gain a level 1 qualification in Practical Horticultural Skills awarded by City and Guilds and assessed by the college. Seed of Hope CIC has three sources of income1-Trading income - Our main product is our horticultural sessions which are paid for through personal health or social care budgets. We also sell a variety of products both online and through the Walled Gardens of Cannington shop. These include household items and garden planters made from upcycled pallet wood, wildflower seeds (Seeds of Hope) and plants that have been grown by participants. We are also plan on expanding our groups to people with dementia and people experiencing work related stress. 2- Projects - Our projects have three aims- to provide a goal for our participants, to improve community green spaces, and to provide income. Our award winning Spring Orchard project was completed in 2017 and we are currently working on the Cannington Church Gardens of Rest. Our design for this project was a finalist in the Church Times Green Church Awards 2017. 3- Grant income- As a Social enterprise we aim to be less reliant on this source of income than the other two. However at this start-up phase of our development we need grant funding to support us whilst we grow and develop. Seed of Hope CIC is set up as a Social Enterprise as opposed to a charity for two main reasons. We believe that the current dominant systems of service provision in mental health take power away from service users. Power is an important factor in a person's Recovery. Setting up as a charity implies that people with mental health problems require charity to help them rather than having the power to work co-operatively in their Recovery. Secondly being in control of the source of our income and how it is spent allows us to maintain our independence as an organisation. This is important to us because it means we do not have to work in ways which we know don't help people with mental health problems in their Recovery journey. Being a CIC allows us to work as a co operative. Everyone who takes part in Seed of Hope CIC can become a member of the CIC entitling them a vote on company policy and strategy. Our founding principles are enshrined in our articles of association, these are- 8.1 Recovery - Seed of Hope CIC is a Recovery based organisation. 8.2 Mental Health - Seed of Hope CIC is concerned with the mental health of participants. We are not convinced by the scientific evidence and through our own experience, of the existence of Mental Illness. This does not discount an individual’s experience of psychological or emotional distress, or the negative impact of this on a person’s life. 8.3 Pay Equality– Seed of Hope CIC will value the contribution of all employees regardless of seniority in the organisation. Seed of Hope CIC will be a co-operative organisation, and as such will cap the maximum pay of any employee to two and a half times that of the lowest paid employee. 8.4 Membership- Every participant will be offered the opportunity to contribute to the governance of the organisation as a Member as defined in these articles. 8.5 Intrinsic Elements-The main activity of Seed of Hope CIC is Social and Therapeutic Horticulture. The main elements of which are shown through research to provide positive outcomes for the participants. Seed of Hope CIC will also carry out activities that provide some or all of the intrinsic elements for participants. 8.6 Diversity of Income-To maintain the independence of Seed of Hope CIC which may be compromised by a disproportionate reliance on any one stream of income. Income will be sought from all of the following sources-Grants, Trading Income, Payment by Participants, Fundraising Activity, Commissioned Activity. 8.7 Participant Director- It is of paramount importance to Seed of Hope CIC to have a Participant Director on the Management Team. In order for them to carry out their role all reasonable adjustments will be made to the organisations arrangements for meetings of the Management Team. 8.8 Humour- Mental Health problems can be both life limiting and life threatening. There is much sadness and distress involved in the lives of those experiencing mental distress. Seed of Hope CIC will at all times work in a positive hopeful way and this includes the use of humour at all levels of our interactions. The intention of this is to raise spirits, reflect on the irony of situations, maintain and promote hope and mental well being. It is not intended to harass, belittle, distress, discriminate, bully or intimidate.

recipientOrganization.name: Sweet Track Counselling Services & The Friends of Sweet Track Counselling
recipientOrganization.description: The Sweet Track Counselling Agency CIC believes in the wellbeing of the local community and the work we do is designed around two core principles: 1. Provide equality for residents of Glastonbury and its surrounding areas who want support for mental ill health or emotional issues by offering affordable and easy access to therapeutic services. We believe in offering choice for individuals who are on a journey of self-help and exploration, meaning people can work with therapeutic methods that suits them best. Our services currently include low cost counselling, eco-therapy, group and art therapy support. 2. Nurture students by providing practical learning experiences for the next generation of counsellors and therapists who are training for their qualifications. We set the trust up because we saw an increase in people suffering who were not able to get access to professional support for their mental health. This was due to obstacles including long waiting lists, cancellations, long distant treatment, high costs associated to private therapy. The increasing demand for professional therapeutic support has put a significant strain on local services. Our aim is to help alleviate some of the burden experienced by local GP’s, schools, local charities, since they are struggling to support the need for help from people relating to mental health struggles.

recipientOrganization.name: Aldates Community Transformation Initiatives
recipientOrganization.description: ACT exists to provide relief to people in need in Oxford, in particular the homeless and ex-offenders. Committed to working towards a just society that allows those in need to flourish, we seek to understand each person’s unique situation and to work closely and supportively with them to get their lives back on track. We aim to be a community where people who are homeless or recently released from prison receive intensive and bespoke support. This includes: - Weekly outreach to rough sleepers, inviting them to our Monday dinner from which they can begin to access further support - Provision of overnight accommodation through the Oxford Winter Night Shelter - Targeted support for people on release from prison or living in the local bail hostel through our Meet at the Gate project, designed to help minimise return to life on the streets or re-offending - Supported housing in 10 properties - 1:1 mentoring including life skills development and support to access employment In this way, ACT seeks to provide opportunities for people who are homeless or at risk of it to rebuild their lives for the long term – and the consistent, committed support they need to do this successfully.

grants.title: COVID19 Yes! Brixham
grants.description: Grant to Youth Enquiry Service (Brixham)

grantProgramme.title: Devon Coronavirus Response and Recovery Fund

recipientOrganization.name: Youth Enquiry Service (Brixham)
recipientOrganization.description: Youth Enquiry Service (YES) provides a drop-in information, advice and support services to young people aged 11 to 25, offering a free, confidential service in a welcoming and friendly environment. This support includes counselling, advocacy, mentoring/befriending with the philosophy of empowering and enabling young people. We believe that the young persons physical, emotional and mental health and social development are paramount and essential to the young persons wellbeing. Peer-led initiatives and group work, as well as face-to-face support are organised in order to offer a comprehensive service for the young people of Brixham and Torbay. Information, advice, guidance and support includes benefits, housing and homelessness, sexual health, employment, legal issues, drugs and alcohol, relationship issues and free counselling through our partnership with Checkpoint (The Children's Society). We are a charity working closely with other agencies and have further partnership agreements with Connexions and the Youth Service. We also offer targeted work with those at risk, identified through Children's Services and the Youth Offending Team on projects such as Youth Achievement Awards and AQA accredited workshops. YES supports several youth led local projects, including Brixham Young Volunteers who aim to break down barriers and build bridges in the local community by hosting events for people of all ages. YES workers and volunteers accompany young people to court, doctors appointments, hospital visits and to emergency housing meetings. We supply food parcels for emergencies, travel warrants, shower and laundry facilities for those in need and work closely with Checkpoint to support homeless young people across Torbay.

grants.title: COVID19 Emergency foodbank funding
grants.description: Funding to support a foodbank with its coronavirus response

recipientOrganization.name: The Salvation Army Shepton Mallet
recipientOrganization.description: The Salvation Army is a missional church that looks to provide relevant services in the Community that it works within. In Shepton Mallet we provide many varied services from children's activities to work with the homeless. Our weekly programme consists of two parent and toddler groups, a community drop in with a job club. A digital link club offering both internet access to look and apply for employment, help to provide support with basic computing knowledge, and helping people understand IT when apply for benefits and pay bill's. We also run a Community lunch club which is attended by people who are either looking to get out of the house for a bit of company, people dependant on alcohol and other substances or in some cases for people who don't have enough money to buy food. We also run a club for older people in our community that meets once a week providing them with a place to come and chat with each and share in the activities that we put on. A Brass band for children from the age of 9 upwards. Once a month on a Saturday we run a family craft activity with a cooked meal, to encourage the whole family to spend time together. We have a Charity Shop attached to our building which offers us are only real source of income, and also allows us to be open throughout the week to meet the needs of our community. One of the biggest parts of our work in the community though is the running of the local food bank. over the last twelve months we have given away over 400 food parcels providing food for families or individuals when they cant afford it. The food bank is run on a referral basis and we work closely with agencies, both professional and voluntary, so that we are not just simply handing out food but helping to deal with the underlying need of why the service users do not have enough money to buy it. Along side the food bank we run a Christmas appeal. Again this takes referrals from agenesis of families who without help for what ever reason could not have afforded Christmas. We do around seventy Christmas food hampers and provide toys for over one hundred and fifty children.

grants.title: COVID19 Virtual counselling and bereavement support for people affected by life-threatening conditions
grants.description: Grant to We Hear You

recipientOrganization.name: We Hear You
recipientOrganization.description: We Hear You works across Somerset providing emotional support to patients, families, friends and carers who have been affected by cancer or any other life-threatening conditions - to which we recently added Covid-19. People who use our service often report feeling numb, isolated and overwhelmed and can find their situation too big to cope with. We provide a safe space where people can say the unsayable and ask the unanswerable. We switched to offering our service via telephone or online using Zoom, with all our team working from home, as soon as the crisis became apparent.
