We work alongside our clients, who can often have chaotic lifestyles, with whatever issues are affecting them; working with them and gently acknowledging the possibilities for change. Working with clients who are homeless or at risk of homelessness, we are at the frontline of responding to covid-19 across Somerset, providing immediate, practical assistance to some of the most vulnerable individuals who are rough sleeping, in hostels or in temporary or supported accommodation.

recipientOrganization.name: North Guildford Food Bank
recipientOrganization.description: To provide food parcels to people in need who have been referred to their organisation by a wide variety of agencies. Agencies provide them with a food voucher which is then exchanged for food to last for a minimum of 3 days. They also offer a free cafe on a Wednesday morning from 08.45 to 10.45 when the food bank is open.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Food and Essentials
grants.description: Funding toward the purchase of food stock for a food bank, based in Cobham, to be able to meet the increase in demand for their service, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Cobham Area Foodbank
recipientOrganization.description: Cobham Area Foodbank is a registered charity with the aim of providing food for disadvantaged people at a time of crisis. The Foodbank became a registered charity in September 2013 after initially launching as an initiative of Churches Together in Cobham, Oxshott and Stoke d'Abernon. Food is donated by members of the public at drop-off points including local churches, Waitrose, Sainsburys and Starbucks and then sorted and stored in the charity’s warehouse space. The foodbank is open every Friday from 12.00-1.30pm at the Methodist hall on Cedar Road, Cobham. People are referred to the foodbank by social services or other professionals who provide a voucher to demonstrate that they are in need. Food for three days is given in a size which is appropriate for the size of the family and support is also provided via a friendly word over a cup of tea by volunteers who can also support with signposting clients to other services The foodbank has no staff, but around 60 volunteers and a committee made up of 8 individuals.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Food and Essentials
grants.description: Emergency relief response to Corona Virus. Purchasing food and other basic supplies and food vouchers to supply food to those with no money to buy food.

recipientOrganization.name: St Peter’s Church West Molesey
recipientOrganization.description: St Peter’s Church in West Molesey (SPWM) is an Anglican Church serving the Parish of West Molesey. Services are held in St Peter's Church and Chandler's Field School every Sunday. The Church’s aim is to spread a message of love by words and deeds to everyone in the local community. At present the Church has a number of projects in progress: weekly engagement with each of the local primary and secondary schools, a free-to-access sports camp for 8-16 year olds in each of the school holidays, a weekly community breakfast alongside the East Elmbridge Foodbank, an emergency winter night shelter and a youth drop in cafe, which operates on Mondays and Thursdays between 3.30pm and 6pm each week. Historically there has been both the PCC and a Charitable Trust which supported the work of St Peter’s Church. The Trust was a joint venture with another Church but increasingly it was deemed that it was too complicated to have both the PCC and the Charitable Trust, and the Trust therefore ceased on 31st March 2019. St Peter’s Church is not yet certain how much will be distributed from the Trust to St Peter’s.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Food and Essentials
grants.description: Funding toward subsidising meals for the vulnerable, by an organisation based in Merstham, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Merstham Community Cafe CIC
recipientOrganization.description: The Merstham Community Cafe CIC is fully committed to playing its part in helping to tackle deprivation on the Merstham Estate, through the provision of healthy, nutritious and affordable food and through the full utilisation of a training kitchen to deliver training courses on food preparation and menu planning for young mothers. We will also provide training and work experience for young people who may be interested in careers in the catering industry. We will be working with YMCA East Surrey and Redoak Centre for the benefit of local youngsters with disabilities and learning difficulties for providing cookery classes. We will be using Fairshare, to utilise surplus food to feed mouths cheaply. The café will be in the centre of a Community Hub on the Merstham Estate. All 4 Directors of the CIC are local...1 being a Borough Councillor for the area, and one a retired Borough Councillor. The other 2 are also associated with a local charity called Loveworks who operate a Foodbank in the Hub where the café will be located. Another local councillor is on the Steering Committee and a further member runs free support groups for those troubled by addiction within the local area. Also on the committee is a member of Redoak, providing support to disabled youngsters. 2 of our number are Trustees of the Merstham Facility Community Trust who will have a presence in the Hub where the café is situated. Any profits from the café will be used to provide extra community services to supplement their work in providing IT Training, Job Search, Uniform Swap and other community based activities. All the volunteers will be recruited locally and already help to run a one day per week hot meal pop up free service for locals. the local YMCA and Redhill colleges will be involved in the training kitchen. A survey has shown how much the local people feel the need and would like to be involved in our project.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: Funding toward the purchase of equipment for staff to be able to work from home for a charity that supports those with disabilities, during the COVID-19 pandemic,

recipientOrganization.name: The Grange Centre for People with Disabilities
recipientOrganization.description: Founded in 1938, The Grange Centre for People with Disabilities is a registered charity, company limited by guarantee, and a registered Housing Association. Located on a 15-acre site in Bookham, the charity helps adults with learning disabilities and other secondary disabilities to realise their full potential and live independent and fulfilling lives. Services support approximately 100 clients a day and include:  Residential Care for 16 people who have higher support needs in purpose-built accommodation;  Accommodation for up to 60 tenants in a Supported Living service, both on the main site and offsite in central Bookham and Epsom;  Skills Training – operating Monday to Friday 9.15am to 4.15pm in Dorking, Bookham Village and the main site – in areas such as Catering, Horticulture and Woodwork, Creative Arts & Textiles;  Mini enterprises such as fudge-making and a partnership with Beyond Words, the books for people with learning disabilities;  The charity's shops and Café also offer clients valuable opportunity to gain retail skills and training;  In collaboration with local employers, The Grange also enables clients to undertake external work placements.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Food and Essentials
grants.description: Funding to support disadvantaged people in Camberley facing hardship during the Covid-19 outbreak

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Asylum seekers
grants.description: Funding for a project supporting Unaccompanied Asylum-Seeking Children during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: Big Leaf Foundation
recipientOrganization.description: Big Leaf Foundation was established in 2018 in response to the unmet needs of displaced young people in Surrey. Having fled conflict and persecution, displaced young people in the UK face huge barriers to accessing education, support and employment and, most importantly, in finding a community. We aim to address this through supporting vulnerable and isolated young people (aged 16-25) into education and employment and providing a programme therapeutic and community-focused activities that will enable them to build a fulfilling life in the UK and flourish in their new home. We want the young people we work with to be excited about the opportunities available to them, and to value their unique talents and abilities so that they can rediscover their potential and move forward with renewed optimism. Through our projects we also aim to provide the space for young people to build trusted relationships with those around them so that they might begin to feel a sense of home and hope and be less vulnerable to negative external influence or self-destructive behaviour. Our projects include: • HUB – our weekly drop-in sessions for displaced young people living in Surrey. We provide ESOL support, help with homework, conversation, activities and games and a hot supper. It’s also a chance for young people to ask any questions they might have about life in the UK and meet other people for the community around them. Food is freshly prepared and halal and everyone sits down and eats together. • I SPEAK MUSIC RADIO PROJECT – our new project in partnership with Surrey Arts and Kane FM is a combined academic and music project built around English language, music and broadcast studio skills. Sessions focus on increasing participants’ use of English, working together on song-writing and emphasising self-expressions through personal choice of musical and lyrical style, and learning a musical instrument. • SUMMER CAMP – our annual five-day summer camp at the beautiful Trill Farm in Devon is a chance for our young people to relax, to take a break from their worries, to eat well, sleep well, experience something new, be outside and have fun. There’s a packed programme of activities encompassing everything from woodwork, pottery and leatherwork to organic gardening, falconry and equine therapy with games, music and campfires in between. Read more about our summer camp and other projects at www.bigleaffoundation.org.uk/projects

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Older people
grants.description: Costs of delivering meals to isolated older people in Haslemere

recipientOrganization.name: Haslewey (Haslemere & District Community Centre)
recipientOrganization.description: Haslemere and District Community Centre, known as Haslewey, is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee. Its primary aim is to manage and administer an all-age community centre for charitable purposes for the benefit of the community of Haslemere and the surrounding district. The centre has around 6000 visits per month, and the premises has a number of rooms which are available for hire. A wide range of community activities are housed at Haslewey including ballet, indoor curling, Pilates, belly dancing, bingo, yoga, Zumba, Walks for Health, Spanish and Haslewey Knit-Natter & Craft Club. Podiatry and hair dressing services are also available on site. The centre runs a community car for those who struggle to get out. This service has no fixed charge and is maintained through clients’ voluntary donations. Haslewey relies largely on room rental to cover the running and maintenance of the building. The centre has operated since 2003, and it employs 3 full-time staff and 6 part-time staff members. The operation is overseen by a 10 Trustees.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Homelessness
grants.description: Funding toward the purchase of equipment that will protect their staff and clients, for an organisation that provides housing and support to the homeless, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Transform Housing & Support
recipientOrganization.description: Transform Housing & Support (THS) is an incorporated charity, company limited by guarantee, and registered social housing provider, which has been operating since 1972. Working across Surrey, as well as in the London Borough of Sutton and Wokingham in Berkshire, the organisation helps more than 1,000 people per year to transform their lives. The charity's mission is to provide housing and support for homeless, vulnerable and excluded people, empowering them to reach their goals and live independent and fulfilling lives. Support is provided to people who face obstacles such as homelessness, mental health issues and disabilities, people in recovery from drug and alcohol dependency, with a history of offending, and those leaving care. Much of the charity's work is preventative, intervening and assisting people to turn their lives around before their situation gets worse. Each client is provided with a comfortable home where they can feel safe. Specialist one-to-one support is also given to each person, to enable them to overcome the issues they are facing, to build their confidence, gain essential life skills, and participate in their community, and access training, education and employment opportunities. The aim is to enable people to move on and live independently when they are ready. Transform owns around 500 housing units and manages almost another 100 for other organisations.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Older people
grants.description: Funding toward equipment for home work, recruiting more volunteers and the cost of extending the opening hours of a service, which helps the elderly in Epsom and Ewell, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Age Concern Epsom and Ewell
recipientOrganization.description: Age Concern Epsom & Ewell (ACEE) empower older people to live the most fulfilling lives they can. ACEE provide a free and confidential Information and Advice Service and further services including Home Visiting, Toe Nail Cutting, Transport Scheme, Befriending, Moment Makers service, Community Companions, DIY, Hearing Aid Clinics, IT Support, and Social Events. The charity also coordinates a bank of 243 volunteers who support the services by being drivers, befrienders, IT supporters, fundraisers etc. The work benefits all older people in the borough, and is aimed at improving their well-being, helping them remain socially active and independent, and giving them the support they need to lead the life they want. The charity was established in July 1947. It has a Management Committee of 13, 9 part-time workers and 243 volunteers and helpers. In 2010 the Trustees incorporated a company limited by guarantee bearing the name Age Concern Epsom & Ewell, which was subsequently granted charitable status.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: Funding toward the purchase of equipment for an organisation, based in Guildford, that offers counselling and learning activities to those with learning disabilities, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Halow Project
recipientOrganization.description: The halow Project is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee which began operating in 2006. In 2009 a separate social enterprise company called Halow Care was established which provides front line social care support. The halow Project supports around 200 young learning-disabled people, aged 16-35, on their journey into and through adult life. Halow aims to ensure that people with a learning disability have the same life choices and chances as any other person, and are able to develop as individuals, have a vision and purpose for their lives, and make a contribution to the people and places where they live. Activities include regular social activities chosen by the young people at a Youth Committee, 1:1 support from halow Buddies and a Supported Living Service. Additionally the group provides two educational, vocational and practical programmes – A Reason To Get Up (ARTGU) and the Building Futures Group. The halow Project currently has 10 full time and 7 part time members of staff, a Board of 6 Trustees and 34 volunteers.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Advice and support
grants.description: Funding toward temporary extra salary cost and the cost of ensuring all staff can work from home, for an organisation, based in Epsom and Ewell, that offers free legal advice, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Epsom & Ewell Citizens Advice Bureau
recipientOrganization.description: Epsom and Ewell Citizens Advice Bureau (EECA) is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee. It is also regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority. It provides advice, undertakes specialised casework, and has established a specialist money advice project more recently as a response to the significant increase in the number of clients seeking advice on complex income and debt problems. The mental health project, which EECA has run for over 20 years, is designed to help people with Severe and Enduring Mental Health (SEMH) issues in the Surrey boroughs of Epsom and Ewell, Mole Valley, Reigate and Banstead, and Tandridge. The service is aimed at those who are unable as a result of their illness, to visit or telephone their local Citizens Advice office in the normal way. It offers helps clients to put their finances in order by managing any debts, securing benefits to which they are entitled, and obtaining grants or services from charities. EECA is based in Epsom, but staff will be able to see clients at convenient locations across all four boroughs covered. Additionally, across the whole organisation, EECA undertakes tribunal work which includes everything from preparing benefit appeal papers through to representation at the hearing. The charity also works on research and campaigning to bring about necessary changes to policies and practices that affect clients’ lives. Issues which EECA deals with can be as simple as a form needing clarity, to a national drive to deal with rogue bailiffs. EECA keeps in close contact with the Member of Parliament and works with Citizens Advice at a national level to bring about change. EECA is audited annually by Citizens Advice nationally.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Food and Essentials
grants.description: Funding toward the purchase of emergency food provisions, by an organisation, based in Ash Vale, that will deliver these provisions to the vulnerable in the community, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: St Mary's Church, Ash Vale
recipientOrganization.description: St Mary's Church, Ash Vale is a Church of England Parish Church., with a Community Centre attached to it. In addition to regular Christian worship, the church hosts a wide range of activities that support the whole community. This includes regular activities including a pre-school, regular toddler groups, Youth group, Silver Circle (for retired locals), choirs, dance groups, dog training, keep fit and one-off / ad-hoc events such as arts and crafts workshops, quiz nights, concerts, and community 'bring and share' meals. The PCC has launched a project "Opening up the Church" to increase the community use of the main church space (i.e. using the space all week rather than only on Sundays). St Mary's Church is the parish church in Ash Vale and serves the surrounding community. It is very close to Ash Wharf, which is 25 on the IMD index in Surrey with 20% of children living in poverty. The church will serve anyone from the community whether they have a faith or not. St Mary's was founded in 1906.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Food and Essentials
grants.description: Funding towards a foodbank in Epsom and Ewell during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: Generation Church
recipientOrganization.description: Ewell Christian Fellowship Trust was established in 1990 and is a registered charity in this name. It operates under the working name 'Generation Church'. The Church is based at West Ewell Infants School on Ruxley Lane, with Generation Resource Centre (comprising the church offices and a small meeting room) located in a separate building at the rear of the school site. The Church provides outreach activities into the local community. This has included the Lighthouse Education Project for children and young people who are home-schooled, as well as those at risk of exclusion from school and children from local traveller families. Current projects include Friday Friends - A project for isolated over-60s which provides a place where people can come and enjoy company, crafts, games and talks; Epsom & Ewell Foodbank, running once a week from 5 centres (Tadworth, Ewell, Banstead, Epsom and Leatherhead); and a young peoples (11-17) club that has been running weekly for many years which is open to the whole community.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Mental wellbeing
grants.description: Contribution to a Surrey charity supporting vulnerable young people during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: Eikon
recipientOrganization.description: Eikon is a Surrey-based charity and company limited by guarantee, established in 1995 and providing long-term support to some of the county’s most vulnerable, disadvantaged and at-risk young people and their families. Eikon introduces preventative approaches as many of the young people Eikon works with are on the verge of homelessness, exclusion from school, crime, involvement in drug and alcohol abuse, self-harm, mental health issues or family crisis. Eikon works in secondary schools and in youth centres and conducts Mobile Outreach programmes to target hard-to-reach young people. Eikon works with around 3,000 young people annually and aims to help young people build their wellbeing, resilience and aspirations. Eikon means picture or vision in the Greek language and this reflects Eikon’s ambition to help young people visualise and realise a better future for themselves. Since 2016 four charities – Eikon, Reflex Woking, Windle Valley Youth Project, and The Lifetrain Trust have merged to form the organisation that Eikon is today.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: Purchase of 50 tablets for disabled isolated people to access community services and support during the Covid-19 pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: Surrey Coalition of Disabled People
recipientOrganization.description: Surrey Coalition of Disabled People aims to promote the rights of disabled people in have equality of opportunity and to live as independently as they would like. We aim to help our members access the latest information about services and support for Disabled People in Surrey and to provide training to use and access to information about various technologies. The main activities of the organisation are: Co-production and Engagement, Technology and Innovation, Wider Determinants of Health education, Influencing and Mental Health. Co-production and Engagement Surrey Coalition is the central point of contact for co-production activities with the Disabled community in Surrey. We organise groups for people with impairments of all types to come together to enable commissioners and service providers to work with end-users to better design services. We run regular groups such as Surrey Vision Action Group, a Long Term Neurological Conditions Group and a Hard of Hearing Forum as well as bespoke groups on request. Technology and Innovation We maintain a 'demonstration suite' of technology for our members to try and to learn with to improve wider social and health outcomes. Alongside devices, we demonstrate various apps like Google Live Transcribe and Mental Health apps. We run technology pilot projects that will benefit Disabled people and Carers. A current project we are coordinating if called TESH (Technology Enabled Smarter Homes) and our next pilot is starting in the East of the County soon and is called Tech to Community Connect. It will explore the use of technology in reducing loneliness and isolation for Disabled people and Carers. Wider determinants of Health education We work in collaboration with other organisations such as the NHS and Social Care to promote services and support available and to deliver key health messages. We work with organisations like Active Surrey Disability to support projects that will make Physical Activity more accessible to Disabled People. Influencing We work to influence locally and Nationally to improve accessibility and inclusion for Disabled people. As an example, National work with NHS England to improve the accessibility of the NHS 111 service for people with a Hearing Impairment. We run a series of 'Lets Loop Surrey' visits to highlight local issues with accessibility and to help the organisation to make their business or service more accessible. Mental Health We regularly communicate Mental Health information to our membership including sources of support and developments to services in Surrey. As people who are Disabled or who have a Long Term Health Condition (LTHC) are much more likely to experience Mental ill-Health, it is important that services are accessible to everyone so we ensure that we keep on top of new and existing services. We coordinate the Independent Mental Health Network (IMHN) for the Surrey and NE Hants area and we have a contract with Surrey and borders NHS Partnership Trust to deliver the FoCUS (Forum of Carers and people who Use Services) network.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Older people
grants.description: Core costs for a charity supporting isolated older people in Woking during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: Woking Age Concern
recipientOrganization.description: Age Concern Woking is an independent registered charity which was set up in 2005 following research among organisations working with older people in the Woking area. The charity’s objective is to promote the well being of older people in the Woking area and to help make life a fulfilling and enjoyable experience. One key service which Age Concern Woking provides is a befriending scheme whereby volunteers make regular visits to the homes of older people. This service has been running for many years and currently supports over 50 people on an ongoing basis. The charity also runs a ‘Home from Hospital’ service to support elderly people who have recently returned from hospital, to ensure that they settle back home and are receiving all the help they require; as well as an Emergency Assistance service, which currently receives around 20 referrals per month. An information and sign-posting helpline is also provided for elderly people in need of advice and guidance in respect of a range of issues such as local services and social welfare. This telephone line answers queries from around 90 callers per month. Age Concern Woking also provides a fire risk check programme, in partnership with Surrey Fire and Rescure Service, through which trained volunteers help to keep older people safe by carrying out home fire safety checks and installing smoke detectors where necessary. All of the services offered by Age Concern Woking are available free of charge. The charity currently has a management committee comprised of 8 people and 4 part-time members of staff. Approximately 77 volunteers assist the charity on an ongoing basis. During 2012/13, Age Concern Woking’s friendship volunteers and staff visited/befriended 104 clients, and taking each of the charity’s services into account, 1,137 older people were helped during the period.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Older people
grants.description: A contribution to the costs of continuing to support older people in Reigate ad Redhill during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: MHA Reigate & Redhill Live at Home Scheme
recipientOrganization.description: MHA Reigate and Redhill Live At Home Scheme is part of the nationwide Live at Home Initiative, run by Methodist Homes for the Aged (MHA) Care Group, a registered charity, founded in 1943 to care for vulnerable older people. There are 60 Live at Home Schemes across the country, operating under the MHA charity umbrella. However, each Scheme operates autonomously, is guided by an elected Committee of local people (including Members, volunteers, supporters) and is required to self fund. MHA Reigate and Redhill Live At Home Scheme was set up in 1997 and is a local Surrey-based service, which operates from an office base in Redhill Methodist Church. It supports older (60+) people who are living in their own homes to feel a renewed sense of purpose and belonging within their communities. The organisations aims are to maintain independent living, improve well-being and reduce isolation. It runs a diverse programme of activities, which focus on enhancing a positive outlook, promoting independence and building strong friendships and social networks. MHA offer accessible and affordable weekly day clubs in Horley, Redhill and Reigate, monthly coffee mornings and escorted shopping trips, a weekly club specifically for those living with dementia and their carers, an annual holiday, seasonal outings, befriending for those finding it harder to get out and about, a telephone befriending service, a range of volunteering opportunities, a handy-man repair service and monthly pub trips for ladies and gents. In Spring 2019 two new clubs opened in Merstham and south Reigate. The day clubs offer a 'structured' activity in the morning e.g. exercise, a talk, a team game or a music session, followed by a home cooked lunch and then informal games and chat. MHA are a Membership scheme and charge a small (£12) membership fee every 6 months and currently have nearly 160 Members. They rely heavily on our volunteers helping staff at the Clubs, with transporting our Members to activities, as Befrienders and as Chefs.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Addiction
grants.description: Funding to support vulnerable people struggling with addiction in Surrey during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: Catalyst
recipientOrganization.description: Catalyst (Previously known as SADAS - Surrey Alcohol and Drug Advisory Services) is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee. It offers drug and alcohol users across Surrey access to support, thus reducing the harm to themselves, their families, and communities. Counselling for those struggling with substance use issues is provided through the ‘Reach Out’ programme. In addition, the charity’s ‘Welcome Project’ offers support, guidance and activities to increase wellbeing for people affected by stress, anxiety and depression, and who may feel isolated. The Welcome Project is part of Community Connections mental and emotional wellbeing services for working-age adults in Surrey. Catalyst also works with those at risk of losing a tenancy and who have complex needs including mental health problems. The head office is based in Guildford, but the charity also has offices in Surrey Heath and Godalming. Catalyst works with all partner agencies from within the health sector in a drop-in, counselling, group and outreach format. Approximately 5000 people are supported per year. The Charity was established in 1998 and is governed by 8 Trustees.

grants.description: Project costs to provide cooked meals to disadvantaged families, elderly and isolated people in Guildford during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: Foodwise (TLC) Limited
recipientOrganization.description: To relieve financial hardship through the provision of food coaching to teach people how to budget, purchase, prepare and cook nutritional food at reasonable cost undertaken within a Christian ethos.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Mental wellbeing
grants.description: Costs to providing remote support to grieving people across Surrey during the Coronavirus Pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: Jigsaw (South East)
recipientOrganization.description: Established in 2012 and previously operating as a branch of the national charity Jigsaw4U, Jigsaw (South East) [JSE] is now a separate registered charity and a company limited by guarantee. The charity is based in East Grinstead (West Sussex), and its objects are "to relieve the mental, spiritual and physical distress of children and young people in Surrey and surrounding areas where a family member has a terminal diagnosis, or to support children and young people who have experienced the death of a close family member through illness, accident, suicide or murder". The charity provides support via 1-1 sessions, home and school visits, and family support group programmes. Grief Support Workers run Family Groups which give families the opportunity to meet others in a similar situation and share their experiences. The groups comprise a six-week programme run one evening per week and for one full day on a Saturday. JSE provides advice, support and training to schools and other professionals, runs a forum for young people aged 10-16, and offers newsletters, days out and events. 14 part-time members of staff are employed by the charity. The charity is also supported by a team of 30 volunteers and has 4 Trustees. The majority of Jigsaw’s clients are resident in Surrey, although a small proportion are resident in the northern part of West Sussex and in Kent.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Older people
grants.description: Core costs to increase capacity and support of vulnerable and critical care people during the Coronavirus pandemic
grants.Primary beneficiary: People in care or suffering serious illness

recipientOrganization.name: Phyllis Tuckwell Hospice
recipientOrganization.description: The Phyllis Tuckwell Hospice is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee, not having a share capital. The charity’s mission statement is “to give excellent specialist care and support to patients and families living with life-limiting illnesses, and through training, empower other healthcare professionals to do the same”. The hospice is based in Farnham and offers Specialist Palliative Care to adults facing the end of their life, serving a population of 600,000 across West Surrey and North East Hampshire. The charity has been supporting patients with life-limiting conditions and their families since 1979. Every day, the hospice supports over 100 patients and carers in their own homes and at the Hospice. Services include Clinical Nurse Specialists, an 18-bed In-Patient Unit, a Day Hospice, Patient and Family Services, Physiotherapy, Occupational Therapy and Complementary Therapy. All services are offered free of charge. The NHS covers less than 16% of the charity’s costs, which means that the Hospice has to fundraise 84p in every pound - over £10,000 a day. The charity currently employs 64 members of full-time staff and 213 part-time staff; the charity also benefits from the support of 950 volunteers and 11 trustees.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Families with Young Children
grants.description: A contribution to core costs to a charity supporting disadvantaged families during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: Home-Start Runnymede and Woking
recipientOrganization.description: Home-Start Runnymede and Woking (HSRW) is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee. The charity’s aim is to offer free, confidential and non-judgemental support and practical help to families where there is a child under the age of 5, who are experiencing difficulties and struggling to cope with the challenges of parenting. HSRW staff assess each family’s needs and match the family with a volunteer. All volunteers are parents themselves and undergo a preparation course. A volunteer will visit a family once a week in their own homes for up to a year and work co-operatively to enable the family to cope with the demands of being a parent, to develop resilience, and to prevent the need for intervention by statutory services. HSRW is planning to expand the work by offering group work and parenting courses, in response to Surrey County Council cost-cutting many children’s centres in the area. The charity plans to centre its support on level-2-need families who are no longer able to access Children’s' Centre support due to changes in how children’s centres operate. During the year to 31st March 2019 HSRW was able to support 138 families and worked with 271 children, 211 under the age of 5 and 60 older children. The charity has also run 2 volunteer preparation courses during the year, adding 10 new home-visiting volunteers to the team.

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Tendring Eldercare
recipientOrganization.description: Tendring Eldercare was formerly known as Family Support Clacton (801336), which was started in 1982. As of 1st April 2014 the Charity became a Charitable Incorporated Organisation, and the trustees changed the name to Tendring Eldercare as it kept more in line with the services we provide. With over 30 years of experience the aims of the Charity are to improve the quality of life for older people. Particularly those who are isolated many of which are living in the rural areas of Tendring, to reduce isolation and alleviate the pressure on their families and carers. We deliver our services through our wellbeing day centre which is situated in West Clacton, and our rural luncheon club situated in Little Clacton. Our flexible approach allows us to tailor our services to suit each clients individual needs.

grants.title: Grant to Accuro (Care Services)
grants.description: to respond to the COVID19 crisis and help sustain an organisation which supports children, young people and adults with a learning disability and their families in West Essex

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

recipientOrganization.name: Accuro (Care Services)
recipientOrganization.description: Accuro is a small, local charity, which aims to support people with learning disabilities in Harlow and across West Essex by delivering a wide range of social activities to avoid loneliness and social isolation and to provide much needed respite to families. Accuro • develop potential of people of all ages with learning disabilities, • help teach new skills including life, social, communication skills • help avoid loneliness and social isolation • improve self-confidence, self-esteem • increase independence • increase happiness, wellbeing • help prepare children for adulthood • provide respite for families Accuro’s strategic vision is to eliminate loneliness and social isolation of people with learning disabilities within their local communities, enhancing their confidence to cross bridges into a wider world. Accuro currently run the following services to meet our aims • Cool connections – a youth club for children U19 with Autism (ASD) in Harlow • Under 19 project – 2 youth clubs for children U19 with disability, in Uttlesford (Great Dunmow and Saffron Walden) • Loughton Youth Group – for U19s in Loughton • Saturday Play club – U16s in Saffron Walden • School Holiday Project – Group activities and 1 to 1 sessions across Harlow, Epping and Uttlesford. • Adult Friendship Scheme – Social Evenings, small group activities in Harlow and Uttlesford By working closely with our service users, their families and community partners such as Essex County Council we ensure we identify the need and develop innovative creative solutions to meet the identified need, enhancing the lives of local children, young people and adults with disability and their families. Accuro provide opportunities for local people with disability to belong, contribute and thrive. We have over 35 years’ experience and a proven track record of delivery. We make a real impact and in our 2016 stakeholder survey 100% of respondents said they were “proud of Accuro” and would “recommend us to a family in need.” Respondents in our stakeholder survey also told us “Accuro is a lifeline” and “Without Accuro my sons’ life would be less”. We were told Accuro have “given my child a chance” and “are a highly valued support for our family and have helped us cope in the darkest of times when we felt alone” “My son gets so much from Accuro”, “my daughter has made most of her friends at Accuro” and “we couldn’t get the support from anywhere else, the whole family benefits from the break”. A volunteer said, “I have never been happier than when I was able to volunteer every week – it was honestly the highlight of my week.” A grant from HRF will help Accuro continue to make a real difference to the lives of local people with disability, and their families / carers in Harlow. The funding from Harlow recreational fund will enable us to continue to provide social and recreational activities for people with disability living in Harlow attending Cool connections and / or Harlow Adult Friendship scheme. Accuro provide opportunities for local people to belong, contribute and thrive and with your support we can continue doing so. Thank you for considering our application.

grants.title: Grant to Wilderness Foundation UK
grants.description: to provide an online service and sustain an organisation providing support to young people and their families through outdoor education during COVID19

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

recipientOrganization.name: Wilderness Foundation UK
recipientOrganization.description: The Wilderness Foundation reaches in the region of 5,500 children, young people and adults per year. We prepare and educate participants for the future through participation and inclusion in wild activities. We promote that nature and wild spaces are of incalculable value not just to maintain biodiversity and wildlife but for human wellbeing. Our objectives as set out in the memorandum of association are: *To advance the education of the public by increasing knowledge and understanding of wilderness and the conservation thereof, the interrelationship between wilderness and the environment generally by the provision of instruction, and of opportunities, for direct experience of wilderness. *To initiate and manage social benefit programmes which will use wilderness experience to enable vulnerable and disadvantaged people to play a fuller role in society (especially the young). All our projects and programmes provide direct support, connecting people to nature for wellbeing benefits, mental, spiritual and physical – and to teach people in turn to care for nature into the future. We teach Leave no Trace Ethics, respect for, and understanding of our impact on the web of life whilst developing positive social connections and relationships.

grants.title: Grant to Welcome to the UK
grants.description: towards additional staff time and education resources for migrant and refugee families in Southend during COVID19

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Improve life skills, education, employability and enterprise

recipientOrganization.name: Welcome to the UK
recipientOrganization.description: Welcome to the UK supports migrant families in Southend to engage in our community, realise and reach their aspirations. We enable families to adapt to life in the UK, including language barriers, personal and professional development and isolation. We work annually with 150 women and their families from 20 countries. In 2012, our founder moved to the UK, unable to speak or understand English. She will not forget how hard everything was. She had started a new life, in a new country, expecting her first child. She looked for an organization, to reduce the loneliness she felt. Online she found nothing local. She joined ESOL and in 2014 started her own friendship group for migrant mothers. We remain the only group of its kind locally, and have all-female trustees with experience of migration. We hold friendship groups with women and their children, English classes and other workshops. Our activities are driven by peer-to-peer support built between members. We enable migrant women to overcome barriers in achieving their self-defined aspirations. Our work supports families, to feel safe, and secure, whilst also enabling them to feel pride in Southend as their home by encouraging them to be actively involved in their communities.

grants.title: Grant to Kids Inspire
grants.description: to continue providing emotional support to young people across Essex during COVID19

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Kids Inspire
recipientOrganization.description: Kids Inspire helps disadvantaged young people turn their lives around and gives them back their future. Our goal is to ensure no child is left without the support needed for wellbeing, to live a full and happy life, by building relationships through therapy, coaching, mentoring, group work, family support in the form of bespoke, child-centred service packages. We support young people across Essex who are at an educational, social and/or economic disadvantage resulting from trauma, emerging mental health issues or who are referred because other support agencies consider them 'too complex' to help. We are developing a community arm.

grants.title: Grant to First Stop Centre
grants.description: to sustain an organisation supporting vulnerable people in Braintree during the COVID19 pandemic

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: First Stop Centre
recipientOrganization.description: First Stop Centre is a community drop in centre, based near the town centre in Braintree. Our mission is to work with people who are disadvantaged, in a non-judgemental way in order to improve their lives. We have been operating in Braintree since 1981 and over that time we have worked with other agencies and hundreds of clients. We see a wide range of clients including: Those who have a history of mental health Those who have learning disabilities Substance mis-users The homeless Single Parents Unemployed Ex-offenders Senior citizens We offer many interventions in order to make a difference, these are: Basic Skills education classes (English, Maths and Computer Classes) Life Skills training (anger management, self-esteem building, budgeting skills) Individual Time Limited Counselling Benefits advice Job seeking skills (C.V. construction and interview techniques) Advocacy Service (within the context of citizen advocacy) Canteen Befriending Many of the clients that access First Stop are people that have slipped through the net. Some are unable to read and write, many are not engaging with other statutory agencies. Because we are a small independent charity, we are able to work with these clients and in many cases provide the support in order that they can access the help they need. We provide the clients with a positive experience, which gives them the best chance of making changes in and to their lives and moving forward. Each week we see over 50 clients. The difference we made to these clients included: Many were able to engage in classes and work towards a formal qualification. Some clients were able to produce a C.V. and to link this to internet job sites, where appropriate Clients who attended our anger management classes have reported they have been able to start making more positive choices about their behaviour We helped clients towards social inclusion and become less socially isolated Provided a safe meeting place for other interventions from other agencies- as we are known to many of their clients and they feel safe meeting here We pride ourselves on being non-judgmental and working to enable the client, for some this is over a short period of time, for others this may take a lot longer, and the forming of a trusting relationship with us is a huge step for some. We are able to take steps at the client’s pace, and we often feel like parents gently pushing the clients to make positive choices and steps towards becoming a more active, healthy member of our community.

grants.title: Grant to Community 360
grants.description: for the costs of a community response project during the COVID19 pandemic to provide support for the most vulnerable people in Braintree, Colchester and Maldon

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Community 360
recipientOrganization.description: Community360 (C360) is an independent charity formed in 1968. We are committed to a vision to build “thriving local communities”. Our Mission is: - “To inspire and enable local community action to improve quality of life”. We aim to do this in line with our core values, which are to: - provide passionate, intelligent leadership for the sector in Colchester, Essex and beyond; - empower people, groups and organisations through high quality support - -be creative and innovative in meeting the needs of local communities and the voluntary and community groups and organisations that serve them; and - be fair and honest in everything we do We achieve this through a number of projects, including an experienced Community Development team, Community Accounts Service and Business Bank. As a result, staff lead on community volunteering programmes with more than 400 volunteers, work with over 300 community groups a year to access funding, embed good financial practices, recruit their own volunteers, plan and train, as well as network and promote what they do. We value working in partnership and consult regularly with the sector to guide the development of policy, co-produce new projects and deliver services. We also manage programmes that provide fundamental, practical support to the community. Our Community Transport schemes facilitate over 50,000 trips each year and we hire scooters and wheelchairs to people 5 days a week. Our organisation is constantly evolving, anticipating opportunities in our community and seeking to maximise the impact that we can all have to make our vision a reality. As the provider of Community Voluntary Services (CVS) for Braintree District, we deliver projects that improve the quality of life for local residents and enable voluntary action to impact in neighborhoods and parishes. At the heart of what we do is Community Development. We support charities and non-profit making groups to form, establish their activities and continue to operate, whilst upholding good standards of practice. We help them to find the resources they need (i.e. funds or in kind donations), network and collaborate to enhance their opportunities (such as through Lunch and Learn sessions) and to learn and develop with the provision of courses and bespoke training. We are involved in many fora and committees to work well across the voluntary and community sector. We identify gaps and develop services to meet them. For example, we have established the Braintree District Older Persons forum, where agencies that support older people can network and work together on shared agendas to support older residents in the district. We manage Braintree Time Bank – we encourage social action through the principles co-production, time bank members use time as currency to exchange skills and support. Over the past year 57 new time bank members have exchanged 2000 hours of time to support the local community through initiatives such as a Community Caretakers scheme and i-tea computing sessions. We oversee Braintree Volunteer Centre – as 1 of 14 centres in the Volunteer Essex network we advertise and recruit volunteers for 200 organisations as well as provide guidance and support around volunteer management and best practice. We have placed 69 volunteers in the first six months of the year. We are introducing a Slipper Exchange as part of our falls prevention agenda. Braintree residents can exchange old, sloppy and worn slipper for a new well fitted pair as well as find out information on support services and community activities. We have already exchanged 45 pairs with plans to expand this during the Winter period. We also have a strong commitment to health and wellbeing initiatives, which we would like to continue to expand. We embed good health and wellbeing throughout all of our programmes. However, we seek to offer targeted support where possible. This may be through volunteering, our community weight management service, providing social groups or monthly Tree-Mendous walks of Braintree and Bocking Gardens. Throughout Mid Essex we work with a range of partners and have particular strong working synergies with Braintree District Council as part of the Live Well Child campaign (addressing childhood obesity and working with ten schools in the district), Active Braintree Network and the Strategic Health and Wellbeing Board. We pride ourselves on providing proactive community engagement, meaning we like to take our services to people. Working throughout the district we understand the challenges faced by town and rural communities, particularly with regards to accessing services. We are adept at working with residents to establish activities based on their needs, rather than prescribing a ‘one size fits all approach’.

grants.title: Grant to Volunteer Centre Uttlesford
grants.description: to increase staff hours who are coordinating volunteers to respond during the COVID19 pandemic in Uttlesford

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Volunteer Centre Uttlesford
recipientOrganization.description: Volunteer Uttlesford was established in 1995 to support the community of Uttlesford which is the largest geographical district in Essex and the most rural. The overall aim of the organisation is to 'make volunteering a part of everyday life in Uttlesford' we aim to achieve this by:- promoting and developing volunteering across Uttlesford acting as a broker by matching volunteers with appropriate opportunities, identifying, creating and developing volunteering opportunities, marketing the benefits of volunteering publicising the health, well-being and social benefits of volunteering broadening the impact of volunteering through innovation providing skills to improve the quality of volunteers enhancing the quality of life, health and well-being of individuals through volunteering Our current projects include: Working with young people aged from 9 years, encouraging them to be helpful and supportive to others who may have some additional requirements, giving them an early insight into volunteering and it's benefits to the community. Petal Wave Art Trail: an inter-generational art project, which is helping to raise awareness of dementia throughout Uttlesford. It is a voluntary project and as such encourages people of all ages to volunteer, in a fun and positive way. Employee Volunteering - working with local employers, to encourage volunteer employee schemes, in the past year we have had many successful employee volunteering days working with Organisations who have a short project, needing attention. Youth 16-19 promoting the idea of volunteering as a positive activity. Befriending - in partnership with St. Claire Hospice, running workshops for potential befrienders and supporters. Dementia Cafe - Managing a dementia cafe in Saffron Walden, for those living with and those caring for people with dementia, this is run almost exclusively by volunteers. All of these projects take place in sourcing, interviewing and placing general volunteers with Organisations and Timebank volunteers (being neighbourly) in your local community.

grants.title: Grant to Citizens Advice Bureau - Colchester
grants.description: for new IT and telephone systems to enable volunteers and staff to work remotely during the COVID19 pandemic

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Maximise ability to strengthen community cohesion and build social capacity

recipientOrganization.name: Citizens Advice Bureau - Colchester
recipientOrganization.description: CAC was established in 1939 as one of the original 200 Citizens Advice bureaux opened by the National Council of Social Services. From its inception, the service has been volunteer-led and existed to provide free, confidential, impartial advice to the citizens of Colchester to help them with the problems they face. The aims of CAC are to: • Provide free confidential and impartial advice and information for the benefit of the local community • To influence the development of social policies and services • To ensure that individuals do not suffer through lack of knowledge or inability to express their needs effectively. These aims contribute to the reduction of crime and antisocial behavior as: • We help clients escaspe from the cycle of long term debt, enabling them to return to economic activity. Last year we helped clients write off nmore that £600,000 of debt • We help clients to claim the benefits they are entitled to. Last year, we helped claim £64,000 of additional benefits • We help clients understand their rights and responsibilities at tenants. Lasr year, we helped with 3,000 housing issues • Help clients resolve employment issues. Last year, we helped with 1,200 employment issues To achieve these aims, we provide: • Face-to-face advice 5 mornings per week from our Crouch St Office (drop in service) • Follow-up appointments 5 days per week for more complex cases (casework) • Telephone advice 5 afternoons per week • Email advice 5 days per week via the Colchester Advice Network (CAN) • Face-to-face advice for 5 sessions per week at Colchester Central Library • Face-to-face advice on Wednesdays at Wivenhoe library (enabling library opening on a day when it would otherwise be closed). In addition, we run discrete projects to provide: • 1 session of face-to-face advice at the Lakes Mental Health unit, with follow-up casework where needed • 5 days specialist debt advice for Colchester Borough Homes tenants via home visits with follow up specialist casework. • 5 days advice via webchat • Weekly evening advice session at the Military Corrective Training Centre (MCTC) with follow up specialist casework. • Financial Assessment Benefits Advice (FABA). • Home Visiting Service for Essex County Council (ECC) benefits service. (Referral basis) In total, CAC provided advice to 12,000 clients last year (discrete client contacts) with 16,350 separate issues*. A bulk of advice (42%) related to debt, followed by benefits and tax credits (18%) and employment (10%). We monitor client volumes on a quarterly basis to ensure client contacts are in line with target. We also monitor trends in the mix of issues to ensure the skills of our advisers matches emerging client needs. * These figures include telephone and webchat advice. Some client contacts via these channels will be from outside the borough.

Services include showers, laundry, clothing, an IT suite, a postal address, hot meals and refreshments. Our Occupational Therapy service supports therapies and activities to improve people’s resilience and self-esteem; to develop skills and improve their social networks. Since 2016 we have provided supported move-on accommodation in partnership with another charity.

grants.title: COVID-19 COMMUNITY SUPPORT

grants.title: COVID-19 Faringdon Viral Kindness
grants.description: We are led and run by volunteers. We are working closely with the local Health Care Team, Police, Town and District Councils to ensure safety of the people we are providing help to as well as out volunteers.

recipientOrganization.name: Faringdon Volunteer Community Support
recipientOrganization.description: We help people stay safe and comfortable during self issolation by helping with: 1) Urgent supplies 2) A friendly person to talk to 3) Collecting prescriptions

grants.title: COVID-19 Cholsey Coronavirus Support Group
grants.description: The Day Centre closed its doors before the general lockdown in recognition of the increased risk to its elderly client group. It immediately set up the Cholsey Coronavirus Support Group (CCSG) in concert with Cholsey Older Persons Activities/Befriending Service (COPA, and organised a village meeting including the Parish Council and St Marys Church. The original aim was to maintain contact with our members and contacts, but as the crisis escalated we aimed to work with and for the village, and sent out a leaflet to every household with the DC contact number as the new Cholsey Helpline.

recipientOrganization.name: Cholsey Day Centre Trust
recipientOrganization.description: Cholsey Day Centre Trust runs a day centre for up to 35 members three times a week, and is open to the elderly, those with mild to moderate impairment issues, and mild to moderate dementia. As well as a cooked meal at lunchtime the Day Centre offers an increasingly diverse range of activities and entertainments, as well as providing a limited range of outreach provision.

grants.title: COVID-19 Responding Positively
grants.description: We are closed and therefore not receiving the weekly attendance fees from members. Our major fundraiser , the Easter bazaar has had to be cancelled .We are continuing to fully employ our Coordinator to maintain at least regular weekly contact with members ( by phone , letter and e mail) and their family many of whom live away and in any case cannot visit.

recipientOrganization.name: The Wychwoods Day Centre Ltd
recipientOrganization.description: We are a locally based Day Centre for the Elderly with 22 members(average age 85) We meet once a week offering refreshments and a two course home cooked lunch with activities ranging from music therapy to church services, scrabble to quizzes. Our aim is to reduce social isolation and enable people to remain at home for as long as possible .We are the only type of provision of its kind in the Wychwood Villages and apart from a part time paid Coordinator exist entirely through the efforts of approximately 50 volunteers who drive, help and cook.

grants.title: COVID-19 Creatively Clever
grants.description: We are setting up a programme of online and at home resources for young people aged 13-19. We will provide bespoke tutorials and any equpiment needed to access them in topics of interest to young people. We will also be providing virtual youth club spaces hosted by qualified youth workers to support young people facing disadvantage and dealing with pressure created by the pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Leys CDI
recipientOrganization.description: Leys CDI is a local charity which develops and co-ordinates projects of long-term benefit to the Blackbird Leys and Greater Leys estates in Oxford. It is a grass roots project that is led by local people and focuses on delivering a project for young people aged 9-25 and an over 50's project called The Clockhouse. The organisations strengths lie in its community roots and its trusted relationships with local people who are at the heart of the organisation. Leys CDI strongly believes in enabling local people to get involved and learn new skills and progress through the project to leadership.

grants.title: COVID-19 MLMC Coronavirus Service
grants.description: Following Government advice and to ensure the health and safety of our members with a learning disability and our staff and volunteers, we have taken the decision to close our office and put all of our activities, projects and group work on hold. In order to secure the financial sustainability of the charity we have cut all unnecessary costs and taken advantage of the Government’s Staff Retention Scheme. However, we recognise that during this crisis, the physical and mental health of our members is at risk due to the loneliness, isolation, worry, confusion, and in some cases lack of support that they will experience.

recipientOrganization.name: Oxfordshire My Life My Choice Association
recipientOrganization.description: Our mission is threefold: 1. To make sure that there is independent support for people with learning disabilities in Oxfordshire to have their say, claim their rights and to take control of their own lives. 2. To make sure that the views of people with learning disabilities are taken seriously by both professionals in the services they use and the wider public. 3. To “Power Up” their lives so they can make a positive contribution to society. Our activities include a peer-led travel training scheme, user-led training, a learning disability nightclub, Gig Buddies, a campaigns team and 13 self-advocacy groups.

grants.title: COVID-19 Kirtlington Youth Club Survival
grants.description: We have shut down our club night and our youth leader is staying in contact with all our members through social media. He provides puzzles, tasks and challenges to the group whilst at the same time keeping very close contact with our more vunerable members ( bullying being the main issue ). Due to Covis 19 we have lost three very valuable income streams that would have ensured our survival until our main fund raiser in Nov ( ? ).

recipientOrganization.name: Kirtlington Youth Club
recipientOrganization.description: Kirtlington Youth Club caters for the young people of both Kirtlington and the surrounding villages ( Bletchington, Weston on the Green etc, ). We aim to provide a safe and secure enviroment for young people ( age 10-16) in a rural area to meet and overcome some of the restrictions that living in a rural village give young people. We look to integrate the young people into the village community and give them a voice.

grants.title: COVID-19 Emergency Family Support Project
grants.description: Oxfordshire Family Support Network is facing an unprecedented need for support from an incredibly vulnerable demographic. recipientOrganization.name: Oxfordshire Family Support Network
recipientOrganization.description: Oxfordshire Family Support Network exists to support and empower the family carers of people with learning disabilities. We provide information, advice and 1:1 support - helping carers to self advocate and enabling them to ensure the right support for their family member. The families we work with tend to be caring for a loved one with severe or profound needs, who is unable to live independently. Whilst we work with famiy carers - the adults and children with learning disabilities that they support are our ultiamate beneficiaries.

We run groups to allow parents to come out and form part of a community. We also offer parents evidence based information in which they can then make there own parenting choices from evidence based informtion delivered in a appropriate way. Due to corona we are unable to run groups and offer parents the much needed face to face support.

grants.title: Covid19

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Iranian Community of Hull (ICOH)
recipientOrganization.description: The Iranian Community of Hull (ICOH) is an Anglo-Iranian voluntary and community group which supports newcomers and facilitates their integration into British society. According to the Office for National Statistics (ONS) more than 600 people with Iranian ethnic heritage are living in Hull. Iranians make up the highest proportion of asylum applications to the U.K. and Hull has a disproportionate number of Iranians who have settled in the city. ICOH has around 300 active members. We work in close liaison with leading local charities and Black, Asian and Minority Ethnic (BAME) community groups based in Hull and Yorkshire to: - Deliver training and employment services. - Support asylum seekers with their relocation. - Provide emotional support and special services. - Run cultural and social activities. Training and social activities are used by ICOH to introduce beneficiaries to British and other minority ethnic customs, reduce loneliness and discourage segregation. We have already seen more members finding employment, gaining confidence speaking English to local people, befriending individuals from outside their ethnic community and an understanding of British customs.

grants.title: Covid19
grants.description: Covid-19. Funding to enable services to continue.

recipientOrganization.name: JPC Community Farm
recipientOrganization.description: We provide relief to people with complex needs by reason of disability by providing accommodation, care, development opportunities and employability training, as well as through the provision of respite facilities, advice and services for those who care for them. We provide meaningful day care support, specialist education and independence training for disable people, with a focus on young adults. This includes sessions to address their needs and improve their confidence as well as a range of independent living and other transferable skills, including household skills, personal care, accessing community facilities, rights and leisure activities. Most of our beneficiaries face multiple disadvantage including through physical impairments, sensory impairments, autism as well as learning or mental difficulties, meaning they required 24-hour care and support. We also operate The Orangery, an on-site community café as a social enterprise which provides employment and work experience opportunities for our disabled participants. We have also applied for funding to provide a free meals delivery service for vulnerable people during the current Covid-19 pandemic.

grants.title: Covid19
grants.description: Covid-19 response. Funding will support organisation increased project costs to enable them to continue to reach participants.
grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Revival North Yorkshire CIC
recipientOrganization.description: Our objective is to support and improve the mental, physical and emotional well-being of the local community, particularly those who are elderly and vulnerable in the rurally isolated North York Moors. We aim to: • Combat loneliness and isolation • Promote home independence • Revive the culture and heritage of the North York Moors through local traditions and activities We currently provide a range of support, services and activities which encourages community spirit ,bringing people together, so that they can maintain connections and make new friendships which will help to prevent loneliness and isolation. We provide Memory Lane Lunches in the Danby and Sleights areas, Memory Lane Music and Good Old Days reminiscing sessions. We are currently sourcing funding to begin Move It or Lose exercise classes in to villages. We have applied to The National Lottery Community Fund for funding and this will no doubt be seriously delayed in the current situation.

grants.title: Covid19
grants.description: Covid-19. Funding for fuel and equipment for remote working, and for staff costs to support adults with learning difficulties.
grants.Impact Category: Improve life skills, education, employability and enterprise

recipientOrganization.name: Ripon Community Link
recipientOrganization.description: Ripon Community Link supports adults and young people with learning disabilities offering day services and work experience. We do this at two sites, St Wilfrid's Bungalow, a dedicated facility in the heart of the community and at Ripon Walled Garden a 4 acre site which has a woodland, orchard, historic walled garden and is open to the public. The Bungalow offers a wide range of support learning activities such as literacy, numeracy, art and drama. We also run community based groups such as recycling, rambling, sports and work experience roles at our pop-up coffee morning and community shop in a local residential home. At the Walled Garden service users have the opportunity to learn about horticulture in the gardens and customer service in the Tearoom. Woven through all our work is skill based education, supporting individuals to develop and explore their interests and to develop literacy, numeracy, money management and interpersonal skills. Through this we aim to improve independence and tackle potential issues of loneliness and poor health both mental and physical.

grants.title: Covid19
grants.description: Covid-19. Funding to set up connectivity for vulnerable people with no internet connection.
grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Springbank Community Association
recipientOrganization.description: We have provided all the usual community activities and facilities from our purpose built community centre for over 30 years. For the last ten years we have specialised in delivering help with IT to over 12000 people per year who didnt or hadnt had access to IT or dont have IT literacy through no fault of their own. Last year we delivered a three month pilot project delivering IT help in the home to over 50 elderly or disabled people. We provided help with internet connectivity and various home IT aids eg.Alexa, audio visual door alerts and audio visual connectivity via skype on large screens eg tv screens or tablets. We provided free recycled computers in many cases which had been donated and we had removed all data or installed new hardware in. We provided temporary connectivity via dongles in many cases and delivered instruction in use of all the equipment. The present emergency highlights the vulnerable people who are not connected to internet services. Fair numbers of people still do not have any contact with the outside world apart from ordinary phones and many do not have or can use smart phones. All current advice and information is via the web and these people dont have access to it!.These people will become known as the emergency unfolds and different organisations provide help and assistance outside the doors but there arent organisations set up to help connect them connect. We could provide dongles and tablets with very simple connection instructions.

recipientOrganization.description: Love Driffield exists to relieve poverty in the town of Driffield and the surrounding area of the East Riding of Yorkshire. This is primarily through running the Driffield and Wolds Food bank. The objects of the CIO are: To relieve persons in the Driffield and surrounding ares of the East Riding of Yorkshire that are in financial hardship in such ways as the trustees from time to time think fit, in particular, but not exclusively by: a) running a food bank, knows as "The Driffield and Wolds Food bank" providing emergency food, essential toiletries, and household items to individuals and families in need and/or for distribution by charities or other organisations working to prevent or relieve poverty. b) Such other means, including (but not limited to) the provision of support or signposting to relevant information and other advisory services.

recipientOrganization.description: Incredible Edible Marshland aimsto bring together the Marshland villages through growing and sharing, to support a kind, confident and connected community. We currently have a programme of cookery classes, tutored gardening classes, community gardening/growing projects, social activities around cooking/growing/sharing. We have planned a VE Day planting session, a programme of communal growing, developing of verges with wildflowers to support the environment, a 'Clothes Swap' and other activities to support community engagement.

recipientOrganization.description: Paperworks is a charity and social enterprise providing personalised support for individuals with autism, learning disabilities, and complex needs. Our aim is to enable our clients to play a greater part in their communities. We offer the chance to develop in a real work environment with tailored one-to-one training plans, as well as opportunities to meet new people and gain skills in a range of well being activities and projects.

recipientOrganization.name: Local Works Ltd
recipientOrganization.description: Local Works Ltd was established in 2011 and is an alternative education provider specialising in delivering sports based education programmes. In particular, the company focuses on providing courses for young people who find it difficult to cope with the formal education system, are from deprived backgrounds and who face multiple barriers to personal development. The objective of the programmes offered is to create opportunities for young people to develop their social skills, gain confidence and self-esteem and break out of an often isolated and marginalised existence. The company offers a BTEC course in Active Sports and Leisure and has contracts with local schools and academies to deliver the programme. In addition, the company offers evening activities that are not qualification based but are focused on developing on young people's team skills, learning how to relate to others and understanding their role in the local community. The recently delivered I Will Fund financed project in conjunction with the Two Ridings Foundation was a great success and we have continued to provide for the young people using our resources and a small grant from the Crime Reduction Fund. A small group of 8 volunteers has been formed from the group arising from the young people’s own initiative.We focus on the most vulnerable young people in the local community.

recipientOrganization.name: Resurrected Bites Community Interest Company
recipientOrganization.description: Pre Covid-19 we ran pay as you feel cafes in Harrogate & Knaresborough using good quality food that was destined for landfill in order to tackle loneliness and food poverty. We have obviously closed our cafes and are now providing free food packages with 3 days food including cooked meals to the most vulnerable in Harrogate, Knaresborough & Boroughbridge. We have given food packages to over 250 people in the first 8 days.

recipientOrganization.name: Ingleton Rural Community Association
recipientOrganization.description: We raise funds to provide and maintain a community Centre, Sports Field, Multi Use Games area, Bowling Green and Outdoor Swimming Pool. We provide leisure events throughout the year to promote social cohesion within the Parish of Ingleton, We also host educational courses to help people access training locally without need for travel therefore increasing skills for employment. We also provide financial help to affiliated groups and advice where required. At present we have set up a helpline at the Community Centre to allow the elderly and vulnerable to call in to organise shopping and prescription delivery. We the mobilise one of our 70 volunteers to deliver the goods and/or prescription.
