recipientOrganization.name: Artizan
recipientOrganization.description: We enable, empower and support people with disabilities to meet their full potential, through therapeutic craft activities and social enterprise, in the uk and the developing world. In the UK we run free weekly craft workshops for adults and children with disabilities in Harrogate, Ripon and Leeds. This provides vital opportunities for people with disabilities to get out of their care homes, increase their social interaction, make new friends and learn new skills in a caring, supportive and creative environment. Participants can also take part in events, helping sell the crafts, giving them the opportunity to meet the public and demonstrate their skills, talents and abilities. This also raises their self-esteem, reduces their social isolation and benefits their mental wellbeing. Our trained mosaic artists have an incredible opportunity to be part of our "mosaics for schools" project where they teach children in primary schools how to mosaic over the course of 6 visits to the school. The objective of this project is that we break down barriers between the able and less-able in our society, children have the experience of working with those who are differently-able and discover that these differences are not so great after all. For our artisans, it is a rare and empowering opportunity to be the one teaching a skill as opposed to receiving instruction. We also run two after-school craft clubs for children with disabilities and special needs, providing vital opportunities for social interaction, having fun and learning new skills in a caring and supporting environment.

The work we do aims to build the skills and knowledge of individuals through hands on participatory activities to grow food, cook healthier meals, learn crafts and DIY skills that help them make their money go further and improves their physical and mental health.

This entails: * Encouraging generous giving among our members, and displaying generosity to those around us, in terms of money, attitudes and practical service. * Giving away the Good News of Jesus Christ, in word and action, to all who wish to hear it. * Building people up in faith, good relationships, well-being, self-esteem and maturity. We try to achieve these aims in all our activities, which include worship services, children's groups, meals for homeless people, a club for young adults with learning disabilities, a parent and toddler group, a coffee drop-in, and the loaning of our premises for a host of community groups and events.

recipientOrganization.name: Bentham Older People Together
recipientOrganization.description: Please note that Bentham Older People Together acts under the auspices of Low Bentham Public Hall and Victoria Institute which is the registered charity and which manages and is accountable for our income and expenditure. The following are the aims of Bentham Older People Together: 1. Provide a safe, welcoming environment for the older people in the community; 2. Reduce rural isolation and loneliness and thereby improve individuals’ health and wellbeing; 3. Build resilience in older members of the community through access to high quality information, help with the internet, support networks and friendship; 4. To encourage community participation through volunteering; 5. To build positive relationships between older residents and marginalised young people in the community. This application specifically relates to a short-term project we have established which aims to: 1. Make sure people in the Bentham area who are self-isolating or unable to get out know how to get help; 2. Find out who is able to volunteer some help, however limited; 3. Provide support for matching people who need help with volunteers, and providing registration, training and support for those volunteers.

The general charitable purposes are the advancement of health or saving lives, Disability, The prevention or relief of poverty and Recreation. The beneficiaries are elderly and old people and other charities or voluntary bodies. This is achieved by providing services, providing advocacy, advice and information. The identified activities are: A wide range of older people’s services aimed at improving later life and enabling them to remain independent and in their own homes. Transport – minibus journeys and volunteer car scheme, Information and Advice, Independent support, Home from Hospital service, Befriending, Day activities – Lunch Clubs, social opportunities and special interest groups. Practical help at home.

recipientOrganization.name: Kingstrust Network CIO : Gateway Community Care Hub
recipientOrganization.description: The Community Care Hub was opened on the 7th March 2020 with a view to help minimise the effects of poverty, enhance social inclusion and social well-being. It replaced the Gateway Charity Shop and is jointly run by Kingstrust Network CIO and Gateway Church Withernsea CIO. Before Coronavirus the Hub, was running a creche facility for disasdvantaged parents. We also had a group session aimed at the local residential care home residents, called Tea, Toast and Natter. Also a communal meal on a Wednesday that was focused on our vulnerable and lonely community members, this was being done on a donation basis so that those who couldn't afford were still made welcome. Since Coronavirus the government imposed ruling on social isolation, The Gateway Community Care Hub has obviously suspended these services and has acted as an emergency response hub responding too the desperate needs of essential food items, delivering items to households such as prescriptions and obtaining shopping for people self-isolating. we have created a toy library to address restlessness and also have clothes in stock to answer the need due to non essential shops closing and baby supplies. Educational packs for all ages as well extra need children are also being delivered to those requiring and craft packs. Also we are addressing feelings loneliness and uncertainty at this time through a befriending system.

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Action for Family Carers
recipientOrganization.description: Action for Family Carers was established in 1990 to promote the relief of persons who are ill, disabled, incapacitated or elderly and to make a positive difference to the lives of unpaid family Carers, including Young Carers, in Essex. Our Board of Trustees, many of whom are Carers themselves, oversee our charity’s aims which are: 1) To have a positive impact on outcomes for Carers 2) To raise public awareness about Carers 3) To improve public awareness of the organisation 4) To ensure the sustainability of the organisation for the benefit of Carers We hold NCVO’s PQASSO Quality Mark at Level 3; only the fourth organisation in the UK and the first in Essex to achieve this. The assessors noted in particular the dedication of the staff and volunteers and stated that “Governance is truly excellent – it is a real strength of the organisation in all its aspects”. The needs and views of Carers in Essex are central to all we do. We consult with Carers regularly to ensure we provide the support they need, when needed. We facilitate regular Carer Reference groups and Carer Forums. Carers save the economy millions of pounds each year through unpaid care. We support them to continue to care appropriately. There are an estimated 180,000 adult Carers in Essex. We support adult Carers with advice and guidance and through our ‘Feeling Good, Caring Well’ wellbeing programme; volunteer-led counselling and befriending; training and support to return to work. We give Carers respite with the provision of day services for older people and activity groups for people with dementia or memory problems. We support Young Carers under 18 with Young Carer clubs and a programme of support in schools. Young Carers may help care for a family member with a long-term illness, physical or sensory impairment, mental health problems or a drug/alcohol addiction. BBC research estimates that 1/5 secondary pupils is a Young Carer. Clubs give Young Carers an opportunity to enjoy being a child in a safe environment with other Young Carers who understand the issues they face. In schools, we help to address the inequality faced by Young Carers where they achieve nine GCSE grades lower than their non-caring peers. We will advocate for a Young Carer with their teacher, perhaps explaining why they have trouble completing homework or getting to school on time, and help them to work out strategies so they can achieve the best possible outcomes. We give transition support to Young Adult Carers as they balance caring with making important life choices including education and employment. We are a Network Partner of Carers Trust and promote our services through their network. We also have agreed ways of working with other voluntary sector organisation such as Age UK and Community Agents. We work with children’s services within the county council and receive referrals from them. We promote our activities and services via our webpage, Facebook, Twitter, local media, presence at community events, CVS offices and via schools and youth groups.

recipientOrganization.name: Age Concern Colchester & North East Essex
recipientOrganization.description: Our Vision Age Concern Colchester supports and empowers people to live better in later life. Our Core Services The core services that we currently provide and that will be positively impacted by the project are: - • Advice – Financial, Mobility, Housing, Care and Health (£1.3m per year in benefit awards delivered last year, on target for between £1.8-£2m this year) • Information and Support – 7,500 phone calls a year providing signposting and direct support o Health and Disability, Legal, Consumer Matters, Care, other signposting o Handyperson services • Befriending (196+ clients being delivered a befriending service in the home, or being matched to a befriender currently) • Friendship groups – this year over 7,000 attendees to 920 clubs. • Free ½ hour legal surgeries with top local solicitors – 70 people supported last year • IT Training / Technology support • Research in conjunction with Essex University to get external review of our projects Our Values • To be held in great trust in whatever we do • To operate with compassion • To bring together community • To strive for excellence across the organisation We have covered the Borough of Colchester since 1950 and since April 2019 we have expanded our operation to support across North East Essex and Witham. Our Advice Service now supports across North East Essex, Befriending North East Essex and Witham. Essentially we find people who are in poverty and who are lonely and we support them to a new place where they can financially survive and reconnect with society through groups and activities focused on Health in Mind, Health in Body, Emotional Support, Information and Education. We have two new services coming on stream which are Dementia support for Tendring and an End of Life Befriending Programme across North East Essex called Compassionate Companions.

grants.title: Grant to Strengths in Communities CIC
grants.description: to supply additional IT equipment to staff and volunteers to support the adaption of their services due to the COVID19 pandemic

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Strengths in Communities CIC
recipientOrganization.description: Skilled peer support during pregnancy, birth and post birth, is life changing for mothers, fathers and babies. Early prevention through the transition to parenthood is at the heart of our work. Evidence is clear - it is a time when people are particularly open to change. Drawing on strengths in communities we nurture the resilience of vulnerable parents during this critical time to achieve the following outcomes: • The best start in life for babies • Resilient parents and communities that are less dependent on limited professional resources Our aim is to establish purposeful, supportive peer relationships during pregnancy that enable volunteers and parents to feel valued, respected, supported and socially connected. By nurturing parents’ resilience (and in turn their babies), we contribute to positive outcomes during the "1001 Critical Days" (UK Cross Party Manifesto). We aim to prevent escalation of need. Our ‘Pregnancy Pal and Birth Buddy’ volunteer programme began in South Essex in 2010 to address a clear gap in support for vulnerable, disadvantaged families. Over the past nine years we have developed a high-quality volunteering initiative that reduces social isolation, helps expectant and new parents prepare for changes ahead, increases resilience, and improves relationships between parents and their infants. We achieve this by building trusting peer relationships, starting in pregnancy, continuing in hospital during labour and birth and ongoing during the early months of parenting. We prioritise communities in Basildon, Thurrock and Canvey Island facing significant social, health and educational inequalities particularly families living in the 10%/20% most deprived postcodes. As well as improving the health, wellbeing and resilience of vulnerable parents, we also aim to make the experience of our volunteer peer supporters deeply rewarding. Our volunteers often describe their involvement as ‘life changing’. Through skilled, regular supervision and extensive training, our volunteers state improved: personal development (86%); knowledge of health issues (71%); self-confidence (71%); and awareness of local services (86%). Volunteers can improve their employability prospects by gaining a level 3 national vocational qualification through our City and Guilds Accreditation Centre. Evidence of learning and skills into practice are derived from the natural volunteer setting. Peer support is provided by volunteers and paid workers. They are trained to focus on parents’ strengths and assets, treat them as equal partners, and avoid dependency by empowering vulnerable parents, communities and families to do more for themselves and their children. A Pregnancy Pal or Birth Buddy is “someone in their corner” providing flexible, personalised support throughout pregnancy, labour and birth and the early months of being a parent. Drawing on lived experience or shared characteristics our peer supporters aim to provide knowledge, emotional support, practical help and social interaction. Their strengths-based, non-judgemental approach enables them to build trusting relationships with vulnerable women who may be wary of professionals. We provide the following activities: 1. Intensive one-to-one peer support (home, hospital, community) to vulnerable women and their partners (early pregnancy to 6 months post birth, over 120 families a year, up to 2-hours a week) provided by thoroughly trained and supervised volunteers and paid staff. Parents are encouraged to set and review self-selected achievable goals. For very vulnerable women our birth buddies provide emotional and practical support throughout labour and birth. 2. Weekly community outreach activities to meet pregnant women face-to-face (2-3 hours per session, 10 disadvantaged locations). These take place in GP and children’s centre antenatal clinics, Essex Youth Services, homeless hostels, Thorney Bay Caravan Park in Canvey Island, and women’s refuges. We provide supported signposting and opportunities for pregnant or post birth women to request one-to-one peer support. We set-up information stands at Basildon maternity unit (weekly). Each year, we engage with over 1200 expectant parents via these activities. 3. Antenatal and postnatal exercise and wellbeing sessions (100 women each year). A qualified perinatal fitness trainer and health promotion specialist runs weekly 2-hour sessions in 3 disadvantaged locations (Laindon, Vange, Canvey). Each session is followed by an informal talk about pregnancy and parenthood. Attendees make connections and continue exercising together at the end of the programme. We support them to set up their own buggy walks. 4. Workshops for expectant fathers (2-hours, twice a month in Grays and Basildon): delivered by experienced and qualified antenatal teachers. Topics include: how to support their partner during labour; preparing for changes ahead (e.g. family relationships, mental health); and practical baby-care. 5. Informal groups for pregnant women to meet each other: delivered in Family Hubs (7 disadvantaged locations where there is no provision, 2-hours, monthly basis). These are informal information sessions with simple quizzes about labour and birth; keeping well; and becoming a parent. We encourage new friendships that continue beyond the sessions. 6. Video Interaction Guidance during home visits to parents at risk of poor bonding with their babies (20 parents a year). By sharing positive video clips for parents to reflect on, we nurture attuned early parent-infant relationships. 7. Recruiting, training and supervising volunteers (maintaining an ongoing pool of 30 volunteers): we deliver free four-week taster courses each year (total of 12 hours) that enable local parents to gain new skills, build confidence and find out whether being a Pregnancy Pal or Birth Buddy is right for them. Those recruited to become volunteers attend high quality training (76 hours) and induction that prepares them to carry out the role and receive ongoing one-to-one supervision and peer group meetings (monthly basis). We work particularly closely with community midwives who regularly refer vulnerable pregnant women. A programme manager, a volunteer coordinator and a trainer operate the programme carrying out volunteer recruitment, collaboration with professionals, introductory visits to pregnant women in their homes, matching volunteers to pregnant women’s’ needs, safeguarding, regular volunteer supervision, risk assessments, and ongoing evaluation.

recipientOrganization.name: Basildon, Billericay & Wickford CVS
recipientOrganization.description: Basildon, Billericay and Wickford Council for Voluntary Service (BBWCVS) was formed in October 1979 as an independent registered charity that exists to promote, develop, support and represent a thriving, effective, voluntary and community sector in the borough. We do this by providing a range of services to meet the needs of voluntary and community organisations, helping those that are starting up as well as organisations that are already established. We also support joint working between voluntary and community organisations, with business, and the statutory sector, and help to make sure the interests and concerns of the VCS are well represented. We support all types and sizes of voluntary and community organisations (VCOs), charities and social enterprises in five different ways. Support Services Helping voluntary and community organisations to set up and build their organisation’s capacity. By providing funding advice and support. Facilitating access to training, workshops and other learning opportunities. Providing information and guidance, newsletters and electronic news bulletins. Administering a small grants programme. By enabling local VCS organisations access discount services such as NAVCA essentials. Development Work Identifying local needs. Working with others to develop appropriate actions. Representing and Influencing Representing the views of the VCS to statutory partners through consultation, networking and acting as a link between the VCS, the public sector and the private sector. Promoting and campaigning for the interests of the VCS to help maintain a strong and independent sector. Promoting participation in voluntary and community action. Liaison (Networking and involving) Creating and supporting forums, networks and working groups to help VCOs to work together to share information and best practice. Supporting the voluntary and community sector to be involved and engaged with various statutory bodies, groups and partnerships to influence local plans and decision making BBWCVS hosts the Basildon Volunteer Centre which provides a volunteer recruitment, placement and support service to residents and voluntary and community organisations.

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Voluntary Action Epping Forest
recipientOrganization.description: Voluntary Action Epping Forest (VAEF), operational since 1993 is an independent membership based charity, our mission is to work with the people of Epping Forest District and Harlow District to empower, support and develop voluntary and community activity. As an umbrella organisation we develop new initiatives to meet community needs and promote cooperation between the voluntary and statutory sectors. We offer a range of practical support, including advice on funding, help with running a voluntary organisation and provide a comprehensive Volunteer Service to help local people access volunteering opportunities. We also run a diverse range of community projects, these include: Community Handyman Service - providing a Handyperson to complete odd jobs in vulnerable peoples homes, keeping them safe by fitting anti falls equipment and home security features in addition to jobs such as fitting curtain rails, repairing doors, fitting new shelves or simply changing a light bulb and much more. A number of other services we provide for isolated residents in Epping Forest include Benefits Advice, Befriending, Volunteer Centre, Ace Activities – Support for people with learning disabilities and Gardening. The VAEF Handyperson service that VAEF provides is for elderly and vulnerable residents in Epping Forest looking for support in the home for odd jobs which they are unable to complete themselves. This service is a chargeable one, however it is provided to elderly and vulnerable people in the Epping Forest District and is subsidised by VAEF who are not making a profit from any work carried out. This work ensures that service users are safer and less exposed to crime in their homes. This service is available to elderly / vulnerable residents of Epping Forest on low incomes and also to those who have experienced domestic violence or been victims of crime. Residents who have used the service feel safer and more secure at home following our work and the additional security we provide and fit.

grants.title: Grant to Age UK - Essex
grants.description: towards the operational costs of supporting the increase in referrals from elderly people isolating across Essex during COVID19

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Age UK - Essex
recipientOrganization.description: At Age UK Essex we aim to promote the wellbeing of all older people in Essex and be there to support people to live fulfilling and enjoyable lives. We believe in a society in which people in later life from all communities have equal access to services, where they are free from discrimination and their human rights are promoted and protected. Age UK Essex has achieved the Age UK Charity National Quality Standard (CQS). The CQS is externally assessed by quality assessment experts SGS. Our services are listed below and operate at a countywide level Countywide Befriending Service Home/Telephone (free service) Our Countywide Befriending Service offers companionship through a weekly home visit or phone call. It’s the perfect opportunity for clients to relax in their own home and have a catch up over a cup of tea with one of our screened and trained volunteer befrienders. The aim of the service is to help alleviate the debilitating effects of loneliness and/or social isolation. With people now living longer, this is growing problem with demand increasing across all parts of Essex, Thurrock and Southend. Home Help Service The service has been designed to help older people to live independently and remain in their own homes for longer. and aims to provide practical and emotional support as listed below. Dusting and polishing furniture Cleaning baths, sinks and toilets Washing floors Laundry Changing beds Emptying rubbish bins. Shopping Collecting weekly shopping from the local supermarket Accompanied shopping Collecting prescriptions. Food Preparation Service Outdoor Activity Support Sitting and Companionship Service Toenail Cutting Service The service gives people the chance to have their toenails trimmed by fully trained staff in a friendly and welcoming environment. We hold regular toenail cutting clinics at over 100 easily-accessible venues throughout Essex and we also offer home visits if they find it hard to get out and about. All of our toenail trimmers are trained and assessed by the NHS podiatry service and our Home Visiting service is CQC registered. The service operates every six to eight weeks and helps clients to benefit from the following To remain mobile To avoid becoming isolated and housebound To reduce the likelihood of having a fall To avoid the general discomfort which accompanies long toenails. To help with remaining independant for as long as possible and enhance quality of life Information & Advice Service The Age UK Essex Information and Advice service is a free, impartial and confidential advice service for anyone aged 50 or over, their friends, family, professionals and carers. The service makes asking for help easy. Our team of professional advisors are only a phone call away and are fully trained to offer help and advice on a huge range of issues that affect older people. Our advisors can help people confidently navigate some of the most difficult questions and situations that arise in later life and are experts in giving the support needed. Some of the most common enquires are listed below; Benefits entitlement Housing issues Social care Legal - advisors can provide information about making a will, dealing with an estate or make financial and Welfare decisions Bereavement support Voice Network It's really important that older people in Essex know where to go if they need help and who they can turn to for support. Our Voice Network share information on local services and give older people a voice within their community. Visiting clubs and groups across the county, the Voice Network's team of specially trained volunteers go out and about to give talks about the services and facilities available for older people in their local area. They also help older people get their opinions heard by gathering their views and feeding them back to the local authority and key decision makers. The Voice Network operates across Essex including Southend and Thurrock and also visits organisations such as housing associations, carers groups, GP surgeries, patient groups and other charities. Advocacy Service (In House) Our Advocacy Service operates on a small scale and will support any clients using any our services. The service is managed by our Head of Service for Information & Advice who is also a fully qualified Advocate, providing confidential advice and supporting the most vulnerable members of our society to access information and services. Trading Our Trading subsidiary contributes vital unrestricted income to help fund our services to older people in Essex. It's team of expert arrangers help customers to access products and services, Home Insurance, Motor Insurance, Motor Breakdown, Funeral Plans and Personal Alarms.

(Age range from pre birth to 104) CAVS' core service is the provision of support and promotion for the voluntary action and has a membership of over 350 local groups. The range of services include advice/guidance around structure, governance and finance. We provide up to date bulletins of local news, activity, events and networking opportunities, as well as hosting several annual community partnership events. CAVS operates a number of Schemes, vital for the local community and surrounding areas including: Befriending - 1,000 volunteers matched with isolated and lonely people since inception. Ways to Wellness - 1,500 people in the past three years supported, providing advice and guidance and signposting to appropriate services. Family Mentoring - Supporting families on a one to one basis who are vulnerable and often in distress. Reablement - This service has assisted 370 people in three years who wish to remain in their home having returned from long term care in hospital. Essex Children and Young Peoples Service - Supporting young people to make positive lifestyle choices.

recipientOrganization.name: Project Factory CIC
recipientOrganization.description: Project Factory CIC wants to help grow a cohesive and resilient community by building engagement, celebrating diversity and opening potential. It will draw on existing local assets and resources and develop the current provision by expanding the networks to form partnerships and collaborations across the community and the local area. New projects are already emerging that Project Factory is being asked to support by either leading the delivery or supporting the partnerships necessary to ensure success. Project Factory’s long-term aims include the creation of a hub where it can facilitate both individual and collaborative enterprise, drive opportunities for personal development and skill sharing and embrace a diverse community to promote well-being, bridge differences and develop a mindset that helps build a strong, connected community. The work is multi-faceted and ambitious - on the one hand, Project Factory listens; it starts conversations; it builds partnerships; it grows networks; it encourages collaboration; it communicates - on the other, it delivers informal education opportunities to grow confidence and develop skills; it holds forums and conferences to build consensus; it holds community events to inspire and create joy. It responds to the emerging ideas and ‘seeds’ and works to help organisations and individuals develop their own projects. Project Factory believes in the value of listening and curiosity, the power of experiential learning, the importance of story and playfulness, the potential that lies in unique skills and gifts inherent in each member of the community- which is evoked through connection, collaboration, communication and celebration.

recipientOrganization.name: Personal Independence Support CIC
recipientOrganization.description: Personal Independence (PI) is a not for profit organisation (CIC), founded in 2010 to reduce the number of young people becoming excluded from mainstream society and entering into criminal and unhealthy lifestyles. To effectively drive social change and reduce youth violence and conflict in the community, PICIC deliver its BootCamp in direct partnership with law enforcement, local authorities and education services. Since 2015 the CIC has been working within four London boroughs, funded by the Home Office, The Met, Schools, Local Authorities, Trusts and Housing Associations. The CIC operates from its headquarters in Reigate and Banstead and is in the final stages of establishing an alternative education provision in Surrey. The aim is to now extend outreach work in to Surrey too. BootCamp is PICIC’s foundational offering. Other programmes are designed to build on learnings from BootCamp and are selected on the basis of group’s needs. Follow-on programmes include; Healthy Sexual Behaviour Programme – Male & Female, Anti-Crime Behaviour Programme, Residential Nurture Camp, and Challenging & Identifying Negative Behaviour Programme.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Mental wellbeing
grants.description: Costs towards a charity supporting grieving parents in Surrey effected by the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: Surrey Sands
recipientOrganization.description: Established in 1983, the registered charity, Sands (standing for Stillbirth And Neonatal Death Society) is a national self-help organisation, established to support anyone affected by the death of a baby. The charity is divided into a network of local groups, of which Surrey Sands is one. The aim is to reduce the isolation caused by this misunderstood and lifelong grief. The local Surrey group is run entirely by volunteers, all of whom are bereaved parents, enabling them to offer empathic support to other families of babies who have died during pregnancy, at or around the time of birth or within the first few weeks of life. Volunteers have also undergone the Sands befriender training programme in order to act as befrienders. Surrey Sands is managed by a committee of 5, with an additional 20 volunteers and helpers. Surrey Sands provides one-to-one, group and online support via its trained volunteers on a daily and monthly basis; as well as operating a website, twice yearly newsletter, literature, 3 memorial services a year and memorial gardens. Support starts with the provision of hospital bereavement suites, through to long-term aftercare for as long as parents require. The aim is to help families rebuild their life, learning to live whilst grieving and create their new normal. The group also work to raise awareness of baby loss and to train healthcare professionals in the unique needs of parents at their point of loss.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities

recipientOrganization.name: Dramatize Theatre Company
recipientOrganization.description: Dramatize consists of both a registered charity and a CIC working in conjunction providing “theatre workshops, including dancing, singing, drama and dance movement therapy classes for adults with learning disabilities and special needs”. The charity was first established in January 2003 under the name of the Holly & Chloe School of Dance and had the objects of giving relief, education and a leisure activity to local children with disabilities by the provision of therapeutic and educational exercises through the medium of dance. These aims were later changed to encompass adult services, and the name of the charity was also changed in August 2011 when Dramatize Charity Trust was established. However, two of the Trustees who established the original charity have remained engaged. The CIC was established in October 2012 in order to operate the Theatrical Day Service from Ashford Pavilion in Ashford Park. Although the primary focus is adults (18+) with disabilities, Dramarize also offers a range of workshops for young people, as it wishes to be all encompassing in its goal of bringing empowerment to its service users by enabling them to develop professionally and personally. Dramatize works with individuals with learning disabilities ranging from mild to profound. A range of activities are provided which will broaden students’ knowledge and provide a form of respite for parents/carers. The Dramatize club offers offer a safe, supportive, and secure environment in which individuals enjoy a range of activities including drama, arts, sports and community outings. Dramatize employs 2 full-time and 6 part-time staff members, who are supported by 5 volunteers and a management committee of 5 Trustees.

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Michael Roberts Charitable Trust
recipientOrganization.description: As a Harlow based charity our aims and objectives are to develop voluntary work and social opportunities for people who are often perceived as being disadvantaged, either through a disability or social difficulty. • Providing inclusive drop-in centres for adults with a range of abilities / disabilities • Providing an emergency non-perishable food service for people in crisis and a fresh food service to front-line care professionals • Promoting a team philosophy – together everybody achieves more • Promoting the ability of all people – encouraging social inclusion Since the formation of the charity in 1997 MRCT has sought to involve people with a disability and socially disadvantaged people in all aspects of its work, promoting the value and significance of each person as an individual, encouraging them to take an active role in decision-making and future planning. Our key aim is the inclusion of all people, irrespective of social status, ability, disability, age, ethnic grouping or religious belief. This work includes: • Maybury Open Door – Adult drop-in centre based at two church locations in Harlow and open 3 days a week. • Harlow Foodbank – Proving emergency non-perishable food for people in crisis in Harlow and the surrounding area. • Bounty Club – Surplus fresh food is donated by local companies and distributed to front-line care professionals, charities, organisations, schools and homeless projects for the benefit of the community. * Stansted Airport Partnership - Recycling passengers surrendered / restricted non-perishable food, soft drinks, toiletries and gifts to front-line care professionals, charities, organisations, schools and homeless projects for the benefit of the community. Poundland Partnership - working with the Poundland Distribution Centre in Harlow who provide the foodbank with a range of non-perishable food, toiletries and household items. * St Margaret's Hospital Partnership - Currently working in partnership with St Margaret's hospital in Epping providing emergency food boxes for elderly patients leaving hospital with no family support. Country Food Trust - provides the foodbank with partridge and pheasant sachet food

recipientOrganization.name: Tendring Rural South Neighbourhood Action Panel
recipientOrganization.description: We are a community group who work closely with Essex Police and other partners to promote community safety. Our aim is to engage with people and organisations across the Tendring area (mainly to the south of the district)and to implement projects that reduce crime, improve safety - especially road safety. We meet regularly with the police and hold public meetings - from our discussions we focus on problems and try to find solutions. We have helped set up Youth Clubs and events, organised road safety campaigns and have provided specialist equipment to help combat crime. We help direct resources to where they are needed and our volunteers give hands on help to many community projects. We work with the Essex Probation service and British Transport Police and have representatives on our panel from local businesses, Parish and Town Councils, The District Council, Youth Work and local residents.

grants.title: Grant to Supporting Carers and Families Together
grants.description: to purchase laptop computers and meet additional costs involved in responding to the COVID19 pandemic and helping to sustain an organisation supporting vulnerable young carers in the Rochford area

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Supporting Carers and Families Together
recipientOrganization.description: To relieve the social, emotional, physical and educational needs of carers and their families living in Essex, particularly the Rochford District, where most of our services are targeted. This is achieved through group centered support sessions, one to one support including advocacy as required along with providing a range of information relevant to the needs of carers including national and local policy change and benefit changes and review, advice including information about additional support services, training to improve the ability to care and ensure their own wellbeing is also provided for, along with a number of days out and other activities, including family days for the whole family to participate and spent quality time together. SCAFT supports young carers aged 6 -18 years through group sessions and activities, as well as individual one to one work. Group session provide a safe, understanding environment for young carers to take a few hours respite from their caring responsibilities offering fun games and sports, creative and craft activities, informal and formal learning and days out. For many of our young carers it might be one of the few breaks they get from their caring role and gives them a valuable opportunity to share with others in a similar situation, tackling the social isolation felt by many carers. The One2One service operates through the districts schools, providing weekly or fortnightly individual opportunities to express their anxieties and concerns about their caring role, gain advice and signposting to additional services. The weekly Support Workers visits to schools also provide a chance for staff to consult on the best ways to offer students with caring responsibilities additional support and our staff have been closely involved in assisting schools working towards nationally recognised 'Young Carers in Schools' Awards. The schools support work is currently active in 3 out of the 4 secondary schools in the district and 5 primary schools, with a further 3 primary schools expected to join the scheme at the start of the new school year. SCAFT has also recently championed the introduction of Young Carers Passports to the secondary schools it works with; the scheme is designed to give schools an opportunity to help identify and recognise the caring responsibilities held by young carers; as well as a way of affirming their support to these students. The scheme also gives young carers a visual record of the concessions given to them by the school in terms of additional support; and means that they don’t have to explain their story to each individual member of staff in order to access those support mechanisms. It gives staff reassurance that a student claiming access to a support strategy has the entitlement to do so and that their circumstances and needs have been assessed by the Young Carers Lead. The passport is designed to be personalised to each school and to be tailored to individual student needs. Like a real passport ‘visa stamps’ can be added to show the particular entitlements of the holder. e.g. that they may register late or leave early, that they may need extra time to complete homework, may need access to a phone to check the situation at home is stable, may need to be excused from afternoon detentions or may need time-out from class to compose themselves if they become distracted or distressed.

grants.title: Grant to Waltham Abbey Youth 2000
grants.description: to cover additional costs for a counsellor at a youth organisation to increase her working hours until the end of June in response to the COVID19 pandemic

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Improve life skills, education, employability and enterprise

recipientOrganization.name: Waltham Abbey Youth 2000
recipientOrganization.description: Waltham Abbey is a town of considerable deprivation. One of the 4 wards in the town is the 3rd most deprived area in Essex. It suffers from broken families, low educational attainment, youth crime and unemployment. A considerable percentage of the District’s NEET’s live in the town. The sole local secondary school receives Pupil Premium for over 30% of its pupils to close the gap between disadvantaged and non-disadvantaged young people. Waltham Abbey Youth 2000 (WAY 2000) provides a community resource and seeks to improve sporting, leisure, cultural, education and employment opportunities for the young people of Waltham Abbey. We believe that all our young people deserve a safe and healthy environment, should have facilities which enable them to make gainful use of their leisure time, should understand their duties and responsibilities both to themselves and the community at large and take responsibility for their own actions. WAY2000 is committed to supporting and realising these aspirations by providing a safe, attractive and affordable social environment with a choice of opportunities together with a counselling service. We provide a wide range of quality facilities and opportunities at our youth centre for 2 age ranges: Yip Yop Youth for 7 to 11 year olds and New Images for school years 7 to 11. There is a wide variety of activities at the centre including table tennis, table football, air hockey, games consoles e.g. Xbox, Wii, PS3 etc. Arts and Crafts and a computer suite. These facilities encourage children and young people to interact and socialise with their peers in person rather than sit at home on their mobile phones etc. Various one off activities are organised during the holidays including an Activity Day at Stubbers Adventure Centre, Dodgeball Sessions, visit to the Fire Station etc. WAY2COOK our very popular cookery club focusing on healthy eating and balanced diets is due to be re-opened shortly having now raised sufficient funding to cover costs. Whilst this facility is restricted due to the kitchen space, it has attracted a wide variety of young people including sufferers of aspergers syndrome and autism who mix well with the other participants. The facility was set up in 2013 following a very successful cookery session run by Epping Forest District Council as part of their Summer Programme and following statistics issued by Essex County Council shortly afterwards highlighting an obesity issue amongst the young people of Waltham Abbey. Recipes include burgers etc. but these are made with very low fat meat and are a healthy version. They are always enjoyed by the young people. In addition to the wide variety of activities & leisure facilities provided at our youth centre in Brooker Road, we run a highly acclaimed Counselling Service. WAY Forward Counselling seeks to improve emotional well-being and/or mental health amongst vulnerable young people aged 11-18, with family members if appropriate, together with group work involving younger children to improve self-esteem and self-confidence to lead to improved attainment and ambition for the future and to prevent them from spiralling downwards into self-harming actions, drugs and criminal activities. Having involved parents and family members for some years, with the feedback from them, it is clear that parents realise that there is something causing their child anxiety but do not know how to deal with it. Many contact our counsellor because they feel that CAMHS do not understand their needs. They cannot get help from the local health centre as it has no provision for mental health services for young people and they also make referrals to our counsellor recognising the impact it has on the young peoples' wellbeing and lives . All of this has resulted in us providing a Parent Drop-In facility at our centre to enable parents to come and chat about issues they are experiencing with their children. We now provide this on a weekly basis to meet a much higher demand than was originally anticipated and have developed it to include a variety of activities encouraging relaxation in addition to the counselling and advisory service. The Parent Drop-In facility has highlighted that the parents are experiencing personal issues such as partnership splits and domestic violence which are having a detrimental effect on the children and young people in the families. Our Counsellor helps them cope with their situations and is able to signpost the parents to other organisations who can help and advise with issues such as finance and housing. Numerous young people are tell our Counsellor that they have nowhere quiet at home where they can complete their homework. This means that they fall behind with their lessons, fail exams and their futures are ruined. As a result of this we are now developing a Homework Club. Mental Health issues amongst young people and the lack of support for them is currently headline news. It was recently reported that more than half of prisoners had been excluded from school at some point. Our Counsellor’s work at King Harold Academy, the sole secondary school in the town, has been recognised as improving classroom behaviour and unauthorised absences which otherwise would often lead to exlcusion. Our facility helps to prevent this situation in Waltham Abbey. We have been providing these services for 25 years and continually develop them to meet the needs and aspirations of the young people in the community. Hundreds of young people have benefited resulting in them achieving more academically than they originally expected and giving them greatly improved life chances rather than ending up homeless living on the streets, on drugs or involved in criminal activities as a way of escapism. The value of the facilities and services WAY2000 provides for the benefit of the community is recognised by Waltham Abbey Town Council and Epping Forest District Council who support the Charity in a variety of ways. WAY 2000 is one of the charities based in Essex to be nominated for a Queen's Award for Voluntary Service in recognition of the value of our facilities and the services we provide..

grants.title: Grant to South Essex Advocacy Services
grants.description: towards the staff costs of an organisation providing advocacy and emergency response provision to older people and those with a disability in Southend, Rayleigh and Rochford during COVID19

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

recipientOrganization.name: South Essex Advocacy Services
recipientOrganization.description: South Essex Advocacy Services (SEAS) was formerly known as South East Essex Advocacy for Older People since forming in 1994. Our name changed in 2017 to enable us to provide advocacy services to all people across the whole of south Essex. Advocacy is perhaps one of the most overlooked services that aim to improve the lives of vulnerable people. Our provision ensures that people can voice their own concerns and wishes regarding their healthcare, accommodation, finances and welfare. Our service users include: • People with mental health problems • Older people • People with learning disabilities • People who lack mental capacity • People experiencing financial abuse • People living in poverty We support in excess of 2,000 people each year to: • Understand and participate in decisions about their care and treatment under the Mental Health Act 1983. • Maximise their entitled benefits, so that they can afford the care and support to which they are entitled. • Communicate their healthcare and accommodation wishes to professionals and family. • Understand their personal budget and reduce their debts. • Reduce anxiety and social isolation and improve their confidence, mental and emotional wellbeing and quality of life. • Safeguarding them against further financial abuse and recover their lost finances. We employ qualified advocates to deliver our service across south Essex and we are supported by a team of volunteers. We are contracted by Southend Borough Council to deliver advocacy services under the Care Act, but there are many more vulnerable and isolated people in our local area who do not fulfil the Care Act criteria, but still desperately need someone to speak on their behalf. These people will not have Social Services involvement, yet they still require support to make their voice heard and to reach decisions regarding their needs. These people may be older, have difficulty communicating or struggle with their literacy and comprehension skills. They may have a long-term health condition or have difficulties with their accommodation provider. Without our support, they will struggle to reach positive outcomes and to make positive changes in their lives to improve their wellbeing, health and living conditions. We deliver our services within our office in Southend, in various community Hubs and at people’s homes (particularly if they are bed-bound or would struggle to get to our office).

recipientOrganization.description: We have set up the Wilton and Sherford Community Interest Company to open a pop up shop in Wilton and Sherford, Taunton. Operating from Middleway Meeting Hall, this will provide basic groceries and provisions to a large population (2,000 in Wilton and Sherford and 2,000 in Manor and Parkfield) who currently have NO access whatsoever to local amenities There is no local shop here and the nearest is a large Tesco with 3 hour queues. The age profile here is older than most and our volunteers need access to a local shop to provide elderly with food

recipientOrganization.name: Purple Elephant Productions CIC
recipientOrganization.description: Purple Elephant is a small non-profit organisation which runs projects for children, young people and families in Frome and the local area. Our overall aims are to support social inclusion and integration, helping to develop a more supportive community. Within this aim we focus on supporting disadvantaged children and families, and those with additional needs, often in partnership with other organisations. Our projects are always free or low cost to attend and include annual events such as Frome Children's Festival and family support services including the Toy Library and Family Holiday Fun (activities in each school holiday).

recipientOrganization.name: Southend Association of Voluntary Services
recipientOrganization.description: Southend Association of Voluntary Services (SAVS) is the Council for Voluntary Services in Southend that provides support to the voluntary and community sector in Southend. The organisation has the following core functions: -Development - identifying local need and working with others to develop appropriate action -Representation - ensuring the local voluntary sector are able to present its views to other sectors -Liaison - creating links between the voluntary sector and other sectors -Strategic partnerships - enabling the voluntary sector to partner work with other agencies to provide solutions to specific issues -Support - providing the voluntary sector with a range of support such as information and funding advice. Our core work which supports over 400 member organisations sees our team work with over 150 organisations annually. In the last year we have worked with 72 new and emerging groups who seek to deliver a range of outcomes to support those living and working in Southend. We provide specific support around governance (including legal registration and how to establish a trustee board), policies and procedures, funding (including searches for funders and support with applications). In 2017-18 we support organisations to realise £2.5m in grant income, or which a quarter of a million went to new and emerging groups. We also provide training to these groups especially around grant applications to build their skills and future sustainability in delivering their future work. In 2019 SAVS carried out a dragon’s den workshop where 10 small Southend groups prepared a pitch for funding to 3 dragons. Although no real money was awarded, advice and post-event 1:1 support was provided to each group. 90% of the organisations who took part have gone on to apply and be successful in gaining a total of over £100k in funds for their activities as a result of the training.

recipientOrganization.description: Citizens Advice Harlow has been serving the the community since 1956. We are here to give people the knowledge and the confidence they need to find their way forward - whoever they are, and whatever their problem. We offer free independant, confidential and impartial advice 5 days per week. This covers benefits, debt, housing, employment to name a few. We also offer specialist Law Clinics and free legal advice as part of our blended offer of advice. We deliver an outreach well as the Permitted Development Housing site at Templefields in Harlow.

recipientOrganization.description: bibic supports vulnerable children and young people with a range of disabilities, difficulties and conditions through holistic therapy programmes.  We are now unable to deliver any services at our National Centre or in the family home and, at the same time, the impact of the pandemic on bibic families has been profound. Parents are reporting that children are experiencing increased anxiety, frustration and challenging behaviours (e.g. aggression, self harm, meltdowns). Parents feel on the brink of being unable to cope. Simultaneously, bibic face a 50% drop in income and severe financial risk.

recipientOrganization.name: Southend Foodbank
recipientOrganization.description: Southend Foodbank was established in 2013 by a group of local churches to provide emergency food parcels and additional support services for people living in poverty in Southend. We are part of a national network of foodbanks supported by the Trussell Trust, working to combat poverty and hunger across the UK. We issue food parcels and additional items (such as toiletries) to people referred to us by local professional agencies who have been identified as being in an emergency or crisis situation. This includes families on low incomes, people in debt, people who are homeless or vulnerably housed and, most commonly, families who are experiencing delays in their benefits payments. We have seven distribution centres across Southend, and we distribute in excess of 3,000 food parcels each year. Our foodbank operates throughout the year, Monday to Saturday, only closing on bank holidays.

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: City of Chelmsford Mencap
recipientOrganization.description: Aims: To provide services offering learning and recreational opportunities to children and young people with a learning disability. To provide lifelong learning, social opportunities and community access to people aged 19+ who have a learning disability and associated additional needs. To promote a healthy, independent lifestyle to people with a learning disability and to signpost/refer to, and liaise with, health and social care agencies as appropriate. To provide support to members and their families about different aspects of living with learning disabilities, and to develop new services and courses in response to identified needs. To promote the needs and abilities of people with a learning disability through awareness campaigns and by publicising the activities and achievements of service users. Services: Family Support Worker helps with issues including social care funding and provision, benefits and housing. The Outreach Academy: wide range of structured learning courses, from Functional skills to Yoga, to help students develop and maintain life, work and social skills. Open five days a week, fifty weeks a year, to ensure it provides a regular and constant service. Active in the community and environment (ACE): volunteering in community horticulture and hospitality projects. Working out: long-term, fully supported, work experience placements. Social clubs: Gateway Juniors for 16 to 25 year olds; and Gateway Club for members over 19. These clubs provide a range of workshops and themed evenings, including dance, drama, sport and art, and opportunities to enjoy facilities in the community, including theatre trips, dining out and bowling.

recipientOrganization.name: Wellbeing 4 Life CIC
recipientOrganization.description: Motivated Minds is a lifelong wellbeing provider supporting residents across Basildon Borough/South Essex with their wellbeing. Our aim is to raise awareness and create a positive conversation around mental health and give people hope, as well tools to manage their health. We work across the life span and empower people to take control of their wellbeing, meaning that they can realise their own abilities, can cope with the normal stresses of life, can work productively and fruitfully, and is able to make a contribution to their community. Working across the lifespan gives us an opportunity to offer early intervention and work with different generations within families. Our organisation was founded and has been developed by people who had/have struggled with mental ill health but have gone on to undertake formal qualifications in mental health / psychology / counselling. Our initial aim was to create an informal service that would offer support to the community. Over the past four years we have now built a seven day service around the 5 ways to wellbeing.

recipientOrganization.name: West Somerset Railway Association (WSRA)
recipientOrganization.description: The West Somerset Railway is a 23-mile long steam heritage railway running through the heart of West Somerset. Started in 1871 the railway is one of the largest tourist attractions in the area bringing around 200,000 visitors each year. The organisation has become an integral part of the wider local community, providing employment and volunteering opportunities and boosting the local economy through tourism. Our services have closed entirely due to the Covid-19 pandemic - we are particularly concerned about our team of 1,200 volunteers, many of whom are elderly and self isolating and consequently at risk of loneliness and distress.
