grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Food and Essentials
grants.description: Funding toward the increase in demand for a foodbank service that is based in Caterham, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Caterham Foodbank
recipientOrganization.description: Caterham Foodbank was established in July 2013 as a volunteer initiative based at Caterham Baptist Church, to provide emergency food relief to those in need within the local area. There are approximately 70 local volunteers engaged in the initiative, including representatives from ten local churches. The group is being overseen by a committee of four individuals, who have made an application to the Charity Commission to establish as a Charitable Incorporated Organisation (CIO); the outcome of this application is anticipated very shortly. In the meantime, a Constitution document has been prepared, based upon the model template. An independent bank account is also due to be established, with all funds received to date being held as restricted funds within the Baptist Church. The group is registered with the Trussell Trust and is due to open its doors on Monday 25th November 2013, providing support to those in need, who shall be referred by local agencies. Donated food items are stored in a garage facility at the rear of the church and the intention is to set up a small café area within the chapel, from which tea and toast will be provided to people while they wait to collect their food parcel. Volunteers will also provide a listening ear, and will have the ability to refer individuals on to specialised support and advice, for example a local job club or debt agency.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Families with Young Children
grants.description: Funding toward the essential running costs of an organisation, based in Elmbridge, that offers budgeting support to families that have low incomes, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Oasis Childcare Centre (Oasis)
recipientOrganization.description: Oasis Childcare Centre (Oasis) is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee. Oasis was established in 1996 to support vulnerable families in Elmbridge across all social circles. The centre aims to provide a safe haven for under-privileged children. Oasis works with over 200 families per year and with families where there are often years of unresolved family issues such as abuse, hardship, and with low levels of self-esteem. Support includes a drop-in centre, a crèche for families struggling with childcare or needing additional support, and a weekly parents group offering access to professional counsellors and advice (financial, legal, health, housing and social services advice). Oasis also provides courses on parenting, money management, domestic violence, IT, self-confidence, and healthy-living. The charity is firmly established in premises in Cobham, with a long-term tenancy agreement. In recent years Oasis has had to expand services to meet the growing needs of the local community and to fill the gap left by SCC, who have been assessed as inadequate by Ofsted for the past 12 years. This has meant that the cases picked up by charities like Oasis have grown in number, and in complexity.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: Funding toward the essential running costs of a charity, based in East Surrey, that supports adults with learning difficulties, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Bloomin' Arts
recipientOrganization.description: Bloomin’ Arts (BA) was established in 1997 and aims to provide accessible opportunities for participation and education in performing arts for adults with learning disabilities, who live in Surrey and the surrounding areas. BA is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee. BA runs a number of different activities and courses, the majority of which take place at the charity’s premises in Lingfield, at which they have resided for the last 6 years. The premises is rented by the charity, with the rent renewed yearly in September. The charity aims to offer the opportunity to progress from participant to practitioner in the Arts. The Arts Apprenticeships offer participants the opportunity to develop skills and strengths, with the objective of training for work. The charity also runs a Monday Drama club, Wednesday Music club, Musical Theatre club, and Dance club. The group has produced performances in several local theatres and at Arts Festivals. Recently BA also started a touring theatre company made up of people who have accessed courses in the past, who go out into schools across Surrey. Clients are involved in the whole creative process. BA is supported by a Board of 5 Trustees who are active in supporting the one full-time member of staff - the charity’s General Manager/Arts Practitioner. There are a further 4 part-time Freelance Associates who facilitate art, drama and music sessions, invoicing the group on a sessional basis. The charity is supported by 12 volunteers.

grants.title: COVID-19 Response - Sexual Abuse
grants.description: Funding toward a charity that supports those who have suffered from rape and sexual abuse, based in Guildford, to convert their service from face to face to a work from home and online set up, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: RASASC Guildford
recipientOrganization.description: Established in 1992, the Rape and Sexual Abuse Support Centre (RASASC) Guildford is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee. The charity's stated objects are "to relieve the distress of people who have suffered sexual assault and to educate the public in the problems of sexual abuse". RASASC supports male and female survivors of rape and sexual abuse in Surrey. Services include a confidential crisis helpline, as well as counselling on an individual or family basis. Specific court support and counselling is also provided, teaching coping strategies, how to manage emotions while being cross-examined, and coping with a guilty or not-guilty verdict in court. Awareness raising is also a large part of the charity's activities. Approximately 200 calls are received to the charity’s helpline per month, with callers being nationwide. The charity’s volunteer counsellors are each supporting up to 3 people per week, with individuals travelling to the charity’s Guildford base from across Surrey, mainly West of the county. However, recently RASASC opened a Hub in Leatherhead so that counselling is more accessible to those in need in the North of the County. The charity employs one full time and 11 part-time members of staff, including a Crisis Councillor who specialises in recent trauma and a specialist Family Support Counsellor. There are 2 full-time staff. The charity is governed by a Board of 6 Trustees and supported by 67 volunteers.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Advice and support
grants.description: Funding toward enabling employees of a debt advice service, based in Reigate and Banstead, to set up and work at home and the extra salary costs of working overtime, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Community Debt Advice (CDA)
recipientOrganization.description: Community Debt Advice (CDA) was established in 2007 and is based in Redhill. It provides a free, professional, client-centred and face-to-face money advice service. CDA reaches out and helps people with money problems in the local community of Redhill, Reigate and Merstham. People who are particularly supported include those on benefits, low incomes and/or with health difficulties. CDA operates under the umbrella organisation Community Money Advice, and is also a member of Advice UK. The Citizen’s Advice Bureau also provide support to CDA in complex cases. CDA is not a charity but is an  independent project within RRCC (Redhill and Reigate Community Church, now known as Christ Central) which is a registered charity governed by 7 Trustees. Nov 2019

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Food and Essentials
grants.description: Funding toward an organisation that offers a delivery meal service to the elderly and isolated in the Farnham area, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Brightwells Gostrey Centre
recipientOrganization.description: Established in 1994, Brightwells Gostrey Centre is a registered charity whose main objective is "to benefit the older residents of Farnham and the surrounding area by the organisation and management of a day centre and provision of necessary services". The centre is located in Brightwells Road, off East Street in Farnham and offers a meeting place and a range of services for senior citizens, including lunch and refreshments, recreational activities, outings, therapeutic services and bathing facilities. The charity also owns two minibuses which are used to transport clients between the centre and their own homes. The charity aims to make a positive impact on the quality of life of older people by offering a range of social, cultural and health-promoting activities which encourage independence and choice. A special therapeutic service is available for those who are suffering from differing forms of dementia. Transport is provided by 2 minibuses owned by the charity which collects clients from their homes and returns them later in the day. The charity employs 2 full-time and 6 part-time members of staff and is supported by a team of 30 volunteers.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: Funding toward activity packs and a radio show for an organisation, based in North East Surrey, that supports adults with learning disabilities, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Food and Essentials
grants.description: Funding for a voluntary group helping to support to vulnerable people during the Coronavirus crisis

recipientOrganization.name: Coronavirus Aid Chesham, Farleigh and Warlingham

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Food and Essentials
grants.description: Funding for a charity supporting vulnerable families during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: Home-Start Epsom, Ewell & Banstead (HSEEB)
recipientOrganization.description: Home Start Epsom, Ewell & Banstead (HSEEB) aims to increase the confidence and independence of families by visiting families in their own homes to offer support, friendship and practical assistance; reassuring parents that their childcare problems are not unusual or unique; encouraging parents' strengths and emotional well-being for the ultimate benefit of their children; and aiming to get fun back into family life. Home-Start supports families with at least one child under 5 who are experiencing difficulties and struggling to manage their lives. HSEEB uses parent/grandparent volunteers to offer tailored support for families and offers one to one practical support, friendship, and mentoring within the family home. HSEEB aims to reduce the need for statutory support and helps to give children the best possible start in life. Since HSEEB was established in 1996 over 1,500 families have been supported. HSEEB and is a Charitable Incorporated Organisation. There is 1 full-time worker, 4 part-time workers, and 52 volunteers. HSEEB has a Management Committee of 7 People.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Families with Young Children
grants.description: Funding toward emergency baby supplies for a charity, based in Reigate and Banstead, that offers support for families in poverty, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Stripey Stork
recipientOrganization.description: Stripey Stork is a registered charity which collects new and pre-loved items for babies and children up to 16 years of age (equipment, clothes, furniture and toys), and after making sure they are clean and safe, Stripey Stork distributes them to families in need via community professionals. Stripey Stork has been working largely across East surrey but aims to become a Surrey-wide service that has the operational capacity to respond to 3,500 requests for help per year by the end of 2021. The group was started by a Reigate mum-of-two who wondered what to do with all the baby items she had when her youngest child was finished with them. The local press was filled with stories of economic hardship and the effect it was having on young families. Initial research showed that no one was offering this service locally but that there were local families who desperately needed this support, and there were local families who had items they would willingly donate. Referrals to Stripey Stork come from recognised local professionals such as GPs, Health Visitors, housing associations, and Churches.

grants.title: COVID-19 Response - Healthcare
grants.description: Funding toward a salary of a temporary member of staff for an hospice, based in Woking, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Woking and Sam Beare Hospices
recipientOrganization.description: Woking & Sam Beare Hospice and Wellbeing Care, delivers personal palliative care to adult patients with life-limiting illnesses as well as supporting their carers and families. Patients are referred to us by GPs, hospitals and other healthcare providers. Woking & Sam Beare’s mission is to deliver high quality, specialist care and support to residents in Spelthorne, Runnymede, West Elmbridge, Surrey Heath, Woking and North Guildford. We know that one size does not fit all, and our care is most effective when delivered in response to personal circumstance and needs. It is coordinated and in collaboration with a range of healthcare and social care providers, and is accessible to all patients at the time they need us and in their preferred place of care. Through our services, we offer our patients holistic care, which means that as well as managing their medical needs we give practical, emotional, social and spiritual support. Alongside this, we also provide families and carers with guidance and advice so that they remain well and are best able to support their loved one who is affected by illness. We deliver this through the following activities: • Care in the community - enabling people with life-limiting conditions the opportunity to stay in their own home, care home or nursing home. Over 79% of our patients are supported in the community by our team of experienced palliative and end of life care specialists. • 24/7 specialist support on our 20 bed in-patient ward - delivered by palliative care consultants, expert nurses and dedicated health care assistants for patients at end of life or requiring respite care. • Day care in our Bradbury Wellbeing Centre - patients and carers receive out-patient support with wellbeing sessions, complementary therapies, physiotherapy, counselling, clinical care and social activities. • Family support services - patients and their families can access one-to-one counselling (pre and post bereavement) and peer support groups, including specialist groups for children and teenagers. Counselling is provided at the hospice, but most patients facing a life limiting diagnosis are seen in their own homes.

grants.title: COVID-19 Response - Counselling
grants.description: Funding toward salary costs and Zoom licences for an organisation, based in Reigate, that is transitioning from face to face counselling, to over the internet counselling, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Relate Mid-Surrey
recipientOrganization.description: Relate Mid Surrey (RMS) is a self-funded and independent charity whilst also being a part of the Relate Federation. Our focus is on supporting local families, couples and individuals, including young people, through providing a range of counselling services. Our aim is to change lives in our local area by helping people make those personal changes which enable them to build better relationships. Our mission is to develop and support healthy relationships by: • Helping couples, families and young people to make relationships work better. • To enhance the quality of couple and parental and family relationships • To help relationships and marriage withstand the pressures leading to breakdown • To limit the damage which commonly accompanies failing relationships, separation and divorce and increase the prospect of subsequent relationships succeeding. • To support young people during difficult times and to provide early intervention when they are suffering psychological distress We aim to achieve our mission by delivering inclusive, high-quality services that are relevant at every stage of life. We provide 50 minute 1:1 counselling sessions to individuals and couples and sessions up to 90 minutes for families. These are provided by our trained counsellors. Our counsellors are specifically trained in their line of counselling, whether it is to work with young people, couples or families. Our family counselling rooms are equipped with books, toys and play equipment to provide young people with the resources and atmosphere to help them to talk about their feelings. Play figures, sand, dolls, stress balls and cards can help troubled young people to develop a therapeutic conversation. We also provide Mediation, Sexual Therapy and workshops and courses. The people who come to us are often anxious, lacking confidence, confused and feeling helpless or angry about their situation. Counselling provides a safe, non-judgmental space where clients can express their feelings, explore their thinking, and find a constructive way to move forward.

grants.title: COVID-19 Response - Education
grants.description: Funding toward additional mentoring support and a bursary to pay for the online learning platforms, for an organisation, focusing in Epsom, that helps long term unemployed adults back into employment, during the COVID-19.

recipientOrganization.name: Surrey Lifelong Learning Partnership
recipientOrganization.description: Based in Knaphill in Woking, Surrey Lifelong Learning Partnership (SLLP) is a company limited by guarantee, incorporated in October 2001, and becoming a registered charity in September 2011. SLLP’s mission is to enable those who have missed out on learning in the past to have opportunities to learn and to reach their full potential. The charity's focus is on helping adults living in disadvantaged communities in Surrey and in other parts of the South East. Principally support is provided to those aged 19 and over, but the charity also caters increasingly for young adults aged 16-19 where they are not being supported. The organisation’s main activities are developing the capacity of communities to benefit from learning; and ensuring ongoing support for learners; helping providers of learning to understand what learners need and want. SLLP is also partnering with Oakleaf and Guildford Borough Council (GBC) on ‘GLADE’, a social enterprise providing gardening and street cleansing services for GBC by engaging and training local volunteers and jobseekers. SLLP works to develop community hubs in areas of priority for the delivery of local learning activities, and also provides accredited training for volunteer Community Champions who then help others within their communities to engage in learning. The Partnership has established job clubs in four locations, as well as social enterprises such as The Bike Project, on which Trainees are offered accredited City & Guilds Cycle Mechanics training. Refurbished bicycles are sold back to the community at affordable prices through the Project’s shop in Park Barn. The shop is open 3 days/week. SLLP is managed by 5 Trustees, and employs 3 full time staff.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Mental wellbeing
grants.description: Costs to deliver arts-based support to existing elderly, isolated and vulnerable clients during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: The Lightbox
recipientOrganization.description: The Lightbox is a museum and art gallery in Woking with an events and learning programme. It is both a registered charity and a company limited by guarantee. It hosts widely accessible programmes in its building and emphasises the belief that ‘art makes you feel good’. The Lightbox encourages exploration and learning through play for the younger audiences, including under 5’s activities and holiday workshops whilst also allowing for experimentation for the older audiences, including those living with dementia and isolated older people. In 2013 The Lightbox was awarded the Big Society Award which recognises the organisation’s work in improving lives and strengthening the local community. The Lightbox welcomes over 100 school groups each year, and has an internship and work experience programme with The University of Surrey and Woking College, as well as schools throughout Surrey. There are 20 exhibitions a year in 3 galleries. The charity holds a long term lease on the building from the Council (115 years remaining).

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Mental wellbeing
grants.description: Funding to provide free counselling for those struggling during the Covid-19 outbreak

recipientOrganization.name: The Lucy Rayner Foundation
recipientOrganization.description: The Lucy Rayner Foundation (LRF) was set up by the family of Lucy Rayner who committed suicide at the age of 22 in 2012. The aims of the foundation are to raise awareness of the signs and symptoms of depression in young adults; to facilitate change in the way mental health is perceived by society; to provide emotional support and education for young adults with mental health issues and their families; to build emotional resilience in young adults; and to work alongside other charitable organisations who have the same objectives. The Foundation has a Trustee Board of 7, a Management Committee of 8, and 8 additional volunteers. There are no permanent employees but free-lance workers deliver programmes on an hourly rate.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: IT and phones costs to support people with sight and hearing loss, during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: Sight for Surrey
recipientOrganization.description: Sight for Surrey (SFS) is the trading name for Surrey Association for Visual Impairment. It is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee, based near Leatherhead. The charity has provided support to visually impaired people since 1922, and now also supports those who are Deaf, deafened, hard of hearing, and those with combined sight and hearing loss. Services include assessment and rehabilitation, 1-1 support, access technology training; communication class; resource centre; community outreach; benefits and entitlements service, and support with accessing the job market. SfS supports 6,500 service users and their families or carers, regardless of age, severity of condition, or whether they are registered as visually impaired. SfS also provides external training to local organisations. SfS’s specialist work involves teaching strategies and techniques to enable people with sight loss to manage daily tasks.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: IT costs for a charity supporting disabled children and young people during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: Challengers
recipientOrganization.description: Challengers, established in 1979, is a charity dedicated to ensuring that disabled children and young people, who are frequently marginalised from mainstream settings, have access to inclusive and high-quality play and leisure activities. Each year they support over 1,400 families to access short breaks, essential to their physical, emotional and social development. Challengers mission is to provide inclusive, fun and safe places where all disabled children and young people, regardless of their impairments, can have fun, make friends and challenge their impairments. Challengers currently deliver 25 play, youth and young adult schemes, as well as two inclusive pre-schools supporting children and young people, between the ages of 2-25, at weekends, after school and during the school holidays.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: Staff costs towards a charity supporting profoundly disabled adults during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: Parity For Disability
recipientOrganization.description: Parity for Disability (PfD) is based in Farnborough in Hampshire. It is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee which was originally founded by parents in 1953 to address the lack of provision for their children who had cerebral palsy and related disabilities. The aim is to fill the gap in services for people with multiple disabilities in Surrey, Hampshire and Berkshire. The charity runs three day services for adults, two in Surrey (Camberley and Salisbury Grove in Mytchett), and one in Hampshire (Farnborough). Services are tailored to clients' individual needs, enabling them to access academic, social, living, and recreational activities, as well as regular physiotherapy, and speech and communication therapy, and music therapy. Qualified health professionals provide vital input not available on the NHS. Each person who attends is supported on a 1-1 basis in activities and on frequent trips out. The charity also provides music therapy both on-site and off-site. In addition, PfD runs Easter and summer Teenagers' Activity Schemes for teens with multiple disabilities, during the holidays.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Domestic abuse
grants.description: Funding to upgrade the phone system for a charity to support victims of domestic abuse remotely during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: East Surrey Domestic Abuse Services
recipientOrganization.description: ESDAS is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee, not having a share capital. It was established in 1993 and began delivering its services in East Surrey in 1998. ESDAS is based in Redhill and holds a 7-year lease which began in June 2016. It provides specialist community outreach and services in order to relieve the distress, hardship and need of adults and children affected by domestic abuse (DA) in East Surrey (Reigate and Banstead, Tandridge and Mole Valley). Services are free of charge and include a fortnightly Drop-In Support Group, Counselling, a Volunteer Befriending Scheme, a Parenting Group, a Sanctuary Scheme, legal Advice Drop-in, Independent Domestic Violence Advisers (IDVAs), and Self-Esteem Workshops. The Counselling is tailored to meet the needs of survivors who feel unable to access usual talking therapies through fear, long waiting lists or lack of funds. The charity works in partnership with other agencies, including organising multi-agency meetings or events. ESDAS also delivers training and raises awareness of DA. The charity has a Board of 7 Trustees, employs 9 full-time staff, and 4 part-time staff. ESDAS is supported by approximately 45 volunteers. In 2005 ESDAS was awarded the Queens Award for Voluntary Service.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - People with Disabilities
grants.description: Funding to produce online exercise programmes for people with health conditions, whilst isolating during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: YMCA East Surrey
recipientOrganization.description: YMCA East Surrey was established in 1870. It is one of 116 YMCAs which operate under a national umbrella. However, financially it is run completely independently and provides a wide range of services for the whole community. These activities focus on the vulnerable and disadvantaged and include engaging with ‘difficult to reach’ youths; provision of supported housing; mental health counselling; inclusive activities for young people with disabilities; fitness programmes for all ages, including medical referrals; children’s play schemes, including provision for those with disabilities; and running youth clubs. In 2017-18, 14,707 people benefitted from at least one of YMCA East Surrey’s services, including 8,396 children and young people under the age of 16 and 3,684 people with special needs. These services operate throughout East Surrey and are concentrated in areas of social and economic deprivation. In November 2018, YMCA East Surrey was voted ‘YMCA of the Year’.

grants.title: Covid 19 Response - Advice and support
grants.description: IT provision for a Citizen's Advice to offer support to people in Waverley during the Coronavirus pandemic

recipientOrganization.name: Citizens Advice Waverley
recipientOrganization.description: Citizens Advice Waverley was established in 2006 through the merger of three Waverley Bureaux - Farnham, Godalming and Haslemere & Cranleigh District. It is a registered charity and company limited by guarantee, having no share capital. The overall strategic aim of the charity is "to help people from all sectors of the Waverley community to resolve their problems through the provision of high quality information, advice and advocacy". Free, confidential, impartial and independent advice and information is provided through a telephone helpline and face-to-face interviews at four advice centres (located in Cranleigh, Farnham, Godalming and Haslemere). Outreach services are provided in five locations of social deprivation within the borough (Ockford Ridge and Binscombe in Godalming, and Sandy Hill, the Chantrys and Wrecclesham in Farnham), as well as at Bramley Village Hall, and a home visiting service is available for people unable to visit their local advice centre because of age or disability. The advice service is delivered by trained volunteer advisers, supported by administrative volunteers and a small staff team. In 2017/18, Citizens Advice Waverley advised nearly 5,800 Waverley residents on over 18,000 issues. The charity also supported 101 local families at risk of losing their homes. Citizens Advice Waverley (CAW) also has a working partnership with the South West Surrey Domestic Abuse Outreach Team to ensure the continued availability of these vital services following short notice withdrawal of support from SWSDAOT's previous partner charity. The formal partnership agreement was finalised in the last week of March 2019. In addition to its previous activities Citizens Advice Waverley now employs 5 Domestic Abuse Outreach workers including trained Independent Domestic Violence Advisers and 1 trained Independent Sexual Violence Adviser, plus 2 specialist Children's Workers. Although the SWSDAOT will be based in Citizens Advice Waverley's Godalming office its services cover both Guildford and Waverley boroughs and are delivered in a variety of venues across both boroughs. SWSDAOT provides free confidential, non judgemental and independent advice to victims of Domestic Abuse regardless of age, race, gender, sexuality, religion or mental and physical health; in which service users are believed, listened to and supported, in a way that ensures victims receive the information and advice they need to make informed choices. It also runs structured recovery programmes for women and children affected by abuse, both in groups and individually. From its previous growth rate it is estimated that the service will receive approximately a thousand new referrals in the forthcoming year. Referrals come from the Police, Children's Services and other professionals as well as self-referral by victims and family members. Surrey County Council and Surrey Police provide funding but this does not cover the full costs of the organisation, which relies upon additional grants and donations to deliver its full range of services needed.

grants.title: COVID19 support and advocacy for vulnerable pregnant and post-natal women
grants.description: Support and advocacy for vulnerable pregnant and post-natal women during coronavirus

recipientOrganization.name: White Ribbon Alliance UK
recipientOrganization.description: White Ribbon Alliance UK, based in Shepton Mallet, advocates for women’s rights to safe and dignified maternity care. We believe everyone has the right to respectful reproductive care. These rights are not always respected in the UK. We support women to share their stories and voices in order that maternal and new-born mortality and stillbirths are reduced and universal access to sexual and reproductive health services are achieved. COVID 19 has had a huge impact on maternity care and we need to ensure that the most vulnerable women in Somerset can access continuity of prenatal, post-natal and breast-feeding support.

recipientOrganization.name: Brent Knoll Parish Council
recipientOrganization.description: Having recently lost the Village Store and Post Office the Village has started the process of setting up a Community Shop with helpful advice from the Plunkett Foundation. Due to the recent COVID 19 emergency and in view of the number of villagers who are unable to venture out it has been decided to set up an emergency shop to cater for the day to day needs of the vulnerable residents in the village.

recipientOrganization.name: The Minehead Hope Centre
recipientOrganization.description: Relieving the needs of people in Minehead and West Somerset who suffer from drug and/or alcohol abuse or homelessness and the consequences of such. Promoting social inclusion by relieving the needs of those people who are socially excluded and assisting them to integrate into society. Since the virus outbreak we have had to close the Centre but are still providing takeaway meals and are opening an extra day a week, as the demand for food is great. This has incurred additional costs in respect of wages, food, takeaway containers, disposable cutlery, aprons, masks, gloves and premises costs.

recipientOrganization.name: Chelmsford Community Radio C.I.C.
recipientOrganization.description: Chelmsford Community Radio is the local station for Chelmsford, with a wide range of shows and presenters. We focus on news and views for Chelmsford, and give a voice to local people. We engage with the community, promote and attend events and have guests in the studio to talk about whats happening locally. We offer opportunities for those interested in radio broadcasting, and have projects that offer studio training and radio experiences. Chelmsfrord is the home of radio and the site of the transmission of Britain's first official radio broadcast.

grants.title: Grant to PACT for Autism
grants.description: to support the operational costs supporting people with autism in West Essex throughout COVID19

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

recipientOrganization.name: PACT for Autism
recipientOrganization.description: PACT For Autism provides support to families of children, young people and adults with autism, including those with similar conditions who reside within Harlow and surrounding areas. We also support professionals working within the areas of Autistic Spectrum Conditions. Improving access to information and availability of resources, Improving public awareness and ensuring that all the people, we support, have access to the same positive outcomes that are available to others. We strive to archive these aims by: Providing monthly information & support meetings across Harlow, Epping Forest and Uttlesford, 2 x information and support telephone lines, collation and circulation of relevant and accurate information through our website, relevant social media updates via Facebook / Twitter and Instagram and regular email updates to registered families, professionals and individuals. Parent / carer and professional workshops & autism awareness training; regular liaison with local schools, special educational needs and disability (SEND) teams discussing issues of inclusion, exclusions and Educational Health Care Plans (EHCP). Networking with link workers / social prescribers to ensure signposting to appropriate resources are considered through GP surgeries, sitting on an Autism specific working group within the Child and Development Clinics (CDC) to discuss and improve neuro-developmental pathways (JADES pathway in Essex) and the additional support available to families. Arranging and providing a variety of social activities which includes opportunities for families, children and individuals to have access to safe and secure entertainment appropriate to their learning age, annual trips and swimming events etc. Networking and campaigning locally and nationally on issues relating to autism (including employment, health and education issues). Raising the public awareness of autism via the circulation of information, training, public talks, and an out reach Autism awareness talks service. PACT staff developed and organise an annual information event, inviting a wide range of professionals and organisations to a single venue, for other professionals and families to attend and get information and advice as a 'one stop shop' this has proved very successful for the past two years and will continue, hopefully growing and becoming even more popular.

In addition, we are looking to establish a network of ‘citizen journalists’, people living in various different areas who can be deployed to cover events local to them. We hope to be able to train them not only in radio, but to work towards helping them become skilled at sound and vision recording in order to help realise our ambition to augment our website with video as well as sound, text and graphics. There are creative openings for short story writers, dramatists and actors, musicians, voice-over artists and presenters of special interest material in areas such as fishing, gardening, astronomy, nature and conservation. To support all this we need editors and researchers as well as people prepared to pitch in and help with whatever is needed – sometimes supporting our Roadshow team, sometimes going out on Outside Broadcasts, sometimes in one of our studios or helping with the website we have jobs for everyone and work with job centre plus. princes trust and most charity org that come in to get there message across.

recipientOrganization.name: Streets2Homes
recipientOrganization.description: Our aim is to prevent / end homelessness. Our objectives are to provide opportunities for those most vulnerable in our community to improve their; confidence, well-being, self-esteem, employability, health, lifestyle and opportunities in life. In addition to securing accommodation, equipping them with skills to sustain a tenancy and gain support and assistance to overcome any issues they are facing such as drug / alcohol misuse, poor mental health and other issues that may hinder a positive lifestyle. By helping them to regain and build on their identity and healthy relationships. We provide a wrap-around service consisting of outreach visits on the streets to build trust and relationships and ensure the wellbeing of rough sleepers; a day centre that provides a safe and friendly environment, clean clothes, shower facilities, refreshments and meals. We also provide various workshop sessions at the centre to improve wellbeing, employability and living skills. These include art club, job club, cookery sessions, free haircuts, accredited courses and a client volunteer programme. We assist to seek and secure suitable accommodation, we work with many landlords in the private rented sector, operate a deposit scheme, provision of home starter pack and ongoing tenancy support through home visits once a client is housed. In May 2019 we opened a 9 bed accommodation project where we are able to offer accommodation in a therapeutic, supported environment to relieve homelessness and help the resident to overcome the barriers to accessing more secure accommodation, we work with the resident until they are ready to move on to independent living where we will help them to seek and secure move on accommodation with ongoing support until they are able and confident to manage a tenancy.

recipientOrganization.name: South East and Central Essex Mind
recipientOrganization.description: South East and Central Essex Mind provide support and outreach for the people in Southend and other local communities, including Chelmsford, South Woodham Ferrers, Castle Point, Rayleigh and Rochford, who are suffering with anxiety, depression and other forms of mental illness. Our charity aims for a society that promotes and protects good mental wellbeing for all, and that treats people with experience of mental distress and their families fairly, positively and with respect. While are affiliated with the national Mind charity we are completely independent and we receive less than 1% funding from them each year. We currently run the following projects: • A 24 hour supported housing scheme and two community houses, accommodating up to 20 tenants receiving long term and short term help. • Counselling services for adults, children and young people from ages 5+. • A specialised trauma service. • A dedicated telephone and email service called ‘Somewhere to Turn’. • Peer support and group work in a variety of different areas. • Mental health training for individual schools and businesses. • Police and Criminal Evidence for mental health and custody support. • Drop-in and open door services in Southend and Chelmsford. We assist people with a number of different mental health issues, including anxiety and panic attacks, bipolar disorder, depression, eating problems, Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder, Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder, psychosis and schizophrenia. In the last year we supported in excess of 950 disadvantaged people to address their mental health conditions and learn coping strategies to manage their illness.

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Safer Places
recipientOrganization.description: Safer Places (SP) is an independent domestic abuse (DA) charity with over 40 years’ experience of service delivery. We pride ourselves on our commitment to equity of services for all and deliver a high quality, person-centred and trauma-informed service which reaches and responds to all people affected by domestic and sexual abuse. As a person led service, our clients have choice and control of their support which is individually tailored to them. We work with our clients and their families to reduce their risk and increase their safety and reliance, with the ultimate aim of everyone living free from abuse. This includes a comprehensive range of services such as emotional support, advocacy, access to safe accommodation; CBT based domestic abuse programmes, legal surgeries, counselling, etc. and access to our Women’s Centre. We recognise the radiating impact DA has upon every aspect of the client’s life and that of her children, friends, family and often work life. Felitti’s (1998) Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACE’s) research illustrates the detrimental impact DA has on children’s personal, social, and emotional development and their health and education. Due to the corrosive nature of DA children are likely to have been exposed to numerous ACE’s in additional to DA. As such we provide therapeutic children’s services or work with our partners to ensure that children are supported to flourish in their environment. Our aim is to drive down the incidence of domestic abuse, as such we hold an excellent reputation as a training provider and an example of leading practice and have delivered training to raise awareness and increase the knowledge and understanding of women who have experienced abuse / trauma for staff in the public and voluntary sector, so they are equipped to recognise and respond to clients enabling those impacted by abuse to access specialist services.

recipientOrganization.name: Southend YMCA
recipientOrganization.description: Southend YMCA provides practical support, accommodation and education predominately to children and young people aged 8-24 years old in Southend and the surrounding areas. We want to meet the needs and aspirations of disadvantaged people in our locality; to work for social justice and further opportunity – all with the aim of positively transforming lives. Although we are affiliated to YMCA England and Wales, we are proud that all our services are informed and led by local need. We consult with local people to deliver services which aim to ‘bridge the gap’ in statutory provision and other local support. Our key services include: - Supported housing. Our supported accommodation is for homeless, vulnerable or at risk young people aged 16-25. We provide them with accommodation as well as practical and emotional support to improve their confidence, independent living skills and resilience. - Community housing – we provide two community properties which are dedicated units for 7 young asylum seekers supported by social care. Young people learn to live with others negotiating household rules, tasks and responsibilities. - The Southend YMCA Community School provides an alternative, holistic education to 50 young people (aged 14-16) with social, emotional and behavioural needs. - All-in-Music provides exciting music-making opportunities for people who may not have access to quality and diverse musical experiences. - The SOS Bus provides a safe space for people attending events in Basildon and Southend, especially at night, delivering support and first aid for those in need. We also provide a breastfeeding support service for new mothers, a youth board so that young people can have their voice heard and a mentoring programme, supporting children and young people with issues such as bereavement and social exclusion.

grants.title: Grant to Cruse Bereavement Care Essex Area
grants.description: to provide a telephone service during the COVID19 crisis for those affected by bereavement and fear of bereavement

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Cruse Bereavement Care Essex Area
recipientOrganization.description: Essex Cruse has been supporting adults, children and young people since 1970. Last year, our team of 30 specialist trained bereavement volunteers provided direct support to over 250 people struggling to cope with the immediate and on-going effects of grief. Our services are free of charge and accessible, regardless of the nature of death or length of time since a bereavement occurred. Our vision is that all bereaved people have somewhere to turn when someone dies. Our values: We are Responsive, Compassionate, Respectful, Supportive and Innovative. We currently provide information and advice to anyone who needs it in Essex, and provide one to one and group support to people in Southend-on-Sea Area, Rochford and Rayleigh Areas, Castlepoint and Epping/ Theydon Bois, Chigwell, Chipping Ongar, Brockhurst Hill, Loughton, Waltham Abbey, North Weald Bassett Abridge, Nazeing and Roydon and the surrounding areas. The following are the bereavement support service we can offer; One to one support: Our team of bereavement volunteers use a person-centred approach during one-to-one sessions and receive specialist training in how to support people in a number of ways including- helping to navigate complex feelings associated with loss, developing coping strategies and normalising grief. We see clients at local venues including church rooms or in their own home, a service which is particularly useful for clients who are unable to travel. Helpline and Telephone Support: Cruse in Essex has a Helpline run by a team of dedicated Bereavement Volunteers trained to provide immediate support to an incoming call, carry out initial assessments and work with the client to decide what, if any, additional support they require from Cruse. If appropriate they also signpost people to other services and provide useful sources of practical information. Some volunteers are trained to provide ongoing telephone support. This offers up to 6 one hour weekly sessions. Peer Support and Groupwork for people bereaved by suicide: Our Drop-In Groups provide an opportunity to meet other people in a similar situation and to share experiences. Many people feel isolated and lonely following bereavement, but we find in a group situation people support each other and often lasting friendships are made. We offer Peer Support at St John, Loughton which runs on a monthly basis. Anyone from the local community can attend without an appointment and talk to someone privately as well as join a group facilitated by two trained volunteers. In Southend we run a closed group specifically for people bereaved by suicide, giving them the opportunity to meet others who have lost someone to suicide, share experiences and feelings associated with this traumatic type of loss. Children and Young People: There is a huge demand for bereavement support for children and young people in Essex. We help children and young people experiencing distress, and behavioural and psychological difficulties triggered by bereavement. Specialist volunteers work with children in range of ways, allowing them to express their feelings and develop coping skills.

recipientOrganization.name: Southend Carers' Forum
recipientOrganization.description: Southend Carers is committed to the empowerment of Carers & the encouragement of a wider recognition of their invaluable contribution to society. By understanding their needs, highlighting their concerns and representing their views, we endeavour to provide services to support & advise them, reduce their isolation, help them maintain their caring role and improve their health & wellbeing. With approximately 1,900 carers actively registered with us, our main aims are to ensure that Carers of all ages (5-105 years) living in Southend on Sea are: o able to live healthy lives as regards their mental and physical well-being o able to alleviate the social isolation that many feel due to their caring role and responsibilities o provided with the latest accurate advice, support & information relating to their needs and the lives of their dependents During the last three years we have successfully led the Southend Carers Consortium, and in partnership, we provide a one-stop-shop single point of referral for Carers to access services such as: • Advice, information and guidance: Expert advice, information and guidance on money, housing health and many other issues. • Weekly & Monthly social meet ups, trips & outings, special programme of emotional for young carers aged 5 to 17. • Social activities, guidance and support for Young Adult Carers aged 14 to 25 as they make the transition to adult services. • Social & practical activities and events, bringing carers together with their peers to socialise, pick up new skills and share experiences. • Respite services for parents of children with additional needs and their siblings, including family holidays, social events and day trips. • Emotional support and counselling, offering a safe, confidential and comfortable setting for carers who may feel overwhelmed by their caring role • Emergency planning to help carers plan for the unexpected so that their loved one is cared for - if they are taken ill, involved in an accident or unable to resume their caring role. • High quality, specialised End of Life support and respite for carers of those with a life limiting condition By working together we have made it much easier for carers to access the right practical, financial and emotional support - more effectively and efficiently.

recipientOrganization.name: Home-Start Essex
recipientOrganization.description: The Home-Start Essex (HSE) vision is: “For every child and young person in Essex to grow up in a family that is strong and resilient and able to access support when and where it is needed”. We provide emotional, practical support and guidance to parents of young families, who are struggling with the demands of family life. Typically, they will be experiencing some of the following: social isolation, mental health issues, post-natal depression, domestic abuse, children with additional needs and financial difficulties. Our work falls into the following categories: • Individualised family support, providing tailor-made help and guidance in the home. • Family groups – informal groups for parents to meet, share experiences and develop support networks • Well-Being groups - parents struggling with self-esteem and mental health issues meet to share their own experiences to learn strategies and support each other. • Special projects such as Big Hopes, Big Futures (a school readiness programme).

recipientOrganization.name: Mid and North East Essex Mind
recipientOrganization.description: We are an independent local charity that specialises in supporting children, young people and adults who are experiencing mild to moderate mental health problems. We are here to support and empower people experiencing an emotional or mental health problem by building on their personal hopes and aspirations. This is achieved by identifying and responding to community needs in order to deliver an effective and efficient system of community based services. These services include two counselling services: a free counselling service, open to adults in the Colchester or Tendring districts experiencing mild to moderate mental health problems. We specialise in Counselling for Depression in individuals and couples, but also offer Dynamic Interpersonal Therapy and Psychosexual Counselling. We recently ran a course of Mindfulness sessions shortly to give clients who have completed their counselling some transitional support before they fully leave our service. Our second counselling service is an affordable private service available to people living in the Colchester, Tendring, Braintree, Chelmsford or Maldon districts. Sessions are available for £40 each to children from the age of 5 and adults of all ages. Within the children’s service we offer art, play or talking therapies depending on the child’s age and preference. For adults we have a range of talking therapies available which mirror those available in the free service. Our counsellors in both services are qualified to at least Diploma level and registered with the British Association of Counselling and Psychotherapy (BACP). In May 2018 we will be opening a new service called Chat with Charlie. This was developed alongside the Charlie Watkins Foundation and provides online mental health support for students, initially those at Essex University. The service will run between 6pm - 10pm to bridge the gap between the current service provision. Students can log on for a 40 minute 1:1 session with a trained volunteer or take part in a mental health forum to get support from both professionals and peers. In 2017 we launched a new service called Futures in Mind in partnership with West Essex Mind and Phoenix Futures which is open to people experiencing mental health and/ or drug or alcohol misuse problems. The service primarily offers a series of peer support groups, called Welcome Café’s, these are open in the larger towns across the area, some are more specialist including a young person’s café (for people aged 18-30), an Asperger’s café, art cafes and a group for parents experiencing mental health problems. Alongside these are activity groups such as football, gardening and pottery. These activity groups are run by the service users themselves to reflect in interests of the group members and are supported by a member of staff. The service also offers befriending and mentoring service and is free to service users. Our Children and Young People’s team work with 5-18 year olds experiencing problems with their mental health and emotional wellbeing. We offer 1:1 support either in school or at our Maldon hub for issues such as anger, anxiety, low mood and family problems. For young people who would benefit more from group support we can offer group therapy for 6-8 young people over the course of 6 weeks on a specific issue,predominantly anxiety. Our Support, Time and Recovery (STaR) Team offer free practical support on issues such as housing, job seeking, employment support and help with benefits and finance. The team work in the community and are flexible around the needs of clients. This is available in Mid and North East Essex. In the autumn of 2016 all our staff worked together on a set of values that are most important to us and our service users. These values underpin the way we do everything at Mid and North East Essex Mind and we are really proud of that. Our values are: •Supportive: here when people need us •Non-judgemental: treating all as equals •Respectful: showing admiration for others •Empowering: giving others strength •Honest: trust in our honesty

recipientOrganization.name: Lighthouse Furniture Project
recipientOrganization.description: We are an award-winning local furniture and appliance re-use Social Enterprise and Registered Charity, with a 13 year successful track record, based in Brentwood and operating across much of South Essex and North East London. Our project provides affordable good quality second hand furniture, white goods (with a six months guarantee) and household items which we collect from the local and surrounding areas free of charge. These items are then sold on at low cost to the general public of which many are on low incomes. The sale of furniture helps to cover our operating costs and allows us to focus on our main aim, which is to alleviate hardship and improve the quality of life of vulnerable people within the community. This often includes homeless families and individuals and others in some form of housing crisis. We do this by working in partnership with Social Services, Housing Associations, Women Refuges, Homestart, local authority Housing Departments, CAB's, etc. When clients are referred, we can offer larger discounts and in cases of severe hardship some essential items without charge. Working with Essex County Council we deliver furniture items across South Essex within the local welfare fund known as the 'Essential Living Fund', formerly the DWP's Social Fund. We further support those who are really struggling by providing free kitchen and bedding starter packs, free new carpet off cuts, free sofas and chests/bedsides, occasionally food along with refurbished computers and tables and chairs, providing children and families somewhere to study and to encourage strong families, assisting people to realise their full potential. We give talks and presentations on the causes of homelessness. Any operating surplus is reinvested back into the charity to expand its reach enabling it to help more people, whilst at the same time diverting furniture from landfill with significant environment benefits and one of our aims.

recipientOrganization.description: Thurrock Community Voluntary Service is a Council of Voluntary Services; our mission is to strengthen the voluntary, community and faith sector with support, co-ordination and representation through: - Developing and promoting voluntary led solutions, through policy and influencing decisions to meet the diverse needs and aspirations of the citizens of Thurrock. - Providing a range of accessible, high quality services around information, support, training and advice to community groups and organisations in Thurrock. - Bringing voluntary, community and faith organisations together to share knowledge, promote best practice and co-ordinate activity and opinion. Thurrock Community Voluntary Service (CVS) provides the following services: - ngage, a community development and engagement project of Thurrock CVS which shapes and promotes opportunities for active citizenship and social participation in Thurrock. Projects include a Volunteer Centre which promotes volunteering opportunities to the general public, students and local businesses; Time Bank Thurrock which encourages people to share their skills and resources with others in their local community; and assisting our Thurrock Community Hubs with recruitment and training of volunteers. - Healthwatch Thurrock, which gathers and represents the views of individuals regarding health and social care services, helping to improve services. - By Your Side, which helps vulnerable and isolated people to settle home from hospital with the support of a volunteer. - Social Prescribing, which supports people with health and wellbeing needs including chronic conditions by signposting them to appropriate non-medical support services. - Giving for Thurrock, a community fund for Thurrock voluntary groups and residents to support them to achieve their goals. Thurrock CVS is also a partner of ‘Stronger Together’; a partnership of voluntary and statutory services which promotes local, community activities which strengthen the connections between people and encourages local people to have a greater say in what happens in their neighbourhood.

recipientOrganization.name: Citizens Advice Bureau - Southend on Sea
recipientOrganization.description: At Citizens Advice Southend (our operating name) we aim to provide the advice people need for the problems they face and to improve the policies and practices that affect people’s lives. We provide free, independent, confidential and impartial advice to everyone on their rights and responsibilities. We value diversity, promote equality and challenge discrimination. We help people resolve their money, legal and other problems by providing information and advice and by influencing policymakers. The client is at the very heart of our service, we are here to ensure that people who need help get the right kind of help at the right time. We offer a quality assured advice and information service, delivered face to face, by telephone and through the website, www.citizensadvice.org.uk by web chat and email. We mainly offer our face to face services at our offices at 1 Church Road, Southend-on-Sea, SS1 2AL. Our initial drop in service operates from 10am to 3.30pm, Monday to Friday except public holidays. Follow up appointments are made if necessary. A General Adviser is available at the Community Hub in Victoria Shopping Centre one day per week and we will soon have a presence at the Shoeburyness Hub. We offer a monthly advice service at the offices of Seetec Southend, to their clients who are receiving support through one of the Work Programmes. We have a presence at the monthly drop in for Southend Wave, a multi agency support project for sex workers. Other outreach services are offered according to demand. We also offer some specialist services, referral and, in some cases, eligibility criteria apply to these services determined by the funder of the service.We have a Legal Aid contract in Housing for clients requiring specialist help who are financially eligible for legal aid and where the matter is within scope of legal aid as defined by the Legal Aid Agency. We operate the Housing Possession Court Duty Scheme at Southend County Court available for anyone who has a possession action listed that day. We have a Rent Arrears project with South Essex Homes (SEH) for tenants whose rent arrears have reached the point where SEH is considering repossession action. The aim of the project is to help the tenant stay in their home and to enable them to pay off the rent arrears to SEH, which is a priority debt. We operate a debt casework service funded through the Money Advice Service Debt Advice Project. Our Debt Caseworker is a DRO Intermediary. We have a part time Welfare Benefits Specialist Adviser funded by Southend-on-Sea Borough Council. We operate an immigration casework service lead by an Office of the Immigration Service Commissioner Level 2 Adviser. This service also covers other local Citizens Advice including Basildon, Chelmsford, Maldon, Rochford and Rayleigh and Thurrock. We are developing a ‘Digital Inclusion’ project focusing on immigration forms. We arrange training courses and network meetings in immigration issues. A General Adviser (job share) is based at the offices of the Royal Bank of Scotland at Thanet Grange in Southend, four days a week to provide telephone advice and support to clients referred from the Specialist Support Teams at RBS, based in Southend, Birmingham and Rotherham. This project is funded by RBS. An Adviser from the Royal Association for Deaf People offers a weekly advice service at our office to clients who are deaf or have a hearing impairment. The Adviser who attends also has a hearing impairment. We can assist people with form filling, we prepare simple wills for clients and can offer support relating to power of attorney and related issues. The employment of our Solicitor allows us to prepare where necessary and sign statutory declarations for clients, predominantly for changes of name and lost pawn tickets. We are a delivery partner in the recently established Southend Carers Hub. We provide training courses to organisations on the use of the Citizens Advice public site and other specific areas of advice. We give talks to local groups about the services we offer and/or specific areas of advice. Southend Talking Newspaper undertakes their recordings from our office. Pension Wise staff use our office for their guidance interviews for clients who live in Southend and surrounding areas in south east Essex. The Community Worker for Terrence Higgins Trust uses our office to see their clients who live in Southend. Essex Savers, a credit union, offers a weekly service point at our office. We offer a wide range of volunteering opportunities, supported by paid staff. Since 2013 we have worked in partnership with the Employability and Careers Service at the University of Essex and have hosted 13 internships, funded by the University. All of the internships, except one, are for Research and Campaigns work, the one exception was a Fundraising opportunity in 2014 which coincided with the 75th anniversary of the service. We offer placements to Social Work students, our current student is our 7th placement. We have also worked with Seetec, Southend Adult Community College and South Essex College to offer work placements for jobseekers and students on various courses and also relevant training opportunities. We work with local schools, predominantly, Southend High School for Girls, to provide volunteering opportunities to their sixth form students as part of their community programme. Our charitable objects are to promote any charitable purpose for the benefit of the community in the Borough of Southend-on-Sea and elsewhere (“the area of benefit”) by the advancement of education, the protection and preservation of health and the relief of poverty, sickness and distress. Citizens Advice Southend has operated in Southend-on-Sea since 1908, since 1939 as part of the Citizens Advice service. In 2015/2016 we helped 8133 people (based on a unique client count) with 12,251 issues.

grants.title: Grant to North Blackwater Parishes: Tolleshunt Major, Tollesbury, Salcott & Tollesbury
grants.description: to help with increased operational costs arising from greater community support provided by the volunteer parish nursing team across the four North Blackwater Parishes in response to the COVID19 pandemic

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: North Blackwater Parishes: Tolleshunt Major, Tollesbury, Salcott & Tollesbury
recipientOrganization.description: This project is specifically to gain accreditation of our Parish Nursing Service, to enable the Service to start and to develop within the North Blackwater Parishes, to be sustainable and to work in partnership with existing statutory and voluntary services to help meet the needs of the local community; specifically for those with a mental health condition, including dementia, depression, anxiety, and agoraphobia. There is significant evidence, documented in national and local health profiles, and provided directly by those living and working in the community served by the North Blackwater Parishes, that mental health care and support is where the need is greatest and where gaps in voluntary and statutory service provision currently exist. In relation to this need, the North Blackwater Parishes are currently awaiting appointment of a new Priest as the last incumbent has recently retired for mental health reasons. An experienced and qualified NMC (Nursing and Midwifery Council) registered community nurse who has worked in mental health for many years, has offered her services to undertake the role of Parish Nurse on a voluntary and long term basis (working 10 hours/week). She has successfully completed the Parish Nursing Preparation course, which includes a 4-day residential training provided by the charity Parish Nursing Ministries UK and funded through a small Mission Opportunity Fund grant. Safeguarding adults and children training has also been successfully completed - both NHS and training provided by the Diocese of Chelmsford. The North Blackwater Parishes are situated in rural North Essex and include the villages of Tollesbury, Tolleshunt D'Arcy, Tolleshunt Major and Salcott-cum-Virley. The £1000 funding gained through the Mission Opportunity Fund grant was specifically to recruit and train the Parish Nurse through Parish Nursing Ministries UK (see above). The Parish Nurse is a Christian, with leadership and significant community nursing experience in the NHS, who values and embraces equality and diversity and is able to work as a Parish Nurse on a voluntary basis providing holistic care to people living in the community of all faiths and none. Parish Nursing in England (and in the USA) has been shown to improve social engagement and help to reduce the incidence of loneliness and isolation within communities. The Parish Nursing role has been shown to improve and promote good physical and mental health, through working alongside statutory services, helping people to manage their own health conditions and supporting people to gain confidence and to engage in social activities where appropriate. The following link to the Parish Nursing Ministries UK website explains more about Parish Nursing. Please copy and paste this link into Google https://parishnursing.org.uk/what-is-parish-nursing/ The Parish Nurse role within North Blackwater parishes includes the following: - Enabling people, wherever possible, not to walk through life's difficult journeys alone. - Through health needs assessment, which includes talking with and listening to individuals and groups, the PN service will focus on specific community health need in the Parishes, to focus on reducing social isolation, and supporting individuals with dementia, depression and agoraphobia. -Offering home visits and outreach to those in need who wish to receive support, regardless of their faith or no faith. Longer term aims and objectives include embracing, valuing and building community capacity; by utilising the skills and qualities (and services) that already exist - in developing a Parish Nursing team. Funding gained through the Essex Community Foundation will help enable this to happen. - To support people living and working within our community (parishes) towards whole person centred health and well-being, through health promotion and social inclusion in its widest sense. - Parish Nurse: working closely with the Ministry team and in partnership with the local NHS and other relevant professionals and agencies (statutory and voluntary), such as the four T's, to provide a service that integrates physical, spiritual, emotional, psychological and social health to the local community - regardless of faith as explained above. - Home visiting will be a core feature of the Parish Nurse role, to provide confidential care, based on active listening, onward referral as required and early intervention mental health support. The Parish Nurse is trained and equipped to manage and to provide supervision to all members of the Parish Nursing Team. Support to and supervision of the Parish Nurse herself will be provided by the charity Parish Nursing Ministries UK (PNMUK). This supervision and support is included in the PNMUK accreditation fee. Documents to be uploaded include the following: - Parish Nurse (PN) approved role description (North Blackwater Parishes) - Equal Opportunities Policy for the Parishes and Diocese as a whole - Parish Nursing Ministries UK PN service set up and accreditation process & costs. - Parish Nurse certificate of achievement/completion of C2 leadership face to face and e-learning Safeguarding training. - Evidence of Parish Nurse's up to date registration with Nursing and Midwifery Council. - Evidence of Parish Nurse's enhanced DBS clearance, to enable her to work with children and vulnerable adults, including in the home setting.

grants.description: to help run an adapted service to support to patients and their families at Queen Alexandra Hospital during the COVID19 crisis

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Anne Robson Trust
recipientOrganization.description: The Anne Robson Trust (ART) was launched in May 2018 with a vision of nobody dying alone in hospital. People are eight times more likely to die in a hospital bed than a hospice bed, but despite this, the gap in compassion and dignity experienced by hospitalised patients is widely accepted to be significant. The work of ART is focused around improving those last days and hours in hospital for patients and their loved ones. A volunteer-led organisation, we partner with NHS Hospitals to embed Butterfly Volunteer Teams to sit and support end-of-life patients and their families in the last days of life. To date, we have recruited, trained, equipped and supported 106 wonderfully dedicated volunteers - who have made a combined 7,300 patient bedside visits in hospitals across the East of England since we formed. For many of those patients, a Butterfly Volunteer was their only non-clinical visitor during their final stay in hospital. We are the only charity in the UK that is working towards a vision of nobody dying alone in hospital.

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Abberton Rural Training (ART)
recipientOrganization.description: ART's vision is to deliver a programme of practical and skills training to residents of Essex with a particular focus on supporting those living in rural locations who need help to access jobs, or further education and training, in the rural sector. This is combined with mental health counselling and outdoor activities to help improve mental health, as well as cope with other life issues including alcoholism and drug addiction to help the individuals improve their lives, gain social skills, confidence and self-esteem and prevent them from being active in crime or being led into criminal activities. We have three sites across North Essex including Wormingford, Colchester District; Halstead, Braintree District and Stow Maries, Maldon District. These provide activities including woodlands & land management, horticulture, land based studies, animal care and countryside & environment courses and qualifications. We gain extra experiences with the assistance of local land owners including Bevills Farm, John Rix Farm, Stone Lakes and the Garrison estate. Our students are particularly vulnerable, with over 80% having a mental health issues, and 20% having multiple issues. Many have been involved in criminal behaviour previously, including anti-social behaviour and many suffer from addictions. We believe everyone has a right to education and opportunity and should not be prevented from accessing courses due to their rural location, their anxieties, issues or circumstances so the wrap around mentoring provision is key to keeping high need learners engaged and for working through problems and removing barriers that have stopped them previously from living fulfilling and rewarding lives. By giving them the chance to gain qualifications and experiences, become part of a team in a positive environment, we remove them from negative influences and help them build strategies to cope in the wider world. We have helped prevent 7 direct suicides this year.

recipientOrganization.description: The Cheddar Patient Group's aim is to act as a focus for "healthy" patient participation, be self-sufficient and proactively work with the Medical Centre, patients and their carers to understand and use their views; be a critical friend to the Medical Centre and to influence and inform across all sectors at all levels. A major part of our current work is information and signposting using our website www.cheddarpatientgroup.co.uk especially at this time of uncertainty. Funding from local events is now cancelled due to Covid-19, meaning we are unable to afford our 2020 web hosting, domain name and maintenance fees.

recipientOrganization.name: able2achieve
recipientOrganization.description: a2a mission is to enable personal achievement and progression by developing essential skills and self-confidence through learning, living and working. We did this by supporting day activities in various real life environment such as our cafes, bakery and shop which are now closed to learners due to COVID19. We aim to take the service to those we support - mobile workshops, activity boxes and tasks. Online participation via video link people with learning difficulties and associated disorders including those we support with mental health issues

recipientOrganization.name: Coronavirus Community Help Taunton
recipientOrganization.description: Volunteer support group set up on Facebook with 12,500 members in the main Taunton group and 39 sub groups covering whole SWT area. Links into SCC, SWT district, Red Cross, SPARK and Village Agents, we are fulfilling requests for help via local co-ordinators and volunteers for the elderly and vulnerable including shopping and prescription collection, isolation buddy support, and a safe "chat"forum for advice without any scaremongering, links to useful official guidance and for people to offer support and submit requests for help.
