grants.description: Provision of shopping, prescription delivery, telephone support and information sharing services during coronavirus

recipientOrganization.name: Glastonbury Corona Virus Support Network
recipientOrganization.description: We are a volunteer support network in Glastonbury set up in immediate response to the Cornovirus outbreak. We have been supporting vulnerable / self-isolating people in our community with shopping, prescriptions, phone support and other unexpected difficulties. We also share official advice as well as helpful local information to people in our community. We aim to ensure that people who are unable to get out or who are isolated are supported through the crisis - we have leafleted all addresses in town. We have over 200 volunteers registered and have already carried out over 500 acts of support.

grants.title: COVID19 support for vulnerable people
grants.description: Support for vulnerable people during coronavirus

recipientOrganization.name: Kingston Community Partnership
recipientOrganization.description: The Kingston St Mary Community Partnership was established to implement the Community Plan, which identified that some 50% of respondents needed assistance to manage their shopping and daily tasks. Due to the Coronavirus emergency a Good Neighbours Scheme is being relaunched to help residents with collecting essential supplies and provide emotional support. A network of volunteers has been established, who are prepared to give up their time and accept the risk of providing assistance to the local community. This community led initiative currently relies upon the generosity of its volunteers and is therefore constrained by a lack of financial resources.

recipientOrganization.name: Frome Town Council
recipientOrganization.description: Frome Town Council is a parish council with 23 staff members, all of whom have been redeployed to support a covid-19 response to support residents in Frome. We have established a number of emergency projects working with all of our partners in the town to meet the needs of local people in the current situation. The direct services delivered by FTC include a telephone helpline, emergency food parcel delivery and bespoke shopping the Shop for Me project. We now have over 300 volunteers supporting these and other projects in the town, this bid is to create capacity to support them.

recipientOrganization.name: Reminiscence Learning
recipientOrganization.description: We provide reminiscence therapy through community activities, specific projects, events and training sessions. We also provide respite for carers and support for care workers, particularly in care homes. Due to the Coronavirus outbreak we have had to close our Centre, reinvent the wheel and adapt our services online and by telephone contact. Being in lockdown is taking its toll on our clients and their carers who need support, reassurance and interaction. We need to provide as much contact and engagement as possible to prevent loneliness and isolation from overwhelming our older generation.

recipientOrganization.name: South Somerset Live At Home Scheme
recipientOrganization.description: To reduce the loneliness and social isolation of the elderly members of our community. On 13/03/20 the scheme stopped all groups/outings/activities, and became a welfare and support system with staff and volunteers providing telephone support, shopping, prescription collection etc. We have thus lost the income from member activity contributions whilst salary/rent etc outlays remain. We must be able to cover the expenses of our much expanded volunteer base who are supporting our elderly. Many of our members cannot get to cashpoints and so we must have the financial capability of advancing funds to cover their shopping in the interim.

grants.title: Grant to Dengie Project Trust
grants.description: to sustain an organisation supporting isolated and vulnerable people across the rural Dengie area during the COVID19 crisis

grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Dengie Project Trust
recipientOrganization.description: Dengie Project Trust has been delivering day services to adults of all ages for over 25 years through Knightswood Day Care Centre in Asheldham and within the community. Over time the Day Centre has developed greater expertise in dementia care and carers support and our aim is to provide a range of services which empower older people living within the Dengie Peninsular to make choices which enable them to reach optimum levels of health and fitness, maintain their independence and to lead rich and fulfilling lives. Some of the activities within the Centre include seated exercise classes, reminiscence ,sing & dance, board games and flower arranging. Dengie Project Trust also manage a 'Lend A Hand' Service for those individuals in the community who may need a little help with trips, shopping, appointments, companionship or light housework and an Outreach Service working with local groups of people in their own communities.

grants.title: Grant to Thorpe Bay Methodist Church
grants.description: to move their service online to continue providing music services to young people taking part to improve their mental health during COVID19

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Thorpe Bay Methodist Church
recipientOrganization.description: The Church provides a number of community activities and facilities apart from worship. These include a Kid Club, Pre-school, Parents and Tots, Youth Clubs and a music project. tb youth and tbsongwriting are run by a Youth and Community Worker paid for by the church. Overall Aims of tbsongwriting: 1) To improve young persons self esteem and confidence through songwriting, mentoring and recording music 2) To improve young peoples musical skills and abilities 3) To improve the chances of young people engaging with education and/or employment We aim to work with those that need our 1-1 and group services most, and therefore the vast majority of our young people struggle with poor mental health and/or are not in mainstream education or work. We exclusively work with 15-21 year olds- an age group which is notoriously difficult to work and engage with, yet a significant age for making big choices. We provide 1-1 'Music Mentoring' sessions in schools and at our small studio space. We also facilitate weekly group sessions, empowering community between young people that desperately need healthy friendships and role models. We teach songwriting, recording and help young people learn new instruments and form bands together. As part of our mentoring, we offer every young person the ability to complete accredited qualifications, through Bronze and Silver Arts Awards.

grants.title: Grant to African Families in the UK (AFiUK) CIC
grants.description: to provide food and support to BAME residents in Colchester in partnership with the community hub during COVID19

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Improve life skills, education, employability and enterprise

recipientOrganization.name: African Families in the UK (AFiUK) CIC
recipientOrganization.description: African Families in the UK(AFiUK) CIC was founded in 2015 in order to meet the needs of the needs of the for families of African origin and other BAME communities resident in the UK. It identified that there were barriers that prevented the community in fully participating in making the most of their lives. The organization has been delivering varied projects across Colchester which address the needs of the BAME community. Delivering these projects has given it a unique insight into both the needs of the community and the best ways to meet those needs. We have focussed our work in the areas of health, parenting and raising cultural awareness. One of the unique projects is the women & girls group called the Uhuru (Freedom) Project in partnership with Stop the Traffik, which has been giving a voice to women & girls in BAME Communities. Our Vision The vision of AFiUK is to equip the African Family in the UK to take its rightful place as fruitful members of the society, and to make the most of the available opportunities in their adopted country without adversely affecting the strong family and community networks that Africans are known for.

grants.title: Grant to St John Ambulance Essex
grants.description: to purchase equipment for use by the volunteer staff of St John Ambulance in their ambulances as they provide support for the NHS across Essex during the COVID19 pandemic

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: St John Ambulance Essex
recipientOrganization.description: St John Ambulance is the nation’s leading first aid charity. Started in July 1877. Every year, more than 400,000 people learn how to save a life through our training programmes, including hundreds of thousands of young people. Our volunteers provide first aid in their communities, keeping people safe at events, and working alongside the NHS in response to 999 calls. We’re also always campaigning to raise awareness of first aid and directly educate the public. Event services – We provide medical cover for events – from major sporting fixtures and music festivals to public gatherings. Community first responders – Our volunteers are trained to attend emergency calls and provide care until the ambulance arrives. Ambulance services – We play a crucial role in supporting the emergency services, responding to local incidents and major accidents. Volunteering – Our volunteers provide first aid in their communities, keeping people safe at events, and working with the NHS when lives are on the line. Workplace training – We’re the leading provider of workplace training, reaching over 250,000 people a year. Young people and schools – Over half of the people we train are under 18. We don’t just teach life saving skills – we offer life saving opportunities as well. Teaching in the community – We give people access to important skills they wouldn’t otherwise get the chance to learn. First aid is such a simple skill, but it has an incredible impact. We want everyone to learn it, so that they can be the difference between a life lost and a life saved. We don't want anyone to suffer due to a lack of available first aid.

grants.title: Grant to BOSP Brighter Opportunities for Special People
grants.description: towards salaries and overheads of an organisation supporting children with additional needs across Basildon throughout COVID19

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: BOSP Brighter Opportunities for Special People
recipientOrganization.description: BOSP’s aim is to improve the health and well-being of children and young people with complex disabilities or life-limiting illnesses so they can remain in their local communities. Our objectives are to empower children/young people through delivery of exciting fully supported structured activity sessions; helping to develop their independence, self-esteem, physical and communication skills to enjoy a happier and better quality of life both inside home and within wider community. BOSP clubs enable children/young people, whether they have complex health needs, profound physical disabilities, require specialist feeding, have very challenging behaviours; options to access fun activities readily available to their mainstream peers; whilst relieving family pressures by providing vital respite. High staff ratios ensure most healthcare, communication, social and physical needs are met, ensuring safety of everyone in the setting. Our services provide, amongst others, specific life skills of shopping, preparing food, travel, being out and about in the community. All required by young disabled people to stay healthy and as self-sufficient as possible in their future. BOSP reaches further than immediate beneficiaries of disabled children/young people. Other providers support a lower level need and/or where parent/guardians have to remain present or use less staff. This is cheaper plus easier to deliver as parents remain responsible but is not what disabled children/young people or families really need, being far less effective in achieving identified outcomes of developing independence and self-support life skills, plus does not deliver the respite that parents/guardians we know use to improve their own life opportunities via training courses, attend work, undertake exercise. Our services deliver results. We have proven time and again we reduce isolation and empower disabled children/young people to go forwards in their lives. ECF currently funding our Out and About in Community project ceasing 31/3/20. Successful project with attendees plus parents/guardians making positive comments regarding venues chosen and beneficial outcomes achieved. Monitoring report already submitted plus final report due at project end. Example user comments are: *name change *Jane: initially overawed, portraying loudly both verbally/actions. Became calmer, more friendly, recognising has ‘more responsibility’ (her words). *Angela: Mum reliant. Expanded network, learning to make appropriate friends, now contented when out in community. *Paul: obsessive about things, unfriendly/unapproachable. Learnt to select activities, built friendships, becoming interested in fitness. *Steve: noise sensitive (medication side effect). Wanted to join bowling sessions but frightened. Perseverance/mitigation plan to accommodate/adapt session accordingly. Now attends. Continuation funding: Well-known disabled children/young people are easily targeted to become crime victims or criminal action involvement. Feedback/learning from previously delivering project showed need for disabled children/young people to be made aware of dangers. Planned enhancement, should application be successful, is extend remit to include knowledge of ‘stranger danger’ plus awareness of enticement/becoming crime victims then how to mitigate.

grants.title: Grant to Deafblind UK
grants.description: to support people who are deafblind in Essex during the COVID19 crisis

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Deafblind UK
recipientOrganization.description: Deafblindness is most commonly associated with ageing, but can result at any age from congenital or other medical conditions such as Usher's syndrome, diabetes and stroke, or as a result of injury. Robbed of the ability to carry out the most basic of everyday tasks (such as communicating with friends and family, finding information, making a meal) people living with deafblindness can find themselves in unimaginable social, emotional and physical isolation. Deafblind UK (DBUK) is a membership organisation of, and governed by, people who have deafblindness. It is our vision that people living with deafblindness have the same rights, access and opportunities as others. We deliver quality services that give people with the condition autonomy and control over their lives.Through our work, we support equality , independence and choice. We do this by: - Ensuring that people with dual sensory loss have full representation on our Board of Directors - Raising awareness and understanding of deafblindness - Supporting people with deafblindness to remain in their own homes and participate in their local communities - Providing high quality peer support, volunteer companions, information and advice services to help people living with deafblindness live independently, interact with others, understand what rights they have, and access the services and benefits they are entitled to. Our services have been designed to: - improve our members' confidence and independence - reduce their feelings of isolation - enable them to have better access to information - improve their physical and emotional health The services we provide include: - Outreach (our local community outreach service supports people on-the-ground, helping with everyday problems) - An information and advice line which is made accessible to as many people as possible with textphones, Typetalk, texting and email - We make wellbeing calls to our members to let them know that we are here for them and to give them the opportunity to tell us if we can support them further - Peer Support & Social Groups (supporting our members to engage with their local communities, giving them the opportunity to leave the house and meet with others) - Volunteer companions who give members meaningful and engaging human interaction that dual sensory loss can make difficult - Digital Inclusion (supporting people to make the most of their digital technology by showing them how to use in-built accessibility features as well as third-party software and apps). Enabling our members to keep in touch with others, and to use the internet for shopping, banking and accessing information - Accessible holidays in our specially adapted caravans in Norfolk and Wales - A Casework service where we provide bespoke and individual one-to-one support, empowering more people to resolve their own issues, making sure their voices are heard and that they are able to make informed decisions - A quarterly magazine, 'Open Hand' that includes relevant and useful information and is available in a range of accessible formats

grants.title: Grant to One Community Development Trust
grants.description: to support an organisation giving advice during the COVID19 crisis

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Improve life skills, education, employability and enterprise

recipientOrganization.name: One Community Development Trust
recipientOrganization.description: One Community is a home grown, DIY charitable organisation created by the needs of the local people of Tilbury during the peak of the recession of 2008 for the benefit of their community. Our vision is to inspire and support local people to work actively together to achieve the best for themselves and their community with the ultimate aim of improving their quality of life, and creating economic prosperity. We work with the most disadvantaged communities – particularly residents in Tilbury Riverside & Thurrock Park and Tilbury St Chads who are 61% of the Tilbury population and among the 20% most deprived in England (IMD 2015, Tilbury Community Local-Led Development Strategy 2016). Our strategic objectives are to develop the capacity and skills of local people; to work in partnership with others to promote community well-being; to own, manage or maintain affordable, accessible and thriving community facilities; and to create a sustainable community anchor organisation. All our projects are needs-led and we actively encourage involvement and volunteering from people of all backgrounds. The work we are currently delivering involves supporting the marginalised and the unemployed as we find these are the people who are most vulnerable. This group of people often find themselves removed from main stream activity which does not have many public places for people to meet and gather together. There is currently no jobcentre, leisure centre, pub or bank. We offer a free drop-in coffee morning with a Work Club on Mondays, to support employment opportunities thereby creating economic prosperity. Our community shop is available 24/7 for small group activity for people to come together to do things that would alleviate isolation and worthlessness. We have a project called ‘Little Things that Mean A lot’ for people experiencing barriers on issues that are stopping them from accessing jobs and getting on with their lives. There are some local residents who live in a nearby estate, who have formed a group called ‘LinkUp’ to support others who need recreational activity living on a council estate. We are generally seen as a One Stop Shop where nobody is turned away. We also support the organising of various community events like family fun days to boost the well-being of people in the area. Our TLC Project helps to reduce loneliness and isolation by offering free group therapeutic workshops and peer support through volunteering. It encourages participation in activities that bring people together to connect with the local community. So far this year, we have supported the organising of a walk2connect during the month of March which attracted 60 sign-ups with our local MP Jackie Doyle-Price coming out to do the walk with us as the cabinet Minister who was the parliamentary Under Secretary of state for Mental Health, inequalities and suicide prevention at the time, and her partner Councillor Mark Coxshall who also came on the walk in support. This definitely sent out the right message about the benefits of exercise and group activity to combat loneliness and isolation. We had a Tilbury Carnival in July which attracted over 3000 local people, and in August did a Seaside Special Family Fun Day trip to Southend-on-sea with over 350 local residents and their families enjoying a free private train ride courtesy of c2c rail. We run a supported volunteering called Volunteer Investment Programme (VIP) which is designed to get people back into work regardless of their lack of work experience or disadvantaged due to prejudice, discrimination disability, age, sexual orientation, race etc. We encourage peer support and mentoring to ensure we are a community who are helping ourselves. We received a Bringing Communities Together Award in 2019 from Tilbury on Thames Trust, we won the Queen’s Award for Voluntary Service in June 2018, and local impact award in 2017 due to the outcomes that we have achieved for local people. We were visited by Jeremy Corbyn in November 2018 during his budget rounds. We have quantifiable evidence of the difference our work has made over the years. For example we have an average of 25 volunteers who start on the VIP programme every six months, whom we have encouraged to volunteer due to low self-esteem, never had a job, or have additional needs (physically, mentally or emotionally) and other issues. They are usually people who are not engaged thus feeling isolated. We measure our impact by tracking their progress through individual personal development portfolio that we create for each volunteer. In each case 90% report of feeling confident to getting involved in the community after a six month period, and at least 50% get into further training, traditional volunteering, paid employment or set up a support group or a small business. We get an average of 350 people use our One Community Shop for various activities during the course of one month, and first time people average 20 during the same period. We follow-up by making phone-calls to find out if they feel their situations were dealt with sufficiently to allow them to get connected in the community. We also partner with other organisations to achieve outcomes for individuals. The area is now more diverse than ever before with 14% of people coming from ethnic minority backgrounds due to its proximity to London for work, and London Boroughs moving their most vulnerable tenants out of the capital to places that are cheaper to house them. However, this brings its own set of challenges for the people who have been transferred into an area that is totally unfamiliar to them. We piloted a project called ‘New Beginnings’ last year to support them to get to know the area and meet people from similar backgrounds, as well as from the indigenous communities. Finally, we are a Hate Incident Reporting Centre (HIRC) with trained ambassadors who support people as and when they phone, report, or come into the shop with hate crime related incidents.
